question_21: Who is the main character in Outcasts United?
answert_21: Luma Mufleh is a young Jordanian woman from a family of privilege. She studies in the United States, but her father disowns her when she decides not to return to her homeland. Luma is an avid soccer player.
question_22: Why did Luma decide to stay in the United States?
answert_22: Luma Mufleh, a Jordanian-born graduate of Smith College, grew up in Amman, the daughter of a wealthy businessman and a doting mother. But her decision to stay in the United States after college drove a wedge between Luma and her parents. Luma joined in.

question_2: Who is Tito in Outcasts United?
answert_2: A Liberian player who Osman recruited to the Under Fifteen Fugees. Tito pretends to be in a gang and, as a result, is shot in the face by an American teenager. Luma then kicks him off the team, worried that the gangs will try to come after other Fugees.

answert_1: Argentina is a vast country whose dramatic mountain landscapes and long coastline lends itself to outdoor sports. Popular activities include canoeing, cycling, diving, hiking, rock climbing and mountaineering, skiing, surfing, windsurfing

question_6: What are some of Argentina's culture?
answert_6: Argentine culture is a blend of European customs and Latin American and indigenous traditions. Argentines are quite proud of their nation and its blended heritage as well as their ability to rise above adversity. They are also proud of their talents in many fields.

question_1: Is outer dark a good book?

question_2: Who are the trio in outer dark?
answert_2: The three men are the id, but also subdivided into id, the dumbest and most animal of the three, and the other two represent primitive ego and primitive superego. This is the exact schema as the dark three which appear in Joseph Conrad's novel, VICTORY.
question_3: What religion is Cormac McCarthy?
answert_3: agnostic
question_4: Is Cormac McCarthy writing a new book?
answert_4: After incubating for some 30 years, Cormac McCarthy's next novel just made a dramatic first entrance onto the public stage. The reading is the first public confirmation of the novel and its title, long the subject of rumors in the literary world.
question_5: What is the book outer dark about?
answert_5: Outer Dark is the second novel by American writer Cormac McCarthy, published in 1968. The novel tells of a woman named Rinthy who bears her brother's baby. The brother, Culla, leaves the nameless infant in the woods to die, but tells his sister that the newborn died of natural causes and had to be buried.

question_8: How does outer Dark end?

Culla later watches the blind man walking towards a swamp, which for him means certain death. The novel ends with Culla thinking Someone should tell a blind man before setting him out that way.

question_11: Is Cormac McCarthy nihilist?
answert_11: Cormac McCarthy, byname of Charles McCarthy, Jr., (born July 20, 1933, Providence, Rhode Island, U.S.), American writer in the Southern gothic tradition whose novels about wayward characters in the rural American South and Southwest are noted for their dark violence, dense prose, and stylistic complexity.
question_12: Is Cormac McCarthy like Hemingway?
answert_12: Cormac McCarthy's later works all portray a nihilistic literary cosmos that rejects the notion of a world governed by moral justice. Bell states, in McCarthy's novels ethical categories do not rule, and moral considerations seem not to affect outcomes (31- 32).
question_13: Why did Cormac McCarthy change his name?
answert_13: Most of McCarthy reads more like Faulkner than Hemingway. He's more like a Melville for modern times.
question_14: Is Cormac McCarthy still writing?
answert_14: Cormac McCarthy is not dead. But if you checked Twitter on Tuesday morning, you might have thought he was. An account claiming to be affiliated with publisher Alfred A. Knopf reported that legendary novelist Cormac McCarthy, author of The Road and No Country for Old Men, had died.

question_1: Who died in out of this furnace?
answert_1: A man outside informs Kracha that Mike has fatally burned in an accident at the steel mill. Cursing his fate at having to break the horrible news to Mary, Kracha goes into her bedroom and tells her that Mike is dead. Mary receives $1,300 from the company as compensation for Mike's death, yet she has no time to grieve.
question_2: Why was out of this furnace written?
answert_2: The Historical fiction novel, Out of This Furnace, was written by Thomas bell to illustrate the steel industry in America between the 1880s and 1930s.
question_3: Why did Kracha come to America?
answert_3: George Kracha is an immigrant who leaves Hungarian-ruled Slovakia in 1881 to seek work in western Pennsylvania, where his relatives reside. Unable to afford transportation, he walks to Pennsylvania, where he meets up with his sister, Francka and her husband, Andrei, and works on the railroad.
question_4: When was Out of This Furnace written?
question_5: How does Mike die in out of This Furnace?
answert_5: The impotence of steel workers to improve their lot in the face of the unshakable power of the steel bosses and the Republican Party leads him to despair, and he eventually dies in a mill accident, a victim of the latter groups'greed.
question_6: Who is spetz out of this furnace?
answert_6: A foul-mouthed Irishman and Mike Dobrejcak's immediate furnace-gang boss at the Braddock steel mill. A Hungarian-born Jew who opens up a rival butcher shop near George Kracha's own butcher shop. When word spreads of Kracha's affair with Zuska, Spetz successfully poaches many of Kracha's scorned customers.
question_7: Where was Djuro Kracha from?
answert_7: Slovakia
question_8: When was out of this furnace written?
question_9: What was Kracha's first job in America?
answert_9: Kracha eventually moves with his family first to Homestead and then to Braddock, where he gets a job in a steel mill.

question_1: What is the meaning of out out by Robert Frost?
answert_1: Out, Out tells the tragic tale of a boy injured in an accident. Just as he is about to go in for his dinner, his arm gets caught in a buzz sawhe loses his hand, and subsequently dies from blood loss. The poem is thus a stark reminder of the fragility of life, and that tragedy can happen to anyone at any time.
question_2: What is the tone of out out by Robert Frost?
answert_2: Out, Out'recreates a true-life tale, in which a boy loses his hand in an accident, the shock of which goes on to kill him sympathy is the dominant tone of the poem.
question_3: How does Robert Frost use imagery in out out?
answert_3: Imagery is used all over the poem Out, Out. Frost's use of symbolism in the poem is significant because constant in Frost's writing style. When the dead boy's friends, neighbors, and family were not the one dead, turned to their affairs (line 39) symbolizes that most people, once dead, are forgotten in time.
question_4: What is the mood of out out?
answert_4: The poem's tone is outrightly tragic. It is written in memory but the tone remains that of a sad surprise where the speaker is unable to digest the reality in which the boy lost his life so suddenly. The poem's tone is that of despair
question_5: What is the message of the poem out out?
answert_5: Out Out tells the story of a young boy who dies after his hand is severed by a buzz-saw. The poem focuses on people's reactions to death, as well as the death itself, one of the main ideas being that life goes on.
question_6: What is the meaning of the title out out by Robert Frost?
answert_6: Frost's title is a reference to Shakespeare's Macbeth. It alludes to Macbeth's speech after the death of his wife, where he comments on the frailty and pointlessness of life. The full text is: Out, out, brief candle! In Macbeth, Lady Macbeth is also torn up by her part in the murder of Duncan.
question_7: What does the saw symbolize in out out?
answert_7: The symbolism there is that the saw is having to carry the weight of what it has done to the boy in ending his life, which is also attributing human emotion to the saw. Figurative language can also be found in this poem.
question_8: What is the theme of Robert Frost's out out?
answert_8: The poem focuses on people's reactions to death, as well as the death itself, one of the main ideas being that life goes on. The boy lost his hand to a buzz saw and bled so much that he went into shock, dying in spite of his doctor's efforts. Frost uses personification to great effect throughout the poem.
question_9: How would you describe the tone of the poem?
answert_9: The tone of a poem is the attitude you feel in it the writer's attitude toward the subject or audience. Tone can be playful, humorous, regretful, anything and it can change as the poem goes along. When you speak, your tone of voice suggests your attitude.
question_10: What is the theme of Robert Frost's poems?
answert_10: Robert Frost used a lot of metaphors in his poetry. Although he covers many subjects and themes, the core themes of Robert Frost poems narrow down to nature and humanity
question_11: What literary device are used in out out by Robert Frost?
answert_11: Personification: Personification is to give human qualities to inanimate objects. For example, the saw, which is compared to a buzzing sound is personified, The buzz saw snarled and rattled in the yard; And made dust and dropped stove-length sticks of wood.
question_12: How does this imagery affect the poem?
answert_12: Imagery in poetry creates similar snapshots in a reader's mind. Poets use imagery to draw readers into a sensory experience. In essence, images show us meaning; when we compare the snapshots in our mind to our own memories or experiences, we connect emotionally to the poem.
question_13: What is the mood of the poem Out, Out?
answert_13: Out, Out'recreates a true-life tale, in which a boy loses his hand in an accident, the shock of which goes on to kill him sympathy is the dominant tone of the poem.
question_14: What is the theme of Out, Out?
answert_14: Major Themes in Out, Out: Death, child labor and fragility of life are the major themes of this poem. Robert Frost has highlighted the issue of child labor in this short poem. Although the boy performs man's tasks, he is still an innocent child at heart. The ending of the poem is callous, shocking, and cruel.
question_15: What is the meaning of the poem Out, Out?
answert_15: Out Out tells the story of a young boy who dies after his hand is severed by a buzz-saw. The poem focuses on people's reactions to death, as well as the death itself, one of the main ideas being that life goes on.
question_16: Who is the speaker in the poem Out, Out?
answert_16: In 'Out, Out-'by Robert Frost, the speaker is an unnamed narrator who appears to have been present when the boy suffered his saw accident.

question_20: Why is it titled Out, Out?
answert_20: Out Out tells the story of a young boy who dies after his hand is severed by a buzz-saw. The title of the poem is an allusion to tragedy Macbeth by William Shakespeare (Out, out, brief candle in the Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow soliloquy).
question_21: What is the source of the title of the poem Out, Out?
answert_21: The title of the poem, Out, Out has been borrowed from one of Macbeth's famous soliloquies in Shakespeare's tragedy Macbeth.Out here means death, as Macbeth meets the end of his life which is like a brief candle. The working boy's life ends as suddenly, so Shakespeare's phrase has a relevant echo in Frost's poem.
question_22: What does the saw symbolize in Out, Out?
answert_22: The symbolism there is that the saw is having to carry the weight of what it has done to the boy in ending his life, which is also attributing human emotion to the saw. Figurative language can also be found in this poem.
question_23: What does the saw in out out represent?
answert_23: Out, Out As a Representative of Death: The poem narrates the tragic death of a boy, who accidentally severed his hand while working on the farm. The young boy later dies in a shock. At the outset, the speaker presents a graphic description of a dangerous saw, which was the main cause of death.
question_24: What does dark of ether mean?
answert_24: Ether is a substance which was earlier used for anaesthesia. Putting in the dark of ether means the boy was anesthetised during operation and his consciousness went dark into it.
question_25: What was symbolized by the words the life from spilling?
answert_25: life is used as a metaphor for blood. The boy's first outcry was a rueful laugh, As he swung toward them holding up the hand, Half in appeal, but half as to keep the life from spilling. Then the boy saw all- Since he was old enough to know, big boy Doing a man's work, though a child at heart- he saw all spoiled.

question_1: What is the purpose of out out by Robert Frost?
answert_1: Out Out tells the story of a young boy who dies after his hand is severed by a buzz-saw. The poem focuses on people's reactions to death, as well as the death itself, one of the main ideas being that life goes on.
question_2: What is the main theme in Robert Frost's the soldier?
answert_2: In Frost's poem, the soldier's death is rather an opportunity for the poet's characteristic reflections on life's limits and freedoms, on boundaries, on the relationship between our place on earth and our aspiration to something else.
question_3: What is the tone of out out by Robert Frost?
answert_3: Out, Out'recreates a true-life tale, in which a boy loses his hand in an accident, the shock of which goes on to kill him sympathy is the dominant tone of the poem.
question_4: What is the meaning behind out out?
answert_4: Out, Out tells the tragic tale of a boy injured in an accident. Just as he is about to go in for his dinner, his arm gets caught in a buzz sawhe loses his hand, and subsequently dies from blood loss. The poem is thus a stark reminder of the fragility of life, and that tragedy can happen to anyone at any time.
question_5: What does the saw symbolize in out out?
answert_5: The symbolism there is that the saw is having to carry the weight of what it has done to the boy in ending his life, which is also attributing human emotion to the saw. Figurative language can also be found in this poem.
question_6: What is the tone of out out?
answert_6: The poem's tone is outrightly tragic. It is written in memory but the tone remains that of a sad surprise where the speaker is unable to digest the reality in which the boy lost his life so suddenly. The poem's tone is that of despair
question_7: What is the main idea of design by Robert Frost?
answert_7: Robert Frost's poem 'Design'ultimately argues that nature and humanity are ungoverned by God.
question_8: What type of poem is a soldier by Robert Frost?
answert_8: Answer: Robert Frost's poem, A Soldier, fashions a variation of the Elizabethan sonnet with the rime scheme of ABBA CDDC EFFE GG; it may be separated either into three stanzas and a rimed couplet, as is the Elizabethan sonnet, or it may be divided into the Petrarchan octave and sestet, also known as the Italian
question_9: What is the theme of the poem reluctance by Robert Frost?
answert_9: In the poem Reluctance by Robert Frost it is emphasized that humans should be reluctant to accepting change with unfavorable endings even if it is difficult as not doing so may lead to an empty life. Frost's use of an extended metaphor induces the emphasis of reluctance by comparing seasons to love.
question_10: What is Robert Frost's most important piece of literature?
answert_10: Robert Frost's most famous poems included The Gift Outright, Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening, Birches, Mending Wall, The Road Not Taken, and Nothing Gold Can Stay.
question_11: Which poem is Robert Frost's most popular poem?
answert_11: The Road Not Taken is not only the most famous poem of Robert Frost but among the most renowned ever written.
question_12: What is the theme of Robert Frost's out out?
answert_12: The poem focuses on people's reactions to death, as well as the death itself, one of the main ideas being that life goes on. The boy lost his hand to a buzz saw and bled so much that he went into shock, dying in spite of his doctor's efforts. Frost uses personification to great effect throughout the poem.
question_13: How would you describe the tone of the poem?
answert_13: The tone of a poem is the attitude you feel in it the writer's attitude toward the subject or audience. Tone can be playful, humorous, regretful, anything and it can change as the poem goes along. When you speak, your tone of voice suggests your attitude.
question_14: What is the theme of Robert Frost's poems?
answert_14: Robert Frost used a lot of metaphors in his poetry. Although he covers many subjects and themes, the core themes of Robert Frost poems narrow down to nature and humanity
question_15: What is the story behind the poem out out?
answert_15: Out Out tells the story of a young boy who dies after his hand is severed by a buzz-saw. The boy lost his hand to a buzz saw and bled so much that he went into shock, dying in spite of his doctor's efforts. Frost uses personification to great effect throughout the poem.
question_16: What is the theme or message of the poem out out?
answert_16: Major Themes in Out, Out: Death, child labor and fragility of life are the major themes of this poem. Robert Frost has highlighted the issue of child labor in this short poem. Although the boy performs man's tasks, he is still an innocent child at heart. The ending of the poem is callous, shocking, and cruel.
question_17: What is the moral of the poem out out?
answert_17: The central moral of this poem is how serious the effects of child labor are: a boy doing a man's job. Though a child at heart, the maturity forced upon him beyond his years enables him to see that his life would be handicapped without the hand. He eagerly pleads for it, not to cut it off as a useless part.
question_18: What does the saw in out out represent?
answert_18: Out, Out As a Representative of Death: The poem narrates the tragic death of a boy, who accidentally severed his hand while working on the farm. The young boy later dies in a shock. At the outset, the speaker presents a graphic description of a dangerous saw, which was the main cause of death.
question_19: What does dark of ether mean?
answert_19: Ether is a substance which was earlier used for anaesthesia. Putting in the dark of ether means the boy was anesthetised during operation and his consciousness went dark into it.

question_1: Who died in out of This Furnace?
answert_1: A man outside informs Kracha that Mike has fatally burned in an accident at the steel mill. Cursing his fate at having to break the horrible news to Mary, Kracha goes into her bedroom and tells her that Mike is dead. Mary receives $1,300 from the company as compensation for Mike's death, yet she has no time to grieve.
question_2: Why was out of this furnace written?
answert_2: The Historical fiction novel, Out of This Furnace, was written by Thomas bell to illustrate the steel industry in America between the 1880s and 1930s.
question_3: Why did Kracha come to America?
answert_3: George Kracha is an immigrant who leaves Hungarian-ruled Slovakia in 1881 to seek work in western Pennsylvania, where his relatives reside. Unable to afford transportation, he walks to Pennsylvania, where he meets up with his sister, Francka and her husband, Andrei, and works on the railroad.
question_4: What year does out of This Furnace take place?
answert_4: The novel focuses on the steelworkers'attempt to unionize from 1889, the first Homestead strike (mentioned by Andrej on p. 38) through the big Homestead Steel Strike of 1892, the Great Steel Strike of 1919 right after World War I, and the events of the 1930s.
question_5: How does Mike die in out of This Furnace?
answert_5: The impotence of steel workers to improve their lot in the face of the unshakable power of the steel bosses and the Republican Party leads him to despair, and he eventually dies in a mill accident, a victim of the latter groups'greed.
question_6: Who is spetz out of this furnace?
answert_6: A foul-mouthed Irishman and Mike Dobrejcak's immediate furnace-gang boss at the Braddock steel mill. A Hungarian-born Jew who opens up a rival butcher shop near George Kracha's own butcher shop. When word spreads of Kracha's affair with Zuska, Spetz successfully poaches many of Kracha's scorned customers.

answert_7: Slovakia

question_1: What is the point of Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_1: Out of the Silent Planet gives voice to Lewis's concerns about the secularization of society and affirms that a return to traditional religious belief is the only means of its salvation.
question_2: What happened at the end of Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_2: After a morning of sailing to the lake, Hyoi and Ransom sight the hnakra and manage to kill it, though wrecking their boat in the process. On the shore, Hyoi and Ransom celebrate their victory, but their triumph is cut short when Weston fires a gun from the nearby forest and hits Hyoi in the chest, killing him.
question_3: What does Bent mean in Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_3: Bent in this context means corrupt or fallen. Because Earth has become bent, it has lost communication with the other worlds in The Field of Arbol, and is known as the Silent Planet or Thulcandra.
question_4: How does Ransom avoid evil in Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_4: Lewis'character, Ransom, from his science fiction novel, Out of The Silent Planet. He proves to be virtuous throughout the story by retrieving a young man whom he did not know, by hunting an alien beast with an alien tribe, and by visiting the alien 'leader'
question_5: What does Out of the Silent Planet say about virtue?
answert_5: Virtue is Virtue is a concept that has been forgotten by society. Many believe that by avoiding evil and wrong they are being virtuous, but this is not all you need to do to be virtuous.
question_6: What happens in the book Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_6: Plot. While on a walking tour, the philologist Elwin Ransom is drugged and taken on board a spacecraft bound for a planet called Malacandra. His abductors are Devine, a former college acquaintance, and the scientist Weston.

question_10: What is the climax of Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_10: Out of the Silent Planet reaches its climax when Weston and the Oyarsa confront one another through the medium of Ransom in a massive village meeting that resembles something out of a 1930s adventure movie. Weston justifies his own actions. Ransom then tells his story to his friend and colleague, C.S. Lewis.
question_11: What is the message of Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_11: The main themes in Out of the Silent Planet are Christianity, racism, and friendship. Christianity: As an omniscient, omnipresent, yet invisible being, Oyarsa stands in for the Christian God, and the utopian nature of Malacandra represents Lewis's vision of the harmony and goodness of Christianity.
question_12: What happens when the spaceship lands in Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_12: In Out of the Silent Planet, Ransom is kidnapped and taken on this spaceship with Devine and Weston to Malacandra to be sacrificed to the Sorns. They use the same spaceship near the end of the book to fly back to Earth.

question_15: What does Handramit mean?
answert_15: Handramit low country of Malacandra. Harandra high country of Malacandra. Hman Hross word for man. Hnakra a specific swimming creature on Malacandra. Hnau person or intelligent created being; not specific to planet of origin.
question_16: What is a Hnakra in Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_16: The hnakra, a shark-like creature that lives in one of the lakes on Malacandra (Mars), first seems to represent all of the terrible things that Dr. Ransom expects from the lifeforms on this alien planet. Lewis uses the hnakra as a symbol of the inescapable place of pain or evil in human lives.
question_17: How did Ransom avoid evil?

question_18: How does Ransom get back to Earth?
answert_18: Ransom's meeting with Oyarsa is interrupted when a group of hrossa bring in Weston and Devine to stand trial for killing three hrossa (including Hyoi). Ransom decides to go with his fellow humans and bring news of the paradise of Malacandra and the will of Maleldil back to Earth.
question_19: Who is the hero in Out of the Silent Planet?
answert_19: Elwin Ransom
question_20: How is HYOI killed and why does Ransom feel responsible?
answert_20: Hyoi is killed by Weston and Devine while Hyoi and Ransom are on a mission to hunt the hnakra (a shark-like creature). Hyoi dies content with his identity as a hnakrapunt (one who has killed the hnakra), rather than resenting the fact that his time was cut short by bent humans.

answert_24: Perelandra, second novel in a science-fiction trilogy by C.S. Although sometimes criticized as having a sexist view of women, Perelandra nevertheless succeeds as both science fiction and religious allegory.
question_25: Is the space trilogy an allegory?
answert_25: There is a dual allegory in the text; not only do the Green Lady and her husband represent Eve and Adam, but also Ransom's role is also allegorical to Christ's. As Downing explains, there are several similarities between Ransom in this story and Jesus in the Gospels.

question_10: What does Bent mean in Out of the Silent Planet?

question_11: What are Eldila perelandra?

question_19: What is Oyarsa?

answert_4: George Kracha is an immigrant who leaves Hungarian-ruled Slovakia in 1881 to seek work in western Pennsylvania, where his relatives reside. The hnakra, unlike any of the other beings on Malacandra, is a purely evil creature who seeks only to hurt others.

question_1: What is the moral of Out of the Dust?
answert_1: Major themes in Out of the Dust include loss and forgiveness, family, and the environment. Hesse's thematic messages convey the power of the human spirit to endure and transcend the pain that accompanies adversity and tragedy.
question_2: What is the summary of Out of the Dust?
answert_2: A poem cycle that reads as a novel, Out of the Dust tells the story of a girl named Billie Jo, who struggles to help her family survive the dust-bowl years of the Depression. Fighting against the elements on her Oklahoma farm, Billie Jo takes on even more responsibilities when her mother dies in a tragic accident.
question_3: How did Billie Jo get Out of the Dust?
answert_3: The breaking point for Billie Jo comes when her father ignores some spots on his skin, even though skin cancer killed his father. Billie Jo believes Daddy would rather be dead with her Ma than alive with her, and she runs away, hopping on a freight train to get away from the dust that has consumed her life.
question_4: Does Out of the Dust have a happy ending?
answert_4: The ending of the book finds us in the Kelby home with Daddy and Louise on the verge of being married, the family's new course falling into place. Billie Jo has the strength to use her hands againboth mentally and physicallyand returning to the piano is the perfect way to show that.
question_5: What does the dust symbolize in Out of the Dust?
answert_5: Just as the apple trees symbolically reference Ma's life and legacy, rain is always portrayed as a symbol of hope. If dust represents hardship, rain represents the hope that someday, something better will emerge from it.
question_6: What does Billie Jo learn when she runs away?
answert_6: Frightened, Billie Jo runs away to the neighbor's abandoned farmhouse and finds a piano inside. She plays, and the music sounds like it should, unlike the noise at home. So she hauls the piano back to her own house, only to discover that her hands are swollen, painful and weeping with pus.
question_7: Is Out of the Dust a true story?

question_8: Why did Billie Jo run away in Out of the Dust?

question_13: How did Billie Jo burn her hands in out of the dust?
answert_13: The Accident Not knowing she's coming back and wanting to get the flaming pail out of the house, Billie Jo grabs it to take it outside. question_4: Why did Karen Hesse write Out of the Dust?
answert_4: Hesse and her husband had two daughters, one in 1979 and another in 1982, and motherhood became a priority and a demand on Hesse's time. As a result, she put poetry writing on hold. She was rewarded for her efforts in 1998, when she won the Newbery Medal for Out of the Dust, a novel written entirely in free verse.

question_10: Is losing a theme?
answert_10: Loss'has been a recurring theme in literature for centuries, from early poets such as William Shakespeare who portrays loss in many of his tragedies including the loss of sanity in 'King Lear'and the loss of reputation in 'Othello', through to Keats's 'Odes'and into the twentieth and twenty-first century.
question_11: What was the main effect of the Dust Bowl?
answert_11: The drought, winds and dust clouds of the Dust Bowl killed important crops (like wheat), caused ecological harm, and resulted in and exasperated poverty. question_2: Who is Jacqueline Krik Krak?

question_5: What does Krik Krak mean in Haitian?
answert_5: In Haiti, if someone is going to tell a story, they'll say Krik? If the people listening want to hear the story, they'll respond, Krak! It's a way for a storyteller to get the audience ready, similar to, Come gather round in English, but it makes the audience more active.
question_6: What does the Madonna symbolize in Krik Krak?

question_7: What is a wall of fire rising?
answert_7: A Wall of Fire Rising is a short story about a man who dreams of escaping his life of poverty in Haiti. Guy lives with his wife, Lili, and their young son, Little Guy. He obtains a job cleaning latrines at the sugar mill, while Little Guy is cast as the lead in the school play.

question_1: What was the name of Krishna's conch?

question_3: How Did Krishna get his conch?
answert_3: After completing their study, Krishna and Balaram want to give guru dakshina to guru Sandipani. Sandipani already knew the power of both so he asked for his son who was drowned in the sea. To fulfill this, Krishna went into the sea where he killed demon Panchjanya and got the conch.

question_9: What was the names of Krishna and Arjuna conch shell?

question_1: What is the significance of the statue Kritios Boy?
answert_1: The Kritios boy is well known for being one of the earliest statues of the Classical period. His contrapposto stance is indicative of the aims of Classical sculptors, exemplifying the natural volumes of the human body.
question_2: What type of sculpture is the Kritios Boy?
question_3: Is Kritios a boy Kouros?
answert_3: Kritios Boy
question_4: Where is the Kritios Boy now?
answert_4: the Acropolis Museum
question_5: Why is the sculpture of the Kritios Boy so significant for the study of art history?
answert_5: The Kritios Boy belongs to the early Classical period of ancient Greek sculpture from 480 BC. It is the first statue known to use the contrapposto posture. With the Kritios Boy, the Greek artist has mastered a complete understanding of how the different parts of the body act as a system.
question_6: What characteristic in Kritios Boy makes it so important in artistic development?
answert_6: When the human body moves, the body's complex skeletal and muscular system ensure a smooth, harmonious, and flowing movement of all the body parts involved. The significance of Kritios Boy can not be overstated because its sculptor was one of the first to grasp this fact and reflect that in his artwork.
question_7: What did the kore statue represent?
answert_7: The kore statue had two main purposes. Korai were used as votive offerings to deities, mainly goddesses such as Athena and Artemis. Votive offerings are gifts given to the deities for worship or payment for favors. Both men and women offered the kore statues.
question_8: What kind of statue is Kritios Boy?
answert_8: Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology the Ancient World The Kritios or Kritian Boy dates to the Late Archaic period 490-480 B.C.E. The statue is thus named because it is attributed to Kritios, who worked along with Nesiotes, or their school of teaching. The statue is made of marble and is smaller than life-size.
question_9: What kind of statue is Kritios boy?
answert_9: Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology the Ancient World The Kritios or Kritian Boy dates to the Late Archaic period 490-480 B.C.E. The statue is thus named because it is attributed to Kritios, who worked along with Nesiotes, or their school of teaching. The statue is made of marble and is smaller than life-size.
question_10: Is Kritios boy Archaic or classical?
answert_10: The Kritios Boy is the best surviving example of the transitional phase of Greek sculpture between the late Archaic style and the early Classical.
question_11: What kind of sculpture is kouros?
answert_11: A kouros is a statue of a standing nude youth that did not represent any one individual youth but the idea of youth. Used in Archaic Greece as both a dedication to the gods in sanctuaries and as a grave monument, the standard kouros stood with his left foot forward, arms at his sides, looking straight ahead.
question_12: Why is the sculpture of the Kritios boy so significant for the study of art history?
answert_12: The Kritios Boy belongs to the early Classical period of ancient Greek sculpture from 480 BC. It is the first statue known to use the contrapposto posture. With the Kritios Boy, the Greek artist has mastered a complete understanding of how the different parts of the body act as a system.
question_13: What does the Kritios Boy represent?

The statue is thus named because it is attributed to Kritios, who worked along with Nesiotes, or their school of teaching. The statue is made of marble and is smaller than life-size.
question_14: Why is the date of Kritios Boy important?
answert_14: Through a distinct shift in the representation of the human body and its subsequent development in sculpture, the Kritios Boy emulates Greek ideals of harmony and order, and will influence the development of the Classical style. Kritios Boy (fig. 1) has been described as a young boy, perhaps a Greek hero.
question_15: Where does the Kritios come from in the title Kritios Boy?
answert_15: The Kritios boy belongs to the Late Archaic period and is considered the precursor to the later classical sculptures of athletes. With the Kritios Boy the Greek artist has mastered a complete understanding of how the different parts of the body act as a system.
question_16: When was the Kritios boy found?
answert_16: While the art still kept the principles, that of which are the human body shape, structure and design, the Kritios looks more like a modern human, compared to the Kouros. The arms are also missing from the Kritios which is another difference from Kouros. In addition, legs are also missing from the Kritios boy.

The significance of Kritios Boy can not be overstated because its sculptor was one of the first to grasp this fact and reflect that in his artwork.
question_21: What did the Greeks achieve with the Kritios Boy statue?

question_22: Why were sculptures important in ancient Greece?
answert_22: In the world of the ancient Greeks there was a very close relationship between sculpture and architecture. Both temples and sculptures were created in order to honour the gods and the sculptures were not just an embellishment of the temple; together they combined to form an integrated and harmonious whole.
question_23: What is the significance of Kritios Boy in the development of art?
answert_23: The Kritios boy is well known for being one of the earliest statues of the Classical period. His contrapposto stance is indicative of the aims of Classical sculptors, exemplifying the natural volumes of the human body.
question_24: What compositional development is depicted in the sculpture Kritios Boy?
answert_24: Kritios Boy The torso depicts an understanding of the body and plasticity of the muscles and skin that allows the statue to come to life. Part of this illusion is created by a stance known as contrapposto.

question_1: Where does Krebs cycle occur in photosynthesis?
answert_1: mitochondrion
question_2: Do plants go through the Krebs cycle?
answert_2: Plants are no exception. Plants respire in the normal way using glycolysis, Krebs cycle, oxidative phosphorylation etc. Often, the respiration is masked by the fact that photosynthesis produces oxygen faster than respiration takes it up and photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide faster than respiration produces it.
question_3: Is the Krebs cycle the opposite of photosynthesis?
answert_3: In the Krebs Cycle, acetate is broken down further so that its remaining carbon atoms are released as CO2. This is opposite of one aspect of photosynthesis, the binding of carbons from CO2 together to make sugar.
question_4: What is produced during the Krebs cycle?
answert_4: Overview of the Krebs or citric acid cycle, which is a series of reactions that takes in acetyl CoA and produces carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP or GTP.
question_5: Does the Krebs cycle occur in photosynthesis?
answert_5: The Calvin cycle is part of the light-independent reactions of photosynthesis. The Calvin cycle uses ATP and NADPH. The Krebs cycle is part of cellular respiration.
question_6: Where does the Krebs cycle take place in plants?
answert_6: The Krebs cycle takes place within the mitochondrial matrix of mitochondria. Glycolysis occurs in the cell's cytosol. The stroma is part of plant chloroplasts, thus it is not the site of the Krebs cycle.
question_7: Does the Krebs cycle occur in the thylakoid?
answert_7: The Krebs cycle occurs in the mitochondria of a cell. This sausage-shaped organelle possesses inner and outer membranes and, therefore, an inner and outer compartment. The inner membrane is folded over itself many times; the folds are called cristae. They are somewhat similar to the thylakoid membranes in chloroplasts.
question_8: Does Krebs cycle occur in plants?
answert_8: Glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation are found in all eukaryotes (animals, plants, and fungi) and many of the aerobic prokaryotes. The purpose of these reaction pathways is to oxidize carbohydrates with O2, yielding CO2, H2O, and chemical energy in the form of ATP.
question_9: Do plants use the ATP cycle?
answert_9: The Calvin cycle is part of the light-independent reactions of photosynthesis. The Calvin cycle uses ATP and NADPH. The Krebs cycle is part of cellular respiration.
question_10: Do plants go through cellular respiration?
answert_10: ATP can be used to store energy for future reactions or be withdrawn to pay for reactions when energy is required by the cell. Animals store the energy obtained from the breakdown of food as ATP. Likewise, plants capture and store the energy they derive from light during photosynthesis in ATP molecules.
question_11: What is the opposite of the Krebs cycle?
answert_11: The reverse Krebs cycle (also known as the reverse tricarboxylic acid cycle, the reverse TCA cycle, or the reverse citric acid cycle, or the reductive tricarboxylic acid cycle, or the reductive TCA cycle) is a sequence of chemical reactions that are used by some bacteria to produce carbon compounds from carbon dioxide
question_12: What is the opposite of photosynthesis?
answert_12: respiration
question_13: Is the Krebs cycle apart of photosynthesis?
answert_13: The Calvin cycle is part of the light-independent reactions of photosynthesis. The Calvin cycle uses ATP and NADPH. The Krebs cycle is part of cellular respiration.
question_14: What type of respiration is the opposite of photosynthesis?
answert_14: cellular respiration
question_15: What is produced during the Krebs cycle quizlet?
answert_15: What are the Krebs Cycle products? Electron Carriers (NADH and FADH2), ATP, and Carbon Dioxide.
question_16: What are two products of the Krebs cycle?
answert_16: NADH and carbon dioxide are products of the Krebs Cycle.
question_17: Does the Krebs cycle occur in plants?
answert_17: mitochondrion
question_18: What cycle occurs in photosynthesis?
answert_18: Glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation are found in all eukaryotes (animals, plants, and fungi) and many of the aerobic prokaryotes.
question_19: What does Krebs cycle do and where does it occur?
answert_19: The two stages of photosynthesis: Photosynthesis takes place in two stages: light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle (light-independent reactions). Light-dependent reactions, which take place in the thylakoid membrane, use light energy to make ATP and NADPH.
question_20: Is the Krebs cycle found in plants?
answert_20: Mitochondria are found in almost all organisms, especially multicellular organisms. Plants, animals, and fungi all use the Krebs cycle as an indispensable part of aerobic respiration.
question_21: Where does the Krebs citric cycle take place?
answert_21: mitochondria

question_1: What happens in the Krebs cycle of aerobic respiration?
answert_1: The Krebs cycle is an eightstep cycle in which acetyl CoA is added to oxaloacetate, which is further broken down producing CO2, reduced coenzymes (NADH + H+ and FADH2), and ATP. During this step coenzyme A is added, carbon dioxide is lost, and NAD+ is reduced, forming NADH + H+.
question_2: Where does the Krebs cycle aerobic or anaerobic?
answert_2: The citric acid cycle (Kreb's cycle) is anaerobic, in that it doesn't require molecular oxygen itself. In eukaryotes, the citric acid cycle occurs in mitochondria, and the mitochondrial electron transport chain requires oxygen.
question_3: How many turns of the Krebs cycle are completed in aerobic respiration?
answert_3: Two turns
question_4: Is anaerobic respiration the same as the Krebs cycle?
answert_4: The main difference between fermentation and anaerobic respiration is that fermentation does not undergo citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle) and electron transport chain whereas anaerobic respiration undergoes citric acid cycle and electron transport chain.
question_5: What happens during Krebs cycle?
answert_5: The Krebs cycle is the second stage of cellular respiration. During the Krebs cycle, energy stored in pyruvate is transferred to NADH and FADH2, and some ATP is produced.
question_6: What are the 4 steps of the Krebs cycle?
answert_6:
Krebs cycle Steps
  • Oxidative Decarboxylation of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA.
  • Step 1: Condensation of acetyl CoA with oxaloacetate.
  • Step 2: Isomerization of citrate into isocitrate.
  • Step 3: Oxidative decarboxylations of isocitrate.
  • Step 4: Oxidative decarboxylation of u03b1-ketoglutarate.
question_7: What is the Krebs cycle in simple terms?
answert_7: Definition of Krebs cycle : a sequence of reactions in the living organism in which oxidation of acetic acid or acetyl equivalent provides energy for storage in phosphate bonds (as in ATP) called also citric acid cycle, tricarboxylic acid cycle.
question_8: Is Krebs cycle part of aerobic or anaerobic?
answert_8: Thus, if oxygen is not present, the respiratory cycle cannot function, which shuts down the Krebs cycle. For this reason, the Krebs cycle is considered an aerobic pathway for energy production.
question_9: Is Krebs cycle anaerobic process?
answert_9: Anaerobic processes do not require oxygen while aerobic processes do require oxygen. The Krebs cycle, however, is not that simple. Although the use of oxygen is not directly involved in the Krebs cycle, it is considered an aerobic process.
question_10: Does Krebs cycle aerobic?
answert_10: The tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs or citric acid cycle, is the main source of energy for cells and an important part of aerobic respiration.
question_11: Where does the citric acid cycle take place is it aerobic or anaerobic?
answert_11: Part of this is considered an aerobic pathway (oxygen-requiring) because the NADH and FADH2 produced must transfer their electrons to the next pathway in the system, which will use oxygen. If oxygen is not present, this transfer does not occur. The citric acid cycle does NOT occur in anaerobic respiration.
question_12: What is the Krebs cycle in aerobic respiration?
answert_12: The Krebs cycle is a series of chemical reactions used by all aerobic organisms to generate energy through the oxidization of acetatederived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins into carbon dioxide. Theoretically there are several alternatives to the TCA cycle, but the TCA cycle appears to be the most efficient.
question_13: How many times must the Krebs cycle turn for each glucose?
answert_13: This means that there are two turns of Krebs cycle for every glucose molecule and, therefore, for a given molecule of glucose Krebs cycle produces 6 NADH and 2 ATP. Glycolysis produces a net of 2 ATP and 2 NADH; therefore, Krebs cycle produces three times the NADH and the same amount of ATP as glycolysis.
question_14: How many ATP are made during 2 turns of the Krebs cycle?
answert_14: 4 ATP
question_15: What is completed in the Krebs cycle?
answert_15: At the end of the Krebs cycle, the final product is oxaloacetic acid. All told, the Krebs cycle forms (per two molecules of pyruvic acid) two ATP molecules, ten NADH molecules, and two FADH2 molecules. The NADH and the FADH2 will be used in the electron transport system.
question_16: Is Krebs cycle part of anaerobic respiration?
answert_16: Anaerobic processes do not require oxygen while aerobic processes do require oxygen. Although the use of oxygen is not directly involved in the Krebs cycle, it is considered an aerobic process.
question_17: What type of respiration is the Krebs cycle?
answert_17: aerobic respiration
question_18: Why is the Krebs cycle anaerobic process?
answert_18: The Krebs cycle does not use oxygen, though it does stop in the absence of oxygen because it runs out of NAD and FAD. Many of your body's cells can also use fatty acids in the Krebs cycle. Fatty acids are the major components of fats.
question_19: What happens in the Krebs cycles?
answert_19:
Krebs cycle Steps
  • Oxidative Decarboxylation of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA.
  • Step 1: Condensation of acetyl CoA with oxaloacetate.
  • Step 2: Isomerization of citrate into isocitrate.
  • Step 3: Oxidative decarboxylations of isocitrate.
  • Step 4: Oxidative decarboxylation of u03b1-ketoglutarate.
question_20: What happens during the Krebs cycle quizlet?
answert_20: The tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs or citric acid cycle, is the main source of energy for cells and an important part of aerobic respiration. The cycle harnesses the available chemical energy of acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl CoA) into the reducing power of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH)
question_21: What happens at Step 4 of the Krebs cycle?
answert_21: Step four of the Krebs Cycle: u03b1-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase In this case, the carbon atom that will form CO2 is oxidised. Furthermore, an energy-rich coenzyme A molecule (green background) is added so that succinyl-CoA is formed. At the end of this reaction, we get a C4 body.
question_22: What are the 4 products of the Krebs cycle?
answert_22: Overview of the Krebs or citric acid cycle, which is a series of reactions that takes in acetyl CoA and produces carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP or GTP.
question_23: What are the 5 steps of the Krebs cycle?
answert_23:
Steps in the Krebs Cycle
  • Step 1: Citrate synthase. The first step is to put energy into the system.
  • Step 2: Aconitase.
  • Step 3: Isocitrate dehydrogenase.
  • Step 4: u03b1-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
  • Step 5: Succinyl-CoA synthetase.
  • Step 6: Succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Step 7: Fumarase.
  • Step 8: Malate dehydrogenase.
question_24: What are the 4 dehydrogenase reactions in Krebs cycle?
answert_24: There are only 4 types of reactions in the Krebs Cycle: Condensation, Hydration/Dehydration, Redox, and Substrate level phosphorylation.
question_25: How do you explain the Krebs cycle?
answert_25: The Krebs cycle is a series of chemical reactions used by all aerobic organisms to generate energy through the oxidization of acetatederived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins into carbon dioxide. Theoretically there are several alternatives to the TCA cycle, but the TCA cycle appears to be the most efficient.

question_1: Why do Koreans say l'as R?
answert_1: A common struggle that Koreans have with pronunciation is with the L and R sounds. This is because they use u3139, which is somewhere between L and R. When writing down English words using Korean characters, this letter is used for both L and R, making Koreans accustomed to using this sound to replace both letters.
question_2: How do you read R and L in Korean?
answert_2: The English retroflex /r/ does not exist in Korean; Korean only has a phoneme /l/ with three distinct allophones: an apical flap [e] in the initial position (as in atom in English), a lateral [l] in the coda position, and a geminate [ll] in the intervocalic position.
question_3: Do Koreans mix up L and R?
answert_3: As a native Vietnamese speaker living South Korea, I observed that Korean does not have distinct L sound and R sound. Their u3139 sound is something in between.
question_4: Can Korean people pronounce L?
answert_4: Korean speakers pronounce L at the end of words as [u026d], which is how it is pronounced in Korean. This may sound like rl to some people, but it is different from both English R and English L. Japanese speakers are the ones who most often confuse R and L at the beginning of words.
question_5: How do Koreans pronounce their L?
answert_5: There is no r or equivalent sound in the Korean alphabet. u3139 can be pronounced a bit like the English L but it could also sound like the single r in Spanish but not exactly. There is no r or equivalent sound in the Korean alphabet.

answert_7: The letter r in Korean is u3139, which is also the letter l. If the u3139 is on the top/in the beginning like ub791 or ub978, it's pronounced like a Japanese r and romanized as r.
question_8: Is R and L the same in Korean?
answert_8: In Korean, the l and r sounds come from the same underlying consonant u3139. If the consonant u3139[rieul] is between two vowels, then it'll usually have the English r sound. However, if it's at the beginning or end of the word, or precedes a consonant, it'll have more of an English l sound.

answert_9: The answer is that speakers of one language tend to replace or mix up sounds of another language that they lack in their native tongue, and the [9] sound in American English isn't found in Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, and Cantonese.

question_19: How long does it take to learn Korean by yourself?
answert_19: It takes about three months or 90 days to learn enough Korean to have at least 3-minute conversations in Korean if you study for 7 to 10 hours per week. Moreover, after one year of looking at this pace, you will become fluent and comfortable with Korean conversation.
question_20: How many Korean words do you need to be fluent?
answert_20: If you want to live in Korea and have basic understanding of things, about 300 words is required as those core 300 words make up almost 80% of our conversations. If you want to understand the rest of them, meaning virtually 100% from conversations, TV, etc, 10,000 words sounds good.
question_21: How long will it take to be fluent in Korean?
answert_21: How long will it take to become fluent in Korean? In general, it will take about 1200 hours to reach a higher intermediate level of Korean skills. You will need additional practice, so you may want to double that number to 2400 hours to get towards fluency using this simple math.
question_22: How many words should I learn a day Korean?
answert_22: Teach yourself sentences and various grammar and pronunciation rules and you'll be considered good in no time. I recommend about three-five sentences a day in the beginning, then move up to any limit that fits you the most when you're a little more confident in Korean.
question_23: How many words do you need to know to be fluent?
answert_23: Advanced. An advanced speaker of a language is also categorized as fluent. Fluency means you've reached 10,000+ words and have reached the highest level of mastering a language without being a native speaker.

question_4: Should I learn Romanized Korean?

question_10: Who invented McCune Reischauer?
answert_10:
Rules in Brief
  • When u3145 is followed directly by u3163, it should be Romanized as shi.
  • To avoid confusion of syllables, a hyphen can be used.
  • When u3131, u3137, u3139, u3142 are found directly before vowel, they are Romanized as g, d, r, b.
  • When u3131, u3137, u3139, u3142 are found directly before a consonant, they should be Romanized as k, t, r, p.
question_11: Is it bad to learn Korean in romanization?
answert_11: As Korean is a language with a different alphabet than our roman one, it's important to get used to it as early as possible, as it will only get harder the longer you've only been using romanization. Learning romanization is not bad per se - actually, there's nothing to learn, that's the whole point of romanization.

question_9: Why is s not pronounced in Korean?
answert_9: The most confusing of this rule is when u3145 or u3146 are the last letters in a syllable. When either of these is the final letter of a syllable, they are NOT pronounced as 'S. 'Instead, they are pronounced similar to a 'D'sound.
question_10: Do Koreans pronounce the r?
answert_10: In Korean, the l and r sounds come from the same underlying consonant u3139. If the consonant u3139[rieul] is between two vowels, then it'll usually have the English r sound. However, if it's at the beginning or end of the word, or precedes a consonant, it'll have more of an English l sound.
question_11: Is N pronounced as d in Korean?
answert_11: Short and Abrupt Pronunciation of Korean The closest approximation to the Korean letter u3134 is n. However, sometimes it can sound pronounced like a d. The reason is that Koreans pronounce sounds shortly and abruptly sometimes.

question_13: How do I fix Korean pronunciation?
answert_13: Korean pronunciation is entirely different in structure compared to English pronunciation. But try to hear the difference.

question_1: Is North Korea friends with Cuba?
answert_1: History. Cuba has been one of North Korea's most consistent allies. North Korean media portrays Cubans as comrades in the common cause of socialism. During the Cold War, North Korea and Cuba forged a bond of solidarity based on their militant positions opposing American power.
question_2: What is considered rude in Cuba?
answert_2: CUBAN CULTURE: Taboos (especially for travelers). Try to avoid these taboos when in Cuba: Spitting on the ground or blowing your nose in public. Taking pictures of anyone (without first asking their permission). Littering (this is not only rude, but it's also against the law).
question_3: How many Chinese are in Cuba?
answert_3: Although only about 150 native Chinese live in Cuba today, in the mid-1800s, there were more than 100,000, nearly all of them men.
question_4: Are Cuban citizens allowed to leave Cuba?
answert_4: Travel and emigration. As of January 14, 2013, all Cuban government-imposed travel restrictions and controls have been abolished. Since that date, any Cuban citizen, with a valid passport, can leave the country at will, without let or hindrance from the Cuban authorities.
question_5: Does North Korea interact with other countries?
answert_5: North Korea is often perceived as the Hermit kingdom, completely isolated from the rest of the world, but North Korea maintains diplomatic relations with 164 independent states. The country also has bilateral relations with the State of Palestine, the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, and the European Union.
question_6: What countries are North Koreans allowed to visit?
answert_6: This doesn't happen but in theory it's possible. There are actually a few countries where North Koreans can travel without a visa. These are Guyana, Haiti, Kyrgyzstan, Micronesia and the Gambia. Kyrgyzstan actually allows North Koreans to stay in their country indefinably.
question_7: Which countries are not allowed to enter North Korea?
answert_7: Which countries cannot visit North Korea? The only country that North Korea restricts visitors from is South Korea (the Republic of Korea), whose citizens need special permission (from both governments).
question_8: Does Russia support Cuba?
answert_8: Since the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, Cuba and Russia have maintained their diplomatic relations. After Vladimir Putin came to power in 2000, relations between both countries increased.  Russia was the first country to provide aid to Cuba after three hurricanes devastated the country in the fall of 2008.
question_9: Do and don'ts in Cuba?
answert_9:
TEN DOS AND DON'TS FOR YOUR TRIP TO CUBA
  • Do dress down. Wondering what to bring to Cuba?
  • Do engage with the local population.
  • Do bring enough cash.
  • Don't patronize luxury hotels.
  • Do patronize paladares.
  • Do bring back Cuban goods.
  • Don't take pictures of the military or police.
  • Do immerse yourself in the amazing culture.
question_10: What should I avoid in Cuba?
answert_10:
13 Things you should NEVER DO in Cuba
  • #1 Don't criticize Fidel!
  • #2 Do not take pictures of the Police!
  • #3 Don't drink water from the tap!
  • #4 Don't bring American Express!
  • #5 Don't blow your nose in public!
  • # 6 Don't be confused with both Currencies!
  • #7 Don't bring Bling!
  • #8 Do not take taxis without a License!
question_11: Are people in Cuba friendly?
answert_11: Cubans are gregarious, friendly people. They will talk to just about anyone, and seem to spend the majority of their days in the company of others. Walking down the street in Cuba, you'll see people sitting outside their homes talking to neighbors. Cubans want visitors to have a positive experience in Cuba.
question_12: Is blowing your nose illegal in Cuba?
answert_12: Never blow your nose in public Unlike other Latin American countries, Cubans consider blowing your nose and spitting in public extremely offensive. Whenever possible excuse yourself and clear your nose in a bathroom or a private area. In addition to using a more sanitary option, you also avoid being rude to your hosts.
question_13: Are there alot of Chinese in Cuba?
answert_13: Chinese CubansSimplified Chineseu53e4u5df4u534eu4fa8showTranscriptions7 more rows
question_14: What percent of Cuba is Chinese?
answert_14: Asian. Cubans of East Asian origins made up 1.02% of the population in the 2002 Census of Cuba. They are mostly of Chinese (especially Cantonese), Japanese or Korean origins. The Chinese population in Cuba is descended mostly from indentured laborers who arrived in the 19th century to build railroads and work in mines.
question_15: How many Chinese live in Cuba?
answert_15: Although only about 150 native Chinese live in Cuba today, in the mid-1800s, there were more than 100,000, nearly all of them men. They were brought to Cuba as indentured laborers, enticed by worthless contracts that promised them freedom after eight years.
question_16: Is China an ally of Cuba?
answert_16: Cuba recognised the PRC in September 1960. The relations are based on trade, credits, and investments, which have increased significantly since the 1990s. China is Cuba's second-largest trading partner after Venezuela.
question_17: Are Cuban citizens allowed travel?
answert_17: Cuba's passport is ranked 79th globally in terms of freedom of movement. Cuban citizens enjoy visa-free travel, along with visa on arrival and eVisa options to more than 60 countries worldwide. But, Cuban passport holders must apply for a visa for the rest of the countries before entering.
question_18: Can Cuban citizens travel to the US?
answert_18: USA has major restrictions for travel. Most visitors from Cuba will not be allowed to travel to USA
question_19: How long can a Cuban American stay in Cuba?
answert_19: 30 days
question_20: Why US citizens Cannot go to Cuba?
answert_20: The primary travel to Cuba restriction for Americans is accessing money while traveling because of America's nearly 60-year-old US Cuba embargo, American debit cards and credit cards will not work on the island as they do for those traveling from any other country.
question_21: What countries are involved with North Korea?
answert_21: North Korea, officially the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), is a country in East Asia, constituting the northern part of the Korean Peninsula. It borders China and Russia to the north, at the Yalu (Amnok) and Tumen rivers, and South Korea to the south at the Korean Demilitarized Zone.
question_22: Does North Korea have an allies?
answert_22: They have a close special relationship and China is often considered to be North Korea's closest ally. China and North Korea have a mutual aid and co-operation treaty, which is currently the only defense treaty either country has with any nation.
question_23: Does North Korea trade with anyone?
answert_23: Largely cut off from the rest of the world, North Korea's trade with foreign territories has officially been severed as a result of global sanctions against the nation.

question_5: Do Koreans have the R sound?
answert_5: In Korean, the l and r sounds come from the same underlying consonant u3139. If the consonant u3139[rieul] is between two vowels, then it'll usually have the English r sound. However, if it's at the beginning or end of the word, or precedes a consonant, it'll have more of an English l sound.
question_6: Does Korean have f sound?
answert_6: Actually, there are no F or V sounds in Korean. In fact, there's no difference between P and F or B and V. Therefore, the P and F sounds are both pronounced as u314d[pieup] and B and V as u3142[bieup]. question_14: What is the W sound in Korean?
answert_14: Korean u110f is pretty much like English K if it's at the start of a word or between two vowels. English G is a voiced stop consonant and Korean only really has voiced stop consonants between two vowels.
question_15: Is there V sound in Korean?
answert_15: W sounds are formed by using u3157 and u315c as a base then attaching a second vowel to the right of the u3157 or u315c. As you've probably noticed, u315e, u3159, and u315a all make the same sound. Memorize these combinations with their sounds and you'll be one giant step closer to being able to read Korean.
question_16: Can Korean people pronounce r?
answert_16: R is a definitely hard pronunciation for Koreans. But, we have a similar sound u3139. Even though English language doesn't have the exact same pronunciation as u3139 I would say L corresponds to double u3139 in Korean.
question_17: Why can't Koreans say the letter R?
answert_17: A common struggle that Koreans have with pronunciation is with the L and R sounds. This is because they use u3139, which is somewhere between L and R. When writing down English words using Korean characters, this letter is used for both L and R, making Koreans accustomed to using this sound to replace both letters.
question_18: Why do Koreans switch R and L?
answert_18: The light tap is often perceived as an R by other speakers, and this is why it seems like the R's and L's are confused (even though it's not the English R). When Korean speakers hear the R in English, they often categorize it as L, which makes it really hard for them to distinguish between the two.
question_19: Why is there no F in Korean?
answert_19: There is no F sound in Korean because you don't really have to differentiate F and P when using the language. It's kinda like asking English users Why do you have no 'u3132'sound? Also, the G sound is similar to u3131 in Korean.
question_20: Why do Koreans say P instead of F?
answert_20: Because Korean doesn't have an /f/ sound, and so they substitute it with /p/ unless they learn to speak /f/ on their own. Japanese does have an /f/, which is in fact an allophone of /h/ and actually more similar to English /wh/ (for speakers that don't pronounce it the same as /w/).
question_21: How do you spell F in Korean?

question_8: Why is konnichiwa written with Ha?
answert_8: Using Ha and Wa in Hiragana In current Japanese dialogue, Konnichiwa or Konbanwa are fixed greetings. However, historically, they were used in sentences such as Konnichi wa (Today is) or Konban wa (Tonight is), and wa functioned as a particle. That's why it is still written in hiragana as ha.
question_9: How do you type Konbanwa?

question_10: What is Konbanwa in Japanese?
answert_10: 3. Konbanwa (u3053u3093u3070u3093u308f) After around 6pm or sunset, you can use konbanwa, which roughly translates to good evening, but literally means tonight. In contrast to konnichiwa, konbanwa sounds more formal, and most people don't use it with their close acquaintances.
question_11: What do you reply to Konbanwa?
answert_11: Fellow Japanese customers will reply with silence, but if this makes you feel awkward, a reply of ohayo gozaimasu (good morning) or konnichiwa (good day) or konbanwa (good evening).
question_12: Is Konbanwa formal?
answert_12: Good Evening in Japanese u3053u3093u3070u3093u306f (Konbanwa) It's a polite and formal way to say good evening. You can use this with most anyone, but it's definitely more common to greet friends and family with an informal greeting on this list instead.
question_13: Why is konnichiwa written with ha?

question_14: Why do Japanese use ha as wa?
answert_14: It's because the sound made by this character has shifted over time. The ancient Japanese people pronounced it as fa but, around the 9th century, it began to be said as wa. Even though the sound changed, people continued to use the character in the same way when writing.
question_15: Why is ha read as wa?

question_22: Do you write konnichiwa in kanji?
answert_22: Konnichiwa (u3053u3093u306bu3061u308f) is a Japanese greeting, typically a mid-day to early evening greeting (10:00 AM to 5:59 PM). It is also used as an informal greeting, hello. With kanji, Konnichiwa is written as u4ecau65e5u306f
question_23: Why is konnichiwa written as Konnichiha?
answert_23: It's because the modern u3053u3093u306bu3061u306f is a shortened version of the old greeting style. It helps to know that the kanji for konnichi-wa is u4ecau65e5u306f (today). A long time ago people used to greet each other by saying things like u4ecau65e5u306fu3044u3044u5929u6c17u3067u3059u306d (The weather is nice today), or u3053u3093u306bu3061u306fu6691u3044 (Today is hot).

answert_24: But unlike the Chinese language, Japanese cannot be written entirely in kanji. question_1: What is Kon ban wa?
answert_1: Japanese Greetings The way to say good evening in Japanese is Konbanwa.
question_2: Is Konbanwa formal?
answert_2: Good Evening in Japanese u3053u3093u3070u3093u306f (Konbanwa) It's a polite and formal way to say good evening. You can use this with most anyone, but it's definitely more common to greet friends and family with an informal greeting on this list instead.
question_3: What do you reply to Konbanwa?
answert_3: Fellow Japanese customers will reply with silence, but if this makes you feel awkward, a reply of ohayo gozaimasu (good morning) or konnichiwa (good day) or konbanwa (good evening).
question_4: Do you say Konbanwa Gozaimasu?
answert_4: You don't say 'Kon'nichiwa gozaimasu'or 'Konbanwa gozaimasu. 'It's because the phrases kon'nichiwa and Konbanwa have different origins from 'Ohayo (gozaimasu)'.
question_5: What time can you say Konbanwa?
answert_5: Fellow Japanese customers will reply with silence, but if this makes you feel awkward, a reply of ohayo gozaimasu (good morning) or konnichiwa (good day) or konbanwa (good evening).
question_6: What is the meaning of Ohayo gozaimasu?
answert_6: The ban in konbanwa means evening. The nichi in konnichiwa means day. We use ohayou gozaimasu before about 10:30 am, konnichiwa after about 10:30 am, and konbanwa in the evening.
question_7: Is Konbanwa a greeting or farewell?
answert_7: Good evening
question_8: Is konnichiwa formal or informal?

Today, it's a colloquial greeting used by anyone, but it can be part of the more formal greeting: Konnichi wa gokiken ikaga desu ka? (u4ecau65e5u306fu3054
question_9: Is Ohayou formal or informal?
answert_9: The shorter version, ohayou, is informal. Either can be used until about 11:00 in the morning, at which point konnichiwa is the appropriate greeting. Konnichiwa is spelled ko-n-ni-chi-HA in Hiragana. Konnichi means today based on its parts, but is never used as an independent word.
question_10: Can you say Konbanwa at night?
answert_10: The Japanese have no one word for hello, they instead have three major greetings based on morning, afternoon, and evening, and a form used when speaking on the telephone. Use Ohayou from waking to about 12:00, Konnichiwa until dusk, Konbanwa throughout the evening, and Oyasumi only before bed or sleeping.
question_11: Is Konbanwa good evening?
answert_11: The way to say good evening in Japanese is Konbanwa. Konbanwa shouldn't be confused with konnichi wa, which is a greeting often during daytime hours.
question_12: What does Konbanwa mean?
answert_12: good evening
question_13: Is Konbanwa a greeting or a farewell?

question_18: Is Konbanwa polite?

question_20: What time do you say konnichiwa?
answert_20: Good evening in Japanese Konbanwa (u3053u3093u3070u3093u306f) is how you should greet people in the late afternoon or evening hours. question_21: What is the meaning of Gozaimasu?
answert_21: The word 'gozaimasu'is a very polite expression and can roughly be translated as am, is, or are in English. The phrase ohayo comes from an adjective, hayai meaning early and it literally means it's early. So, ohayo can take the polite expression gozaimasu after that to say it politely.

question_14: What does inversion mean in language?

question_15: What is inverted word order German?
answert_15: Inverted Word Order in German In the simplest of terms, any time a sentence or clause begins with anything other than the subject, that first word is followed immediately by a verb. The subject follows the verb, then come objects and adverbial constructions. We drank some wine at the restaurant.
question_16: What is inversion and example?
answert_16: As a literary device, inversion refers to the reversal of the syntactically correct order of subjects, verbs, and objects in a sentence. For example, it's syntactically correct to say, Yesterday I saw a ship. An inversion of this sentence could be Yesterday saw I a ship, or Yesterday a ship I saw.
question_17: What is inversion clause?

question_22: How do you address a Japanese name?
answert_22: The most common honorific in Japanese is '-san', which can be used to address both females and males with either the given name or surname. For example, someone with the name Riku TANAKA may be addressed as Riku-san or TANAKA-san. The honorific '-sama'is a more polite and formal version of '-san'.
question_23: How do you call a Japanese name?
answert_23: In japan you usually call someone by his title or his lastname followed by an honorific suffix like san or sama or shi or the title like sensei (professor/master/sir). If you know the person better, depending on the circumstances, you can use chan or kun after the 1st name, or a san.
question_24: Do you use first or last name in Japan?
answert_24: In Japan, like in China and Korea, the first name follows the family name. A person with the first name Ichiro and the family name Suzuki is, therefore, called Suzuki Ichiro rather than Ichiro Suzuki.
question_25: Why do Japanese say Chan after a name?
answert_25: Chan (u3061u3083u3093) expresses that the speaker finds a person endearing. In general, -chan is used for young children, close friends, babies, grandparents and sometimes female adolescents. It may also be used towards cute animals, lovers, or a youthful woman.

question_1: Do Germans use Konjunktiv 1?
answert_1: If you want to talk about something another person said, you may use one of the two special moods in German - the Konjunktiv I (Subjunctive I). This is not a very common form, since it's primarily used for indirect speech. It's rarely used in spoken language, but you will find it in newspapers and articles.
question_2: What is Konjunktiv I in German?
answert_2: Konjunktiv I is used for the 2nd and 3rd person singular and 2nd person plural, the Konjunktiv II for the 1st person singular and the 1st and 3rd person plural to avoid confusion. We can also use the Konjunktiv II to express a wish or desire, to make conditional sentences or to make special, polite phrases.
question_3: How do you form the subjunctive 1 in German?
answert_3: Conjugating the Subjunctive I The Subjunctive I is almost always found in the third-person form: er habe (he has), sie sei (she is), er komme (he's coming), or sie wisse (she knows). This -e ending (except for to be) rather than the normal -t ending in the German third person is your clue to indirect quotation.
question_4: How do you form Konjunktiv 2 in German?
answert_4: Forming the Subjunctive II is much easier than you would think, and is done in two ways. One is the adaptation of the imperfect, and the other is with an auxiliary verb, werden (to become). The most commonly used verbs used without the auxiliary are haben, sein and the modal verbs.
question_5: How do you use the subjunctive 1 in German?
answert_5:
The subjunctiv I is used to express:
  • indirect speech (in colloquial speech the indicative is more common; see indirect speech) Example: Er sagt, er habe sich noch nie so jung gefxfchlt. He said he has never felt so young.
  • some idiomatic expressions. Example: Hoch lebe das Geburtstagskind! Long live the birthday boy!
question_6: Is Konjunktiv the same as subjunctive?
answert_6: In German, the subjunctive is called the Konjunktiv and there are two of them. Konjunktiv Iwhich is formed differently from its younger brother Konjunktiv IIis used chiefly for reporting indirect speech and old fashioned commands. Konjunktiv II is where the magic happens.
question_7: Does German have a subjunctive?
answert_7: German has two forms of the subjunctive mood, namely Konjunktiv I (KI) 'present subjunctive'and Konjunktiv II (KII) 'past subjunctive'. Despite their English names, both German subjunctives can be used for past and present time. The present subjunctive occurs in certain expressions, (e.g. Es lebe der Kxf6nig!
question_8: What is the difference between Prteritum and Konjunktiv 2?
answert_8: The Present Tense The present form of the Konjunktiv II will be the same as the simple past tense (Prxe4teritum) for regular verbs and is used mostly for auxiliary verbs and modal verbs.
question_9: What is Konjunktiv in English?
answert_9: The special subjunctive, also called subjunctive 1 or present subjunctive (Konjunktiv I), is primarily used in newspaper articles and reports when statements are repeated as indirect speech. The special subjunctive is also used in certain idiomatic expressions.
question_10: What is Konjunktiv II in German?
answert_10: Conjugating the Subjunctive I The Subjunctive I is almost always found in the third-person form: er habe (he has), sie sei (she is), er komme (he's coming), or sie wisse (she knows). This -e ending (except for to be) rather than the normal -t ending in the German third person is your clue to indirect quotation.

The subjunctiv I is used to express:
  • indirect speech (in colloquial speech the indicative is more common; see indirect speech) Example: Er sagt, er habe sich noch nie so jung gefxfchlt. He said he has never felt so young.
  • some idiomatic expressions. Example: Hoch lebe das Geburtstagskind! Long live the birthday boy!
question_12: How is Konjunktiv 1 formed?
answert_12: In German, whenever someone else's statements are reported or their feelings or opinions are expressed, the subjunctive I mood is used, and that mood is signaled by distinctive forms of the conjugated verbs.
question_13: How does Konjunktiv 1 work?
answert_13: The present tense Konjunktiv I has the same conjugation endings as the normal present tense (-e, -st, -t, -en, -t, -en) but with the difference of adding -e between the verb and the ending in the second and third person singular and first person plural.
question_14: How do you use Konjunktiv in German?
answert_14:
We use the Konjunktiv I primarily for indirect speech, for example:
  • Mein Bruder sagt, er komme spxe4ter. (My brother says that he is coming later.)
  • Er sagt, er habe Deutsch gelernt. Sie meint, er lxfcge. (He says that he learned German. She thinks that he is lying.)
question_15: What is subjunctive II?
answert_15: Subjunctive II is the form of subjunctive used in wishes and conditional sentences to signal whether a situation is hypothetical or not. For example, when the German words wenn (if) and so or dann (then) precede the clauses in the sentence, you can often expect the verbs to appear in their subjunctive II forms.
question_16: What is the difference between Konjunktiv 1 and 2?
answert_16: Konjunktiv I is used for the 2nd and 3rd person singular and 2nd person plural, the Konjunktiv II for the 1st person singular and the 1st and 3rd person plural to avoid confusion. We can also use the Konjunktiv II to express a wish or desire, to make conditional sentences or to make special, polite phrases.
question_17: What is Partizip II in German?
answert_17: The past participle, known as the Partizip II, is a special conjugation of a verb used in the Perfekt (present perfect tense), Passiv (passive voice) and as an adjective.  So as a general rule of thumb, wherever you'd use an -ed word in English, you'd use the Partizip II in German.

question_20: What is the Konjunktiv in German?
answert_20: We can use the subjunctive mood, Konjunktiv in German, to express unreal situations such as wishes, hypothetical situations and unreal conditional clauses, or to repeating what people say in indirect speech.

answert_22: The 4 subjunctive tenses that we will cover are the present subjunctive, the imperfect (past) subjunctive, the present perfect subjunctive, and the pluperfect subjunctive.

question_24: Does subjunctive exist in German?
answert_24: The German subjunctive mood (der Konjunktiv) comes in two varieties: (1) Subjunctive I (present subjunctive) and (2) Subjunctive II (past subjunctive). Despite their nicknames, it is important to understand that the subjunctive (in English or German) is a verb mood, not a verb tense.

question_3: What is konnichiwa Japanese?

question_4: Why is the Wa in konnichiwa spelled ha?

question_5: Why is konnichiwa written with Ha?
answert_5: Using Ha and Wa in Hiragana In current Japanese dialogue, Konnichiwa or Konbanwa are fixed greetings.
