question_1: What type of organic compounds are found in living organisms?
answert_1: Living things are made of just four classes of organic compounds: proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids.
question_2: What are the 4 major organic compounds in living things?
answert_2:
There are four major classes of biological macromolecules:
  • carbohydrates.
  • lipids.
  • proteins.
  • nucleic acids.
question_3: What function do organic compounds have in living organisms?
answert_3: Organisms use carbohydrates as energy sources, structural units, and for other purposes. Carbohydrates are the largest class of organic compounds found in organisms. Carbohydrates are classified according to how many subunits they contain.
question_4: What are the organic compounds found in a living cell?
answert_4: Most organic compounds making up our cells and body belong to one of four classes: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids.
question_5: Why are organic compounds found in living organisms?
answert_5: The chemical compounds of living things are known as organic compounds because of their association with organisms and because they are carbon-containing compounds. question_6: What organic compounds are found in the body?
answert_6: Organic compounds essential to human functioning include carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleotides. These compounds are said to be organic because they contain both carbon and hydrogen.

question_1: What is the central idea of Ordinary People?
answert_1: A principal theme of Ordinary People is grief over a loved one's death. As Beth, Cal, and Con struggle to cope with Buck's fatal accident, they turn inward, causing conflicts within the family.
question_2: What is wrong with Conrad in Ordinary People?
answert_2: Conrad Jarrett The son of Calvin and Beth, he is the novel's protagonist. About 18 months before the novel begins, he was involved in a boating accident with his brother, Buck, an accident which left Buck dead. A year later, Conrad tried to commit suicide but failed, forcing him to spend time in hospital.
question_3: Why is the book called Ordinary People?
answert_3: Conrad Jarrett The son of Calvin and Beth, he is the novel's protagonist. About 18 months before the novel begins, he was involved in a boating accident with his brother, Buck, an accident which left Buck dead. A year later, Conrad tried to commit suicide but failed, forcing him to spend time in hospital.
question_4: What mental illness does Conrad have?
answert_4: Table 1.StageTermIICharacteristics14 more rowsx26bull;Dec 4, 2009
question_5: Why was Conrad in a mental hospital?
answert_5: Conrad was hospitalized because he tried to kill himself. Poor guy is going to need more than ice cream. Conrad is seventeen going on eighteen, and his hospitalization has set him back a year in school.
question_6: What triggers Conrad's breakdown?
answert_6: In Berger's office, Conrad has a breakdown and admits that he blames himself for the death of Buck. Berger tells him to stop blaming himself and to stop trying to fill Buck's shoes; Conrad needs to allow himself to feel more even when he feels bad, and he needs to be himself for a change.
question_7: What does Dr Berger suggest Conrad's real problem is?
answert_7: We also see for the first time in the novel a complete picture of what Conrad's basic problem is: he blames himself ceaselessly for the death of Buck. He recalls vividly the night Buck drowned, and he cannot help but see the accident as any thing other than his own fault.
question_8: Is Ordinary People based off a book?
answert_8: Ordinary People is a 1980 American psychological drama film directed by Robert Redford (in his directorial debut) from a screenplay written by Alvin Sargent based on the 1976 novel of the same name by Judith Guest.
question_9: Why was Ordinary People book banned?
answert_9: LEAD: IN 1985 a group of parents in North Salem wanted to ban the book ''Ordinary People''from the local schools. The book by Judith Guest, later made into a movie, dealt with teen-age suicide, which had occurred in the town. In addition, the book contained sex scenes and profanity.
question_10: What disorder did Conrad have in Ordinary People?
answert_10: Berger learns that Conrad was involved in the sailing accident that took the life of Buck, whom everyone idolized. Conrad now deals with post-traumatic stress disorder and survivor's guilt. Conrad's father, Calvin, tries to connect with his surviving son and understand his wife.
question_11: Does Conrad have PTSD?

question_1: Is there an order of adjectives in French?
answert_1: Most French adjectives go after the noun they describe. Some very common adjectives usually come before the noun: bon/mauvais, court/long, grand/petit, jeune/nouveau/vieux, gros, haut, beau, joli, premier, meilleur.
question_2: What is the rule for adjectives in French?
answert_2: In French, adjectives must agree with their noun, which means that they have to show whether they are masculine or feminine and singular or plural to match the noun.

question_10: How do you do adjectives in French?
answert_10: To make an adjective agree with a feminine singular noun or pronoun, you usually add -e to the masculine singular. If the adjective already ends in an -e, no further -e is added. Several adjectives ending in a consonant double their consonant as well as adding -e in the feminine.

question_1: What is an example of indirect speech?
answert_1: Indirect speech is speech which tells you what someone said, but does not use the person's actual words: for example, 'They said you didn't like it', 'I asked her what her plans were', and 'Citizens complained about the smoke'.
question_2: What is the formula for indirect statement in Latin?
answert_2: RULE 1: Indirect Statement Accusative Subject + Infinitive Verb [There is no that in Latin!] Unlike with participles, Latin has a full set of infinitives, that is, all six which are possible, encompassing both voices (active/passive) and all three tenses (past/present/future).
question_3: How do you say indirect speech in Latin?
answert_3: Indirect statements in classical Latin usually use the accusative and infinitive construction. In this the main verb of the quoted sentence is changed to an infinitive, and its subject to the accusative case; this construction is also sometimes used for commands and rhetorical questions.
question_4: What begins an indirect statement?
answert_4: Formation: In English indirect statements are introduced by a subordinating conjunction that, which has no equivalent in classical Latin. Instead, a subject accusative + infinitive is used. When dealing with indirect speech, only the subject and the verb are changed - the rest of the sentence remains unchanged.

question_6: What is direct and indirect speech examples?

question_7: How do you write an indirect speech?
answert_7: Usually indirect speech is introduced by the verb said, as in I said, Bill said, or they said. Using the verb say in this tense, indicates that something was said in the past. In these cases, the main verb in the reported sentence is put in the past.

question_25: How do you convert direct speech to indirect speech?
answert_25:
Rules for conversion of Indirect Speech to Direct Speech
  • Use the reporting verb, say or said to in its correct tense.

  • Put a comma before the statement.

question_1: What is the symbol of the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_1: Phoenixes are magical birds that age, die, and are reborn from their own ashes. They symbolize endurance and new beginnings. Professor Dumbledore has an actual phoenix, Fawkes, who swallows an Avada Kedavra meant for Harry, dies, and returns as a tiny, ugly, featherless (37.20) chick at the end of Book 5.
question_2: Why is the Order of the Phoenix called that?
answert_2: 1 The origin of the Order's name We know how Dumbledore's Army came about, with Harry wanting to name it after the Ministry's worst fear. But Dumbledore named the Order of the Phoenix as such due to his relationship with his loyal pet Fawkes the Phoenix
question_3: What is the Harry Potter symbol?
answert_3: The Deathly Hallows symbol a vertical line and circle enclosed by a triangle represents three legendary Harry Potter artifacts: the Elder Wand, the Resurrection Stone and the Cloak of Invisibility.
question_4: What is the Harry Potter triangle symbol called?
answert_4: Deathly Hallows symbol
question_5: What does the Deathly Hallows symbol mean in real life?
answert_5: The Deathly Hallows symbol a vertical line and circle enclosed by a triangle represents three legendary Harry Potter artifacts: the Elder Wand, the Resurrection Stone and the Cloak of Invisibility. The Masonic Square and Compasses symbol forms a similar triangular shape.
question_6: What does Fawkes represent in Harry Potter?
answert_6: Fawkes, Dumbledore's phoenix, becomes a symbol of Harry and Dumbledore's shared loyalty, and of how Dumbledore's support of Harry inspires Harry's bravery. After several mysterious attacks on students, Dumbledore is forced to leave his post by the school governors.
question_7: What is the message in Order of the Phoenix?
answert_7: Unity in the Face of Evil Another leading theme in Order of the Phoenix is the importance of uniting in the face of threat. The Sorting Hat stresses this in the beginning of the book: Our Hogwarts is in danger from external deadly foes.
question_8: What does Order mean in Order of the Phoenix?
answert_8: The Order of the Phoenix was a secret society founded by Albus Dumbledore to oppose Lord Voldemort and his Death Eaters. The original Order was created in the 1970s. It was constructed after Voldemort returned to England from abroad and started his campaign to take over the Ministry of Magic and persecute Muggle-borns.
question_9: Who was the traitor in The Order of the Phoenix?
answert_9: It is revealed that The Order of the Phoenix was betrayed by Kreacher, Sirius Black's house elf, when Sirius, in a fit of anger, gave Kreacher an order that permitted him to speak to Sirius'cousin, Narcissa Malfoy.
question_10: What is the Harry Potter symbol called?
answert_10: Deathly Hallows symbol
question_11: What items represent Harry Potter?
answert_11: The sign of the Deathly Hallows represents all three objects symbolically: the Wand, the Stone, and the Cloak.
question_12: What does the triangle sign in Harry Potter mean?
answert_12: The Deathly Hallows symbol a vertical line and circle enclosed by a triangle represents three legendary Harry Potter artifacts: the Elder Wand, the Resurrection Stone and the Cloak of Invisibility. The Masonic Square and Compasses symbol forms a similar triangular shape.
question_13: What are the symbols of Harry Potter?
answert_13:
Harry Potter Symbols: Deathly Hallows
  • Deathly Hallows. The Deathly Hallows symbol is based on the magical items each of the three brothers used to escape death: the invisibility cloak, the Elder Wand, and the Philosopher's Stone.
  • The Philosopher's Stone.
  • Invisibility Cloak.
  • Elder Wand.
Jan 11, 2021
question_14: Is the Deathly Hallows symbol bad?
answert_14: As a symbol, the Deathly Hallows resemble the swastika. Both were originally positive symbols from a spiritual/mythological background that acquired extremely negative connotations after being adopted by evil political movements (Grindelwald's forces and the Nazi Party, respectively).
question_15: What is the meaning behind the Deathly Hallows symbol?
answert_15: The Deathly Hallows symbol represents magical artifacts described in The Tale of the Three Brothers. The Elder Wand, The Resurrection Stone, and The Cloak of Invisibility are the gifts given to the brothers by Death, represented in the sign by a triangle, circle, and a line respectively.
question_16: Is the Deathly Hallows a real symbol?
answert_16: JK Rowling has revealed the inspiration behind the symbol for the Deathly Hallows. Speaking in a new BBC documentary, the author says it's connected to a film that came out more than 40 years ago. The film features a Masonic symbol - and is similar to the one that appears in Harry Potter.
question_17: Is the Deathly Hallows symbol evil?
answert_17: The Deathly Hallows symbol represents magical artifacts described in The Tale of the Three Brothers. The Elder Wand, The Resurrection Stone, and The Cloak of Invisibility are the gifts given to the brothers by Death, represented in the sign by a triangle, circle, and a line respectively.
question_18: Why is Fawkes important in Harry Potter?
answert_18: Fawkes was a highly intelligent phoenix and Albus Dumbledore's animal companion and defender. Fawkes was instrumental in helping Harry Potter defeat Salazar Slytherin's basilisk in 1993, and he came to Dumbledore's aid in fighting Lord Voldemort during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries.
question_19: What does Fawkes mean Harry Potter?
answert_19: Fawkes was a highly intelligent male phoenix and Albus Dumbledore's animal companion and defender. He had been loyal to Dumbledore for many years prior to the Headmaster's death in 1997. Fawkes was instrumental in helping Harry Potter defeat Salazar Slytherin's basilisk in 1993.
question_20: What do phoenixes represent in Harry Potter?
answert_20: Phoenixes are magical birds that age, die, and are reborn from their own ashes. They symbolize endurance and new beginnings. Professor Dumbledore has an actual phoenix, Fawkes, who swallows an Avada Kedavra meant for Harry, dies, and returns as a tiny, ugly, featherless (37.20) chick at the end of Book 5.
question_21: What bird is Fawkes in Harry Potter?
answert_21: phoenix
question_22: What was the point of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_22: The Order of the Phoenix was a secret society founded by Albus Dumbledore to oppose Lord Voldemort and his Death Eaters. The original Order was created in the 1970s. It was constructed after Voldemort returned to England from abroad and started his campaign to take over the Ministry of Magic and persecute Muggle-borns.
question_23: What does the phoenix in Harry Potter represent?
answert_23: Phoenixes are magical birds that age, die, and are reborn from their own ashes. They symbolize endurance and new beginnings. question_24: What is the symbol for the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_24: Fawkes the Phoenix Fawkes represents endurance and new beginnings in the book. Phoenixes age, die, and are reborn again from their ashes. In the book, Fawkes has repeatedly saved Harry's life, sacrificing its own life.
question_25: What order is Order of the Phoenix?
answert_25: 1 The origin of the Order's name We know how Dumbledore's Army came about, with Harry wanting to name it after the Ministry's worst fear. But Dumbledore named the Order of the Phoenix as such due to his relationship with his loyal pet Fawkes the Phoenix

answert_2: Orchestras play a wide range of repertoire, including symphonies, opera and ballet overtures, concertos for solo instruments, and as pit ensembles for operas, ballets, and some types of musical theatre (e.g., Gilbert and Sullivan operettas).

question_9: What are pieces in a symphony?
answert_9: A symphony is a piece of music written for an orchestra to play. It may be quite a long piece. Usually it is divided into parts, usually 3 or 4 parts, which are called movements. The first movement of a symphony can be a fast movement, often in sonata form.

question_13: What's the difference between an orchestra and a symphony?
answert_13: A symphony is a large-scale musical composition, usually with three or four movements. An orchestra is a group of musicians with a variety of instruments, which usually includes the violin family.

question_15: What is an orchestra concert?
answert_15: The Concert orchestra is a preparatory group that works on building a musical foundation through classical pieces that are arranged for younger musicians. The Symphony Orchestra is a more advanced group that focuses on performing original classical repertoire at a professional level.

question_23: What is music in few words?
answert_23: Music is a form of art that uses sound organised in time.  Most music includes people singing with their voices or playing musical instruments, such as the piano, guitar, drums or violin. The word music comes from the Greek word (mousike), which means (art) of the Muses.
question_24: What are the 4 types of vocabulary?
answert_24: Vocabulary refers to the words we must understand to communicate effectively. Educators often consider four types of vocabulary: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Listening vocabulary refers to the words we need to know to understand what we hear.
question_25: What are vocabulary words?
answert_25: Vocabulary is all about words the words in a language or a special set of words you are trying to learn. First used in the 1500s to mean a list of words with explanations, the noun vocabulary came to refer to the range of language of a person or group about two hundred years later.

question_1: Who are members of the Order of the Phoenix?

  • Aberforth Dumbledore.
  • Arabella Figg.
  • Mundungus Fletcher.

question_2: Who was the traitor in the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_2: It is revealed that The Order of the Phoenix was betrayed by Kreacher, Sirius Black's house elf, when Sirius, in a fit of anger, gave Kreacher an order that permitted him to speak to Sirius'cousin, Narcissa Malfoy.
question_3: Which members of the Order of the Phoenix died?
answert_3: The battle was fought through the castle and the grounds. It resulted in many casualties, the fifty fallen. Of those fallen fifty, Order members Remus Lupin and Nymphadora Tonks were murdered. Remus was murdered by Antonin Dolohov and Tonks by Bellatrix Lestrange.
question_4: Is Dolores Umbridge a Death Eater?
answert_4: Despite her wickedness and pure-blood supremacist attitude, Umbridge was repeatedly stated to be no Death Eater, as she never showed support for them until they took over the Ministry in 1997.
question_5: Is Snape a member of the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_5: Shortly before Lily Evans was murdered by Lord Voldemort, Snape changed sides and became a member of the Order of the Phoenix as well as a double agent during the Second Wizarding War.
question_6: How many Phoenix are there in Harry Potter?
answert_6: two
question_7: Who was the strongest member of the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_7: 1 Albus Dumbledore Albus Dumbledore is by far the most powerful magic-user known in the Harry Potter universe, which automatically makes him the strongest among the Order as well.
question_8: Who is part of the Order in Harry Potter?

question_11: Was mundungus a traitor?
answert_11: It was also mentioned that Mundungus was loyal to Albus Dumbledore, who had helped him at some point in the past. Albus scared Mundungus a bit but nevertheless, Mundungus never betrayed him.
question_12: Who betrayed Mad Eye Moody?
answert_12: 10 BARTY CROUCH JUNIOR - BETRAYED HARRY Mad-Eye Moody had earned the trust and respect from the likes of Albus Dumbledore, so no one would have ever suspected it was all one big ruse to lead Harry into the hands of Lord Voldemort.
question_13: Did Fawkes the Phoenix die?
answert_13: He periodically died by bursting into flames (an event called a Burning Day), and was then reborn from the ashes. He was also immune to the gaze of a basilisk, making phoenixes the only known creatures to be unaffected by the deadly serpent's gaze.
question_14: Did Kingsley Shacklebolt die in the battle of Hogwarts?
answert_14: It is revealed that The Order of the Phoenix was betrayed by Kreacher, Sirius Black's house elf, when Sirius, in a fit of anger, gave Kreacher an order that permitted him to speak to Sirius'cousin, Narcissa Malfoy.
question_15: Was Dolores Umbridge a Death Eater?
answert_15: While Kingsley was unable to defeat Bellatrix Lestrange during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries, he did hold his ground for a time and survived, albeit injured.
question_16: How is umbridge connected to Voldemort?
answert_16: With the fall of Lord Voldemort, Dolores Umbridge was put on trial for her enthusiastic co-operation with his regime, and convicted of the torture, imprisonment and deaths of several people (some of the innocent Muggle-borns she sentenced to Azkaban did not survive their ordeal).
question_17: Is Dolores Umbridge a squib?
answert_17: Dolores Jane Umbridge was born to a Wizard father and a Muggle mother, and eventually had a younger brother who was a Squib. Under the influence of her father, Dolores grew up despising her mother and brother for their lack of magical abilities.
question_18: Why was Dolores a Death Eater?
answert_18: By the time Dolores was fifteen, Orford and Ellen divorced from one another, and Ellen and her squib son were never seen by the magical part of the family again. Henceforth, she pretended in front of everyone that she met and knew that she was pure-blood. She became sadistic, and took pleasure in the pain of others.
question_19: Did the Order of the Phoenix know Snape was innocent?
answert_19: The Order of the Phoenix knew Snape was a double agent, but no one knew he was a triple agent. After Dumbledore's death, the entire Order of the Phoenix believed Snape had betrayed Dumbledore and them.
question_20: Did Snape help Harry in the Order of the Phoenix?
answert_20: Yes. Snape had figured out what harry was trying to communicate to him (while at umbridge's office). He then contacted the Order's Headquarters,12 Grimmauld Place (Probably with their patronus method of communication) to check if anything was wrong, he discovered that sirius was present there and everything was fine.

question_2: How do you use ordenar?
answert_2: Although, in this case, ordenar is used in the sense of to order, you can see that in its origins ordenar could be understood as giving a command to your waiter. As in: Te ordeno que me traigas mi cena. I order you to bring me my dinner.
question_3: What tense is Ordenamos?
answert_3: Past Participleorganizadoarranged
question_4: Is Ordenar imperfect or preterite?
answert_4: In Spanish, you conjugate verbs by changing the ending. If the subject is I (yo), conjugate by dropping the ending and add -o. If the subject is you informal (txfa), conjugate by dropping the ending and add -as (for -ar verbs) or -es (for -er and -ir verbs).

question_1: What is the meaning of Killers of the Flower Moon?
answert_1: Killers of the Flower Moon delves into a string of mostly unsolved murders involving the Osage Indian Nation of Oklahoma in the 1920s. The title comes from an Osage saying that describes the death of blooming April flowers in May, when taller plants crowd them out.

question_1: What is the meaning of Killers of the Flower Moon?

question_1: Can you pass waste products through the ureters to the?
answert_1: Kidneys pass waste products through the ureters to the bladder. The bladder is the storage structure for urine.
question_2: Is waste transported from the kidneys in the form of urine?
answert_2: Urea is carried in the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is removed along with water and other wastes in the form of urine. Other important functions of the kidneys include blood pressure regulation and the production of erythropoietin, which controls red blood cell production in the bone marrow.
question_3: How does urine flow through the kidney?
answert_3: Urine flows through a renal pyramid and exits at the renal papilla, the tip. The renal papilla has collecting ducts, small openings that allow urine to pass through. From the collecting ducts, the urine progresses to the renal pelvis, a widened area of the kidney, and exits through the ureter.
question_4: What delivers urine to the bladder?
answert_4: The ureters are tubes made of smooth muscle fibers that propel urine from the kidneys to the urinary bladder. In the adult, the ureters are usually 2530 cm (1012 in) long and 34 mm in diameter. The ureter is one of the essential organs of urinary tract that controls urine transport.
question_5: What is the pathway of urine?
answert_5: From the collecting ducts, the urine progresses to the renal pelvis, a widened area of the kidney, and exits through the ureter. The urine passes through the ureters to the urinary bladder. When the urinary bladder is full, the body releases urine through the urethra during urination, or micturition.
question_6: Which waste material are not removed from human body through urinary system?
answert_6: It eliminates extra water and salt, toxins, and other waste products. Different parts of the urinary system perform tasks including: Filtering blood.
question_7: Do you elimination of waste is the primary function of the?
answert_7: Kidneys. The paired kidneys are often considered the main organs of excretion. The primary function of the kidneys is the elimination of excess water and wastes from the bloodstream by the production of the liquid waste known as urine.
question_8: Is it true without a gallbladder a person would be unable to produce bile?
answert_8: Without a gallbladder, there's no place for bile to collect. Instead, your liver releases bile straight into the small intestine. This allows you to still digest most foods.
question_9: How is waste carried from the kidneys?
answert_9: The kidneys filter out the waste products and excess fluids from the body and dispose of them in the form of urine, via the bladder. The clean blood flows back to the other parts of the body. If your kidneys did not remove this waste, it would build up in the blood and cause damage to your body.
question_10: In which form is waste removed by the kidneys?
answert_10: The kidneys remove waste products called urea from the blood through tiny filtering units called nephrons. There are about one million nephrons in each kidney.
question_11: How does the kidney form urine?
answert_11: The nephrons of the kidneys process blood and create urine through a process of filtration, reabsorption, and secretion. Urine is about 95% water and 5% waste products. Nitrogenous wastes excreted in urine include urea, creatinine, ammonia, and uric acid.
question_12: What is the pathway of urine through the kidney?
answert_12: From the calyxes, pee travels out of the kidneys through the ureters (pronounced: YUR-uh-ters) to be stored in the bladder (a muscular sac in the lower belly). When a person urinates, the pee exits the bladder and goes out of the body through the urethra (pronounced: yoo-REE-thruh), another tube-like structure.
question_13: Which is the correct pathway for passage of urine in humans?
answert_13: Collecting tubule Ureter Bladder Urethra.

question_6: Why would someone use the Kik app?

question_7: Why you should not use Kik?

question_24: Is Kik really safe?

question_25: Can you be tracked on Kik?
answert_25: Kik and similar applications like Whatsapp allow users to send secure messages over the internet. Kik does not track the content of messages or the phone numbers of users, making it difficult for police to find identifying information in child pornography cases.

question_1: What does Kierkegaard say in Fear and Trembling?
answert_1: Kierkegaard introduces the idea of the paradox and the leap in Fear and Trembling. He says, The act of resignation does not require faith, for what I gain is my eternal consciousness.
question_2: What is the absolute in Fear and Trembling?
answert_2: Though not invalidated, the ethical becomes relative, and the single individual's absolute duty is to God. This duty to God, as absolute, cannot be mediated and thus cannot be expressed in the universal: if it were expressible, it would not be faith but spiritual trial.
question_3: Why did Kierkegaard write Fear and Trembling?
answert_3: Kierkegaard published Fear and Trembling in 1843. He hoped to problematize what he felt were overly simplistic and uncritical interpretations of Christianity
question_4: What is the theme of Fear and Trembling?
answert_4: Belief vs. Doubt. Sxf8ren Kierkegaard's Fear and Trembling is a philosophical treatise on the nature of faith and what it means to truly have it. Kierkegaard feared that his world of mid-19th century Europe was becoming too eager to find something beyond faith and simple belief in God in the name of intellectualism.
question_5: What did Kierkegaard mean by Fear and Trembling?
answert_5: He is regarded as a leading pioneer of existentialism and one of the greatest philosophers of the 19th Century. In Fear and Trembling, Kierkegaard wanted to understand the anxiety that must have been present in Abraham when God commanded him to offer his son as a hum
question_6: How does Kierkegaard describe anxiety?
answert_6: Belief vs. Doubt. Sxf8ren Kierkegaard's Fear and Trembling is a philosophical treatise on the nature of faith and what it means to truly have it. Kierkegaard feared that his world of mid-19th century Europe was becoming too eager to find something beyond faith and simple belief in God in the name of intellectualism.
question_7: What does Kierkegaard mean by the absolute?
answert_7: Yes the absolute, in kierkegaard's work is god. So, the absolute relation to the absolute means that: your subjective relation is totally dominated by the absolute god, jeopardizing the universal (or social conventions/constructs).
question_8: What is the absurd in Fear and Trembling?
answert_8: He is regarded as a leading pioneer of existentialism and one of the greatest philosophers of the 19th Century. In Fear and Trembling, Kierkegaard wanted to understand the anxiety that must have been present in Abraham when God commanded him to offer his son as a hum
question_9: What is the purpose of Fear and Trembling?
answert_9: Fear and Trembling details the relationship between the ethical and the religious in much the same way that Either/Or details the relationship between the aesthetic and ethical. In Either/Or, the aesthetic and the ethical are not entirely opposed.
question_10: What did Kierkegaard based his philosophy on?
answert_10: He is regarded as a leading pioneer of existentialism and one of the greatest philosophers of the 19th Century. In Fear and Trembling, Kierkegaard wanted to understand the anxiety that must have been present in Abraham when God commanded him to offer his son as a hum
question_11: What is the main idea of Fear and Trembling?
answert_11: The main subject of Fear and Trembling is the figure of Abraham and especially the story of the binding of Isaac. Through Abraham's story Kierkegaard tries to relate his notions about Faith, the leap of faith, paradox, absurd, the three spheres of existence and more.
question_12: Why is it called Fear and Trembling?
answert_12: He is regarded as a leading pioneer of existentialism and one of the greatest philosophers of the 19th Century. In Fear and Trembling, Kierkegaard wanted to understand the anxiety that must have been present in Abraham when God commanded him to offer his son as a hum
question_13: What is Kierkegaard anxiety?
answert_13: In his 1844 treatise The Concept of Anxiety (public library), Danish philosopher Sxf8ren Kierkegaard (May 5, 1813November 11, 1855) explains anxiety as the dizzying effect of freedom, of paralyzing possibility, of the boundlessness of one's own existence a kind of existential paradox of choice.
question_14: How does Sartre define anxiety?
answert_14: (Jean-Paul Sartre calls these terms pre-reflective consciousness and reflective consciousness.) An individual becomes truly aware of their potential through the experience of anxiety. So, anxiety may be a possibility for sin, but anxiety can also be a recognition or realization of one's true identity and freedom.
question_15: What does philosophy say about anxiety?
answert_15: The 17th-century English philosopher Thomas Hobbes wrote, Anxiety for the future time, disposeth men to enquire into the causes of things. In other words: You're anxious, so you look for answers, for ways to remove your ignorance.
question_16: What role does anxiety play in existentialist ethics?
answert_16: Existentialist philosophers often stress the importance of angst as signifying the absolute lack of any objective ground for action, a move that is often reduced to moral or existential nihilism.
question_17: What is the absolute in fear and trembling?
answert_17: Though not invalidated, the ethical becomes relative, and the single individual's absolute duty is to God. This duty to God, as absolute, cannot be mediated and thus cannot be expressed in the universal: if it were expressible, it would not be faith but spiritual trial.
question_18: What is Kierkegaard's absolute paradox?
answert_18: Our selection is from Chapter 3 of Philosophical Fragments, The Absolute Paradox. Kierkegaard holds that paradox is the passion of thought. We want to discover something we cannot think, even though this will be the downfall of thinking. That which we cannot think is the unknown, and the unknown is God (the god).
question_19: What does absolute mind mean?
answert_19: Absolute MindIn Hegelian philosophy, an undistorted, rational view of the truth. Philosophy is the ultimate expression of the Absolute Mind, and so is superior both to art (the aesthetic) and to faith (the religious).
question_20: What does Kierkegaard mean by the universal?
answert_20: the universality of the ethical
question_21: What is the absurd according to Kierkegaard?

question_22: What is the point of Fear and Trembling?
answert_22: The main subject of Fear and Trembling is the figure of Abraham and especially the story of the binding of Isaac. Through Abraham's story Kierkegaard tries to relate his notions about Faith, the leap of faith, paradox, absurd, the three spheres of existence and more.
question_23: Is Fear and Trembling a good read?
answert_23: FEAR AND TREMBLING stands as one of Soren Kierkegaard's most widely read works. It's brevity is appealing to those with only a marginal interest in philosophy and theology. It's subject matter is what attracts those persons who want to find a nexus between ethics and theology.
question_24: What is Kierkegaard's existentialism philosophy?
answert_24: Sxf8ren Kierkegaard is generally considered to have been the first existentialist philosopher. He proposed that each individualnot society or religionis solely responsible for giving meaning to life and living it passionately and sincerely, or authentically.
question_25: Who was inspired by the work of Kierkegaard?
answert_25: Kierkegaard influenced 19th-century literature writers as well as 20th-century literature. August Strindberg (1843-1912) found inspiration in Kierkegaard and the famous Norwegian dramatist and poet Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906) clearly seems to have been inspired by the Dane in famous works such as Brand.

question_1: Is Thomas in The Kill Order book?
answert_1: Thomas: A 5-year-old boy immune to the Flare virus who is taken by WICKED from his willing mother in the epilogue of the novel.
question_2: What happens in the end of The Kill Order?
answert_2: But for Mark, Trina, and Alec, the end of the book is the end of their lives. Though we don't see them die, Alec is split-seconds away from crashing the Berg into the building by the time the last page ends. By crashing the Berg into the building, Alec is saving them all from going crazy and suffering.
question_3: What happens in the beginning of The Kill Order?

It's super-rare for a Berg to show up, and the people who come out of the Berg shoot up the village with darts.
question_4: Is Teresa a Deedee?

question_5: Is Thomas in the fever code?

question_6: Is Thomas in the 4th maze runner book?

question_10: What happens in the book kill order?
answert_10: The Kill Order is a young adult novel by James Dashner, which focuses around a group of individuals struggling to survive in the year after the Earth is ravaged by sun flares, all the while attempting to avert becoming victims of a deadly virus that is ravaging the eastern United States.
question_11: What is the climax of The Kill Order?
answert_11: Climax. Of course they struggled to break free of the insane people's restraints,but they were punched the men carrying them. They set the two down in front of the fire and Alec tries to fight back, and is proceeded to be beaten up by the men, and Mark is punished too.
question_12: What happens to mark in kill order?
answert_12: Mark is not immune to the Flare, and eventually falls victim to the deadly virus. Mark eventually sacrifices himself along with Trina and Alec, to help save Deedee. Mark and Trina hug as they die, leaving the world together as Alec crashed the Berg into the building.
question_13: What happens in The Kill Order?
answert_13: After a Berg releases the Flare virus that kills everyone but the four, Mark embarks on a journey to take revenge against those who ordered the execution. question_15: What is the message of The Kill Order?

question_16: How do we know Deedee is Teresa?

question_17: Is Teresa good or bad maze runner?
answert_17: She was obsessed with the prospect of helping and healing and finding a Cure. That is not bad. She only failed to see that WICKED is wicked, and that torturing people is the wrong way.
question_18: Does Teresa have her memories in the maze?
answert_18: She had her memories when she first came out of the Box, but about a day after her arrival, memories started to fade, so the memories were taken, yes, but not the same way as the memories of the other Gladers, and yes, she received the memories back later.
question_19: Does Teresa betray Thomas in the movie?

question_1: What does Kierkegaard say in Fear and Trembling?
answert_1: Kierkegaard introduces the idea of the paradox and the leap in Fear and Trembling. He says, The act of resignation does not require faith, for what I gain is my eternal consciousness.
question_2: What is the theme of Fear and Trembling?
answert_2: Belief vs. Doubt. Sxf8ren Kierkegaard's Fear and Trembling is a philosophical treatise on the nature of faith and what it means to truly have it. Kierkegaard feared that his world of mid-19th century Europe was becoming too eager to find something beyond faith and simple belief in God in the name of intellectualism.
question_3: Why did Kierkegaard write Fear and Trembling?
answert_3: Kierkegaard published Fear and Trembling in 1843. He hoped to problematize what he felt were overly simplistic and uncritical interpretations of Christianity
question_4: What is the absolute in Fear and Trembling?
answert_4: Though not invalidated, the ethical becomes relative, and the single individual's absolute duty is to God. This duty to God, as absolute, cannot be mediated and thus cannot be expressed in the universal: if it were expressible, it would not be faith but spiritual trial.
question_5: What did Kierkegaard mean by Fear and Trembling?
answert_5: He is regarded as a leading pioneer of existentialism and one of the greatest philosophers of the 19th Century. In Fear and Trembling, Kierkegaard wanted to understand the anxiety that must have been present in Abraham when God commanded him to offer his son as a hum
question_6: How does Kierkegaard describe anxiety?
answert_6: Belief vs. Doubt. Sxf8ren Kierkegaard's Fear and Trembling is a philosophical treatise on the nature of faith and what it means to truly have it. Kierkegaard feared that his world of mid-19th century Europe was becoming too eager to find something beyond faith and simple belief in God in the name of intellectualism.
question_7: What is the main idea of Fear and Trembling?
answert_7: The main subject of Fear and Trembling is the figure of Abraham and especially the story of the binding of Isaac. Through Abraham's story Kierkegaard tries to relate his notions about Faith, the leap of faith, paradox, absurd, the three spheres of existence and more.
question_8: Why is it called Fear and Trembling?

question_9: What is the absurd in Fear and Trembling?
answert_9: The title is a reference to a line from Philippians 2:12, continue to work out your salvation with fear and trembling. itself a probable reference to Psalms 55:5, Fear and trembling came upon me
question_10: What is the purpose of Fear and Trembling?
answert_10: Fear and Trembling details the relationship between the ethical and the religious in much the same way that Either/Or details the relationship between the aesthetic and ethical. In Either/Or, the aesthetic and the ethical are not entirely opposed.
question_11: What did Kierkegaard based his philosophy on?

question_12: What does Kierkegaard mean by the absolute?
answert_12: Yes the absolute, in kierkegaard's work is god. So, the absolute relation to the absolute means that: your subjective relation is totally dominated by the absolute god, jeopardizing the universal (or social conventions/constructs).
question_13: What is Kierkegaard anxiety?
answert_13: In his 1844 treatise The Concept of Anxiety (public library), Danish philosopher Sxf8ren Kierkegaard (May 5, 1813November 11, 1855) explains anxiety as the dizzying effect of freedom, of paralyzing possibility, of the boundlessness of one's own existence a kind of existential paradox of choice.
question_14: How does Sartre define anxiety?
answert_14: (Jean-Paul Sartre calls these terms pre-reflective consciousness and reflective consciousness.) An individual becomes truly aware of their potential through the experience of anxiety. So, anxiety may be a possibility for sin, but anxiety can also be a recognition or realization of one's true identity and freedom.
question_15: What does philosophy say about anxiety?
answert_15: The 17th-century English philosopher Thomas Hobbes wrote, Anxiety for the future time, disposeth men to enquire into the causes of things. In other words: You're anxious, so you look for answers, for ways to remove your ignorance.
question_16: What role does anxiety play in existentialist ethics?
answert_16: Existentialist philosophers often stress the importance of angst as signifying the absolute lack of any objective ground for action, a move that is often reduced to moral or existential nihilism.

question_20: Is Fear and Trembling a good read?
answert_20: FEAR AND TREMBLING stands as one of Soren Kierkegaard's most widely read works. It's brevity is appealing to those with only a marginal interest in philosophy and theology. It's subject matter is what attracts those persons who want to find a nexus between ethics and theology.
question_21: What is Kierkegaard's existentialism philosophy?
answert_21: Sxf8ren Kierkegaard is generally considered to have been the first existentialist philosopher. He proposed that each individualnot society or religionis solely responsible for giving meaning to life and living it passionately and sincerely, or authentically.
question_22: Who was inspired by the work of Kierkegaard?
answert_22: Kierkegaard influenced 19th-century literature writers as well as 20th-century literature. August Strindberg (1843-1912) found inspiration in Kierkegaard and the famous Norwegian dramatist and poet Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906) clearly seems to have been inspired by the Dane in famous works such as Brand.
question_23: What was Kierkegaard known for?
answert_23: In addition to being dubbed the father of existentialism, Kierkegaard is best known as a trenchant critic of Hegel and Hegelianism and for his invention or elaboration of a host of philosophical, psychological, literary and theological categories, including: anxiety, despair, melancholy, repetition, inwardness, irony
question_24: What is the absolute in fear and trembling?
answert_24: Though not invalidated, the ethical becomes relative, and the single individual's absolute duty is to God. This duty to God, as absolute, cannot be mediated and thus cannot be expressed in the universal: if it were expressible, it would not be faith but spiritual trial.
question_25: What is Kierkegaard's absolute paradox?
answert_25: Our selection is from Chapter 3 of Philosophical Fragments, The Absolute Paradox. Kierkegaard holds that paradox is the passion of thought. We want to discover something we cannot think, even though this will be the downfall of thinking. That which we cannot think is the unknown, and the unknown is God (the god).

question_1: Who is KF in psychology?
answert_1: KF suffered brain damage from a motorcycle accident that damaged his short-term memory. KF's impairment was mainly for verbal information - his memory for visual information was largely unaffected. This shows that there are separate STM components for visual information (VSS) and verbal information (phonological loop).
question_2: What are the 3 components of working memory?
answert_2: Like attention and executive functions, working memory has a significant influence in cognitive efficiency, learning, and academic performance. In Baddeley's model (2009, 2012) of working memory, there are three main functional components: the phonological loop, visual sketchpad, and the central executive
question_3: What is the Atkinson shiffrin theory of memory?
answert_3: The multi-store model of memory (also known as the modal model) was proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin (1968) and is a structural model. They proposed that memory consisted of three stores: a sensory register, short-term memory (STM) and long-term memory (LTM)
question_4: What is the dual task technique?
answert_4: A dual-task paradigm is a procedure in experimental neuropsychology that requires an individual to perform two tasks simultaneously, in order to compare performance with single-task conditions.
question_5: What is KF real name?

question_6: Is patient KF still alive?
answert_6: Deceased (19512014)
question_7: Who proposed the working memory model?
answert_7: Alan Baddeley
question_8: Who created the multi store model of memory?
answert_8: Richard Shiffrin
question_9: What are the three components of Alan Baddeley's model of working memory?
answert_9: The three main components of Baddeley's working memory are the central executive, the phonological loop, and the visuospatial sketchpad.
question_10: How many components does working memory have?
answert_10: three components
question_11: What are the types of working memory?
answert_11: There are two types of working memory: auditory memory and visual-spatial memory. You can think of these skills in terms of making a video. Auditory memory records what you're hearing while visual-spatial memory captures what you're seeing.
question_12: What are the 3 steps to the Atkinson-shiffrin model to memory?
answert_12: In order for a memory to go into storage (i.e., long-term memory), it has to pass through three distinct stages: Sensory Memory, Short-Term (i.e., Working) Memory, and finally Long-Term Memory. These stages were first proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin (1968).
question_13: What is the Atkinson-shiffrin model of memory quizlet?
answert_13: a model that represents memory as consisting of three separate components called the sensory register, the short term store and long term store, and distinguishes between structural features and control processes.
question_14: What is the 3 box model of memory?
answert_14: The three-box model of memory argues that information processing begins in sensory memory, moves to short-term memory, and eventually moves to long-term memory.
question_15: What is dual-task processing?
answert_15: Definition. Dual-task performance requires an individual to perform two tasks (i.e., Task A and Task B) simultaneously. Typically this type of performance is contrasted with single-task performance in which the individual only has to perform one task at a time (Task A or B).
question_16: What is dual-task interference in psychology?
answert_16: Cognitive-motor interference refers to dual-tasking (DT) interference (DTi) occurring when the simultaneous performance of a cognitive and a motor task leads to a percentage change in one or both tasks. Several theories exist to explain DTi in humans: the capacity-sharing, the bottleneck and the cross-talk theories.
question_17: What is dual-task effect?
answert_17: Dual task interference is observed when performance of one or both tasks within a dual task situation declines compared to the performance of each single task carried out separately (Kahneman, 1973).
question_18: What does dual-task procedure measure?
answert_18: The dual-task paradigm is an established methodology to measure performance capability under these conditions where attention must be divided between two concurrently performed tasks.
question_19: What brain damage did KF have?
answert_19: KF suffered brain damage from a motorcycle accident that damaged his short-term memory. KF's impairment was mainly for verbal information - his memory for visual information was largely unaffected. This shows that there are separate STM components for visual information (VSS) and verbal information (phonological loop).
question_20: Did KF have amnesia?
answert_20: The trauma caused by Cochrane's accident left him with severe anterograde amnesia that has made it impossible for him to remember both new personal experiences and semantic information. Although he could not remember personally experienced events, his semantic knowledge prior to his accident remained intact.
question_21: Who is patient KF?
answert_21: Patient K.F (Shallice Warrington, 1970) describe a case of a person with impaired auditory STM but intact LTM. This suggests distinct anatomical bases for the two.
question_22: What does Clive Wearing remember?
answert_22: When British conductor and musician Clive Wearing contracted a brain infection in 1985 he was left with a memory span of only 10 seconds. The infection - herpes encephalitis - left him unable to recognise people he had seen or remember things that had been said just moments earlier.
question_23: What happened KF?
answert_23: KF suffered brain damage from a motorcycle accident that damaged his short-term memory. KF's impairment was mainly for verbal information - his memory for visual information was largely unaffected. This shows that there are separate STM components for visual information (VSS) and verbal information (phonological loop).
question_24: Who studied patient KF?
answert_24: The trauma caused by Cochrane's accident left him with severe anterograde amnesia that has made it impossible for him to remember both new personal experiences and semantic information. Although he could not remember personally experienced events, his semantic knowledge prior to his accident remained intact.
question_25: Who created the working memory model?
answert_25: Alan Baddeley

question_1: Which keywords should be included in a resume?
answert_1: Your resume keywords should include specific job requirements, including your skills, competencies, relevant credentials, and previous positions and employers. Essentially, keywords should be words that, at a glance, will show the hiring manager that you are a good fit for the job.
question_2: How do you avoid repetitions on a resume?
answert_2:
Avoid Repetition on Your Resume
  • Use keywords wisely. Using keywords can be a great way to get your resume past the automated gatekeepers.
  • Shift the focus from duties to accomplishments.
  • Vary your verbs.
  • Watch out for stock phrases.
  • Read it out loud.
    • Jun 5, 2014
question_3: Which of the following should not be a part of resume?
answert_3: 3. Which of these is not mentioned in a resume? Explanation: Address is not mentioned in a resume. Age, experience, nationality and health is mentioned along with education.
question_4: When selecting words to include in a resume they should be complex?
answert_4: When selecting words to include in a rxe9sumxe9, they should be complex in nature. If your qualifications do not match the requirements of the position you are applying for, it is okay to lie about them in order to get an interview.
question_5: What are keywords to put in a resume?
answert_5: Resume keywords are words or phrases that describe specific job requirements. They are the abilities, skills, expertise, and values that the recruiter is looking for in a candidate. Hint: Abilities, skills, and values you should possess.
question_6: How many keywords should be on a resume?
answert_6: They look for resume keywords, too. So the questions is: how many resume keywords should you include in a resume? The general rule is 25-30. Don't spam the bots and their human overlords.
question_7: What are the 5 most important things included in a resume?
answert_7:
5 Things You Should Always Include on Your Resume
  • Job description keywords. Many employers use an applicant tracking system (ATS) to scan and rank your resume before they even lay eyes on it.
  • Professional title.
  • Certifications and credentials.
  • Relevant websites.
  • Stats on your resume.
question_8: Is it bad to repeat on resume?
answert_8: Repetition on your resume is good when it involves keywords, skills, accomplishments, and education that applicant tracking systems, recruiters and hiring managers are using to identify what they want most in a new hire. You start every accomplishment with the same verb (led, handled).
question_9: How do you list multiple jobs with the same description on a resume?
answert_9: To create stacked entries on your resume, start with the name of your company and its location. Next, stack each job title and the dates you held the job under the name of the company. Make sure you list your jobs in reverse-chronological order
question_10: What you should never put on your resume?
answert_10:
Things not to put on your resume
  • Too much information.
  • A solid wall of text.
  • Spelling mistakes and grammatical errors.
  • Inaccuracies about your qualifications or experience.
  • Unnecessary personal information.
  • Your age.
  • Negative comments about a former employer.
  • Details about your hobbies and interests.
question_11: How do you avoid repetitions in a cover letter?
answert_11: You need to add interest to the letter by writing in a way that avoids repetition. You should also scan your cover letter for any words or phrases that pop up more than once. question_7: What does thug life symbolize in The Hate U Give?
answert_7: Although he dies in chapter two, Khalil plays an important symbolic role in The Hate U Give. Specifically, Khalil's murder dramatizes the process of dehumanization and demonization of young black men in the wider news media that allows them to become scapegoats for the violence in their communities.
question_8: Why does Starr decide to explain why Khalil sold drugs during her TV interview?

question_9: Did Khalil sell drugs for King?

question_10: What is Khalil doing to make money?

question_1: What is a conversion factor?
answert_1: A conversion factor is an expression for the relationship between units that is used to change the units of a measured quantity without changing the value. A conversion ratio (or unit factor) always equals one (1), where the numerator and the denominator have the same value expressed in different units.
question_2: How do you find a conversion factor?
answert_2: A conversion factor is a number used to change one set of units to another, by multiplying or dividing. When a conversion is necessary, the appropriate conversion factor to an equal value must be used. For example, to convert inches to feet, the appropriate conversion value is 12 inches equal 1 foot.
question_3: What is a conversion factor example?
answert_3: A conversion factor is a number used to change one set of units to another, by multiplying or dividing. For example, to convert inches to feet, the appropriate conversion value is 12 inches equal 1 foot. To convert minutes to hours, the appropriate conversion value is 60 minutes equal 1 hour.
question_4: What is conversion factor simple definition?
answert_4: A conversion factors is a fraction that equals one. Multiplying a quantity by a conversion factor changes the units that measure a quantity but does not change the original amount of the quantity. Conversion factors equal unity (1) because they are made from equalities.
question_5: How do I find the conversion factor?

question_1: What is the lock and key theory?
answert_1: A theory to explain the mechanism of enzymatic reactions, in which it is proposed that the enzyme and substrate(s) bind temporarily to form an enzymesubstrate complex. Thus the enzyme and substrate(s) are said to fit together as do a lock and a key.
question_2: Who proposed lock and key theory?
answert_2: Emil Fischer
question_3: What is the lock and key theory for kids?
answert_3: Lock and key model Enzymes are very specific. In 1894 Emil Fischer suggested that both the enzyme and the substrate have specific complementary geometric shapes that fit exactly into one another. This is often referred to as the lock and key model.
question_4: What is the lock and key theory of enzyme activity?
answert_4: In 1894, German chemist Emil Fischer proposed the lock and key theory, which states that enzymes have a specific shape that directly correlates to the shape of the substrate. Basically, substrates fit into an enzyme the way a key fits into a lock. Only those substrates that exactly fit into the enzyme can be catalyzed.

question_1: What is keystone species?
answert_1: Powered by. Encyclopedic Entry Vocabulary. In any arrangement or community, the keystone is considered one of the most vital parts. In a marine ecosystem, or any type of ecosystem, a keystone species is an organism that helps hold the system together. Without its keystone species, ecosystems would look very different
question_2: What is a keystone species quizlet?
answert_2: A keystone species is a species that has a disproportionately large effect on its environment compared to its relative abundance. This differs from a foundation species because a foundation species is just usually a primary producer that dominates an ecosystem in abundance and influence.
question_3: What is a keystone species example quizlet?
answert_3: A keystone species is often, but not always, this type of species, because they can Control the distribution and population of large numbers of prey species. Example of keystone species. The deer, rabbits, and bird species in the ecosystem are at least partly controlled by the presence of the mountain lion.
question_4: What are keystone species give example?
answert_4: For example, the lion, jaguar (shown below), and gray wolf are considered keystone species as they help balance large ecosystems (e.g., Central and South American rainforests) by consuming a wide variety of prey species.
question_5: What is a keystone species example?
answert_5: A keystone species is a species that is particularly important in an ecosystem, and their importance is out of proportion to how many other species there are in the ecosystem. Some examples of keystone species include bison, prairie dog, and otter
question_6: What is keystone species answer?
answert_6: Ans. Keystone species meaning is that they are exceptionally important species which help in the survival of other species in an ecosystem, relative to its population.

Paine, he used the term 'keystone species'to describe the relationship between seastars (predators) and mussels (prey). In architecture, the 'keystone'refers to the wedge-shaped stone located at the top of an archway.
question_8: What is a keystone species kids definition?
answert_8: Keystone species are organisms, usually animals, that play a crucial role in different habitats and have a huge effect on the environment around them. They may help control the population of other species, or perhaps help the growth of certain types of plants in an ecosystem.

question_15: What is a keystone species Class 12?
answert_15: - A keystone species is a species which, compared to its abundance, has a disproportionately large effect on its natural environment, a concept introduced by the zoologist Robert T. Paine in 1969.
question_16: What are 5 examples of keystone species?
answert_16:
Examples of Keystone Species
  • Sharks. This fish is one of the largest in size in deep waters.
  • Sea Otter. This is a mammal in the North Pacific Ocean, which feeds on sea urchins thus maintaining the coastal marine ecosystem.
  • Snowshoe hare.
  • The African Elephant.
  • Prairie dogs.
  • Starfish.
  • Gray Wolves.
  • Grizzly bears.
question_17: What is keystone species give examples?
answert_17: For example, the lion, jaguar (shown below), and gray wolf are considered keystone species as they help balance large ecosystems (e.g., Central and South American rainforests) by consuming a wide variety of prey species.
question_18: What is a keystone species Ncert?
answert_18: Keystone species are those that have an extremely high impact on a particular ecosystem relative to its population.
question_19: What is keystone species Mcq?
answert_19: A keystone species is a non dominant species. It determines the structure of a given population, despite of present in limited amounts. So, option A is the correct answer.
question_20: What are keystone species Class 12?
answert_20: Hint: Keystone species is a species which has larger effect on natural environment, where the concept of keystone species was introduced by Robert T Paine in the year 1969, and this keystone species are described as the one that play critical role in maintaining the structure of an ecological community, and affecting
question_21: How do you identify a keystone species?
answert_21: The surest way to identify a keystone species is through an experiment that eliminates it from its environment, like Paine throwing coastal sea stars back into the sea. But it's not always possibleor ethicalto completely remove an animal from its environment.
question_22: What is a keystone species define and give an example?
answert_22: A keystone species is a species that is particularly important in an ecosystem, and their importance is out of proportion to how many other species there are in the ecosystem. Some examples of keystone species include bison, prairie dog, and otter.
question_23: Who defined keystone species?
answert_23: Keystone species are those which have an extremely high impact on a particular ecosystem relative to its population. Small predators that consume herbivorous species prevent such herbivores from decimating the plant species in the ecosystem, and are considered keystone species.
question_24: What is a keystone species simple definition?
answert_24: A keystone species is an organism that helps define an entire ecosystem. Without its keystone species, the ecosystem would be dramatically different or cease to exist altogether. The ecosystem would be forced to radically change, allowing new and possibly invasive species to populate the habitat.
question_25: What is keystone species example?
answert_25: Large mammalian predators are keystone species for large ecosystems. They consume a wide variety of species and thereby help in maintaining a balance in the ecosystem. For eg., Lions, tigers, jaguars are a few large mammalian predators.

question_1: What did Kevin Rudd say in the sorry speech?
answert_1: I move: That today we honour the Indigenous peoples of this land, the oldest continuing cultures in human history. We reflect on their past mistreatment.
question_2: What was the purpose of Kevin Rudd's sorry speech?
answert_2: On 13 February 2008, then Prime Minister Kevin Rudd moved a motion of Apology to Indigenous Australians. His apology was a formal apology on behalf of the successive parliaments and governments whose policies and laws inflicted profound grief, suffering and loss on these our fellow Australians.
question_3: What was Kevin Rudd's apology?
answert_3: On 13 February 2008 Prime Minister Kevin Rudd made a formal apology to Australia's Indigenous peoples, particularly to the Stolen Generations whose lives had been blighted by past government policies of forced child removal and Indigenous assimilation.
question_4: How did the church respond to the Stolen Generation?
answert_4: Generally the churches expressed interest in assisting and supporting all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and doing what they can to remedy the hurt and damage suffered by those affected by forcible removal in particular.
question_5: Why was the word sorry important as part of the apology?
answert_5: The word sorry in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages and cultures holds special meaning, often used to describe the rituals surrounding death (Sorry Business). Sorry, in this context, expresses empathy, sympathy and an acknowledgment of loss rather than responsibility.
question_6: Does the apology mean that reconciliation has been achieved?
answert_6: The National Apology was a historic step forward in the process of reconciliation. The acknowledgement of the wrong done to the Stolen Generations is an essential aspect of historical acceptance one of the five dimensions we use to measure reconciliation.
question_7: What was the purpose of Kevin Rudd's apology?
answert_7: On 13 February 2008 Prime Minister Kevin Rudd made a formal apology to Australia's Indigenous peoples, particularly to the Stolen Generations whose lives had been blighted by past government policies of forced child removal and Indigenous assimilation.
question_8: Why is National Sorry Day celebrated in Australia?
answert_8: National Sorry Day is commemorated in Australia each year on May 26 as an expression of solidarity with the justice and reconciliation agenda of the nation's Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, and in particular with the tens of thousands of Aboriginal children who were removed from their parents during Australia's
question_9: Why is Apology Day important?
answert_9: On 13 February 2008 Prime Minister Kevin Rudd made a formal apology to Australia's Indigenous peoples, particularly to the Stolen Generations whose lives had been blighted by past government policies of forced child removal and Indigenous assimilation.
question_10: What happened on Sorry Day?
answert_10: A Day of Remorse and Healing In addition to acknowledging the trauma and loss that continues to affect Indigenous communities, families and individuals, National Sorry Day also provides a chance to focus on healing and pursue reconciliation in Australian society.
question_11: Was the church involved in the Stolen Generation?
answert_11: The complicity of state and church in the removal and placement of Aboriginal children in Australia has been well documented. Alongside the apologies, churches have engaged in activities of reconciliation.
question_12: What did the Catholic Church do to the aboriginals?
answert_12: The St Vincent de Paul Society provided assistance to Aboriginal people in the form of food, rent and clothing, fares and finding employment.
question_13: What is the Catholic Church response to residential schools?
answert_13: VANCOUVER, Sept 24 (Reuters) - The Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops on Friday officially apologized for their role in the country's notorious residential school system for the first time, after refusing to do so for years despite public pressure.
question_14: Why was the Catholic Church involved in residential schools?
answert_14: The Catholic Church ran most of Canada's residential schools, which were federally funded institutions meant to strip Indigenous children of their traditions, language and culture. The Truth and Reconciliation Commission has said Canada's residential school policy was cultural genocide.
question_15: Why is the word sorry important as part of the apology?

question_16: Why was the sorry speech important?
answert_16: It supported making a formal public apology to the victims of forced child removal, especially the Stolen Generations. question_17: Why did Kevin Rudd say sorry in 2008?
answert_17: We apologise especially for the removal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families, their communities and their country. For the pain, suffering, and hurt of these Stolen Generations, their descendants and for their families left behind, we say sorry.

question_20: Why was the apology so important for reconciliation?
answert_20: These formal apologies were an important step towards building a respectful new relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. question_25: What is National Sorry Day in Australia and why is it important?

question_1: How does Kevin help Leo in Stargirl?
answert_1: Leo's best friend stands by him when he is being shunned, but just barely. To Kevin's credit, he still sits with Leo at lunch and talks to Leo when everyone else stopped. question_3: What crime did Kevin commit in Stargirl?

question_4: Why does Kevin want fake Stargirl?

question_5: What does Kevin do in Stargirl?

question_6: What explanation did Kevin give Leo for the way people were treating Stargirl?

question_1: What are the five key features of federalism?
answert_1: Different levels of government, jurisdiction, constitutional guarantee, changing the provisions, power of court in disputes are the five features of federalism.
question_2: What are key features of federalism 10?
answert_2:
What are the prominent features of Federalism?
  • The power is distributed among the executive, judiciary and legislative.
  • The national government shares powers with the provincial governments.
  • Government power is divided between different levels of government.
  • Elected officials exercise supreme power in the government.

answert_23: Indian federalism is a threefold distribution based on three lists: I - Union List on which centre make laws such as defence, currency, etc. II - State List on which state make laws such as police, trade, agriculture, etc. III - Concurrent List on which both Centre and State Legislates such as education, marriage, etc.
question_24: What are the key features of federalism class10?
answert_24:
KEY FEATURES OF FEDERALISM:
  • There are two or more levels (or tiers) of government.
  • Different tiers of government govern the same citizens, but each tier has its own jurisdictionin specific matters of legislation, taxation and administration.
question_25: What are the features of federalism Class 10?
answert_25:
What are the prominent features of Federalism?
  • The power is distributed among the executive, judiciary and legislative.
  • The national government shares powers with the provincial governments.
  • Government power is divided between different levels of government.
  • Elected officials exercise supreme power in the government.
Aug 25, 2021

question_5: What is an opinion paper format?
answert_5: An opinion essay is a formal piece of writing which requires your opinion on a topic. Your opinion should be stated clearly. Throughout the essay you will give various arguments/reasons/viewpoints on the topic and these will be supported by evidence and/or examples.
question_6: What is the structure of this essay?
answert_6: A formal persuasive essay is made of three parts: Issue; Side; Argument.
question_7: What are the three parts of an opinion essay?
answert_7:
Organise your essay into clear paragraphs.
  • Introduction: Introduce the topic and give your opinion. Say whether you agree or disagree with the statement.
  • Body: 2 or 3 paragraphs. For each paragraph give a reason to support your opinion.
  • Conclusion: Summarize your ideas and repeat your opinion using different words.
Mar 19, 2017

answert_10: An opinion paragraph has three main parts. The topic sentence states the opinion. The body sentences support the opinion with reasons. The ending sentence restates or emphasizes the opinion.

question_1: What rocks are in the ophiolite sequence?
answert_1: Ophiolites or the ophiolite complex is the general name for the community of mafic and ultramafic intrusives (gabbro, peridotite, and pyroxenite), and extrusive igneous rocks (spilitekeratophyrebasalt) that originate from the oceanic crust and mantle, and greywacke sandstone, shales and siliceous sedimentary rocks
question_2: Where do ophiolite sequences originate?
answert_2: ultramafic rocks are known as ophiolites. Many geologists believe that ophiolites formed at oceanic ridges were emplaced by tectonic forces at convergent plate boundaries and then became exposed in highly deformed orogenic (mountain) belts.
question_3: What are the 3 main layers in an ophiolite?
answert_3: Sediments (layer 1) Volcanic Crust (layer 2) Plutonic Crust (layer 3) Mantle Harzburgite (layer 4) 4 layers distinguished from Geophysics: Typical Ophiolite: 1.
question_4: What is ophiolite used for?
answert_4: Ophiolites in orogenic (mountain building) belts represent sutures between two continental plates. Their recognition is therefore important in tectonic reconstructions.
question_5: What is the composition of ophiolite?
answert_5: An ophiolite sequence consists of variably altered oceanic rocks, including marine sediments, ocean crust, and part of the mantle. The name ophiolite means snakestone from ophio (snake) and lithos (stone) in Greek.
question_6: What is ophiolite rock?
answert_6: Sediments (layer 1) Volcanic Crust (layer 2) Plutonic Crust (layer 3) Mantle Harzburgite (layer 4) 4 layers distinguished from Geophysics: Typical Ophiolite: 1.
question_7: How is ophiolite formed?
answert_7: An ophiolite is a section of Earth's oceanic crust and the underlying upper mantle that has been uplifted and exposed above sea level and often emplaced onto continental crustal rocks. The suffix lite from the Greek lithos means stone. Some ophiolites have a green color.
question_8: What is the probable origin of an ophiolite?
answert_8: An ophiolite is emplaced either from downgoing oceanic lithosphere via subduction-accretion or from the upper plate in a subduction zone through trenchcontinent collision. Subduction zone tectonics is thus the most important factor in the igneous evolution of ophiolites and their emplacement into continental margins.
question_9: Where is ophiolite located in the Philippines?

question_10: How does an ophiolite form at the subduction zone?
answert_10: lithosphere, which becomes an ophiolite when incorporated into continental margins through a complex process known as 'emplacement'. A fundamental problem of ophiolite emplacement is how dense oceanic crust becomes emplaced over less dense material(s) of continental margins or subduction-accretion systems.

question_15: Why is an ophiolite important?
answert_15: Since scientists have never drilled deep enough into the Earth to observe the mantle, ophiolites are important because they are places where geologists can observe large sections of mantle rocks directly. Since then, many more mantle exposures have been discovered, particularly on the ocean floor.
question_16: What ophiolite means?
answert_16: Ophiolite is thrust sheets of ancient oceanic crust and upper part of mantle rocks that have been uplifted and exposed above sea level and often emplaced on top of the continental lithosphere.
question_17: Where can ophiolite be found?
answert_17: Ophiolites have been found in Cyprus, New Guinea, Newfoundland, California, and Oman. The Samail ophiolite in southeastern Oman has probably been studied in the greatest detail. The rocks probably formed in the Cretaceous not far from the what is now the Persian Gulf.
question_18: What is an ophiolite suite?

question_19: What is an ophiolite made of?
answert_19: Ophiolites are pieces of oceanic plate that have been thrusted (obducted) onto the edge of continental plates. They provide models for processes at mid-ocean ridges. question_1: Does operating system manage computer hardware and software?
answert_1: An operating system (OS) is software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for computer programs. Operating systems are found on many devices that contain a computerfrom cellular phones and video game consoles to web servers and supercomputers.
question_2: What program manages computer hardware and software?
answert_2: operating system (OS)
question_3: What are operating systems also called?
answert_3: The operating system, also known as an OS, interfaces with the computer's hardware and provides services that applications can use.
question_4: When unwanted software is installed along with application software it is known as a N ):?
answert_4: Malware is any software or mobile application specifically designed to harm a computer, a mobile device, the software it's running, or its users. Malware exhibits malicious behavior that can include installing software without user consent and installing harmful software such as viruses.
question_5: Does an operating system manage hardware?
answert_5: The operating system (OS) manages all of the software and hardware on the computer. It performs basic tasks such as file, memory and process management, handling input and output, and controlling peripheral devices such as disk drives and printers.
question_6: Does the operating system manage software?
answert_6: The operating system's job Your computer's operating system (OS) manages all of the software and hardware on the computer. Most of the time, there are several different computer programs running at the same time, and they all need to access your computer's central processing unit (CPU), memory, and storage.
