She has almost no one left to turn to in her life now and refuses to think her new friend has anything to do with this.
question_10: What did Nate admit to Bronwyn?
answert_10: Nate admits that he has sold drugs but insists that he didn't kill Simon. Bronwyn then reveals that the rumor about herthat she cheated on a testis true as well. She feels ashamed, but Nate doesn't want her to worry about what people think. Bronwyn doesn't want to disappoint her father.
question_11: Is Nate the killer in one of us is lying?

question_1: What pairs of opposite sides are parallel?
answert_1: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral in which both pairs of opposite sides are parallel .
question_2: What does it mean when opposite sides are parallel?
answert_2: Two pairs of opposite sides are parallel (by definition). Two pairs of opposite sides are equal in length. Two pairs of opposite angles are equal in measure. One pair of opposite sides is parallel and equal in length.
question_3: What opposite sides that are parallel?
answert_3: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral whose opposite sides are parallel. The opposite angles of a parallelogram are equal.
question_4: How many pairs of opposite sides are parallel?
answert_4: Two pairs
question_5: What shape has 2 pairs of opposite sides parallel?
answert_5: parallelogram
question_6: How do you know if opposite sides are parallel?
answert_6: Method 1: If the opposite sides of the quadrilateral are parallel to the other. In order to prove that the opposite sides are parallel, you have to prove that the slope of AB is the same as the slope of CD, and the slope of BC is the same as the slope of AD.
question_7: What does it mean when all sides are parallel?
answert_7: Two sides or lines are parallel if they are lines that are always the same distance from each other and will never intersect or touch. That is what it means to be parallel.
question_8: Which have parallel opposite sides?
answert_8: parallelogram

question_17: Is there a sequel to the book One of Us Is Lying?

question_1: What is the message of One of Us Is Lying?

question_2: Is Cooper cheating in One of Us Is Lying?

question_3: Who cheated in One of Us Is Lying?

question_4: What is the social issue in One of Us Is Lying?
answert_4: The main themes in One of Us Is Lying are the effects of marginalization, the desire for power, and lies versus truth. The effects of marginalization: The novel centers around the dire consequences of an individual's marginalization from the broader social group.
question_5: What is the symbolism in one of us is lying?

question_1: What is a number when it is a product of the same two numbers?
answert_1: The product of two numbers is the result you get when you multiply them together. So 12 is the product of 3 and 4, 20 is the product of 4 and 5 and so on.
question_2: What is the product number of 1?
answert_2: The product of any number and one is the number itself. 1 xd7 1 1, 3 xd7 1 3, 5 xd7 1 5, 7 xd7 1 7, 9 xd7 1 9, etc. The product of number 1 and any other number is the number itself.
question_3: What is the product of any number and 1?

question_5: When two numbers multiplied with each other they are called of the product?
answert_5: The result of a multiplication operation is called a product. question_6: What is the product when you multiply by 1?

question_13: What 2 numbers have the same sum and product?
answert_13: The natural numbers 1,2,3 have a special property: their sum is equal to their product. 1+2+31 xb7 2 xb7 3. The numbers 1,1,2,4 possess the same property: 1+1+2+41 xb7 1 xb7 2 xb7 4.

question_7: What is Silent Spring in science?
answert_7: Silent Spring is an environmental science book by Rachel Carson. The book was published on September 27, 1962, documenting the adverse environmental effects caused by the indiscriminate use of pesticides. The result of her research was Silent Spring, which brought environmental concerns to the American public.
question_8: Why was Silent Spring so important quizlet?
answert_8: A book written by Rachel Carson in 1962. It warned against the growing use of pesticides - chemicals used to kill insects and rodents. Carson argued that pesticides poisoned the food and thus killed many birds and fish. The book warned of a silent spring in which birds killed of by pesticides would no longer sing.

question_10: What caused the Silent Spring?
answert_10: Silent Spring was the result of this partnership and several years of research, focusing primarily on the effects of DDT and similar pesticides. Carson was diagnosed with breast cancer during this time, causing the book's publication to be delayed until 1962.
question_11: Why are doctors in the town puzzled in Silent Spring?

question_12: Where does Silent Spring take place?
answert_12: The impetus for Silent Spring was a letter written in January 1958 by Carson's friend, Olga Owens Huckins, to The Boston Herald, describing the death of birds around her property in Duxbury, Massachusetts resulting from the aerial spraying of DDT to kill mosquitoes, a copy of which Huckins sent to Carson.
question_13: Why Is Silent Spring called Silent Spring?
answert_13: Published in 1962, Silent Spring was widely read by the general public and became a New York Times best seller. The title Silent Spring was inspired by a line from the John Keats poem La Belle Dame sans Merci and evokes a ruined environment in which the sedge is wither'd from the lake, / And no birds sing.
question_14: What do you think happened to this small town Carson is describing?
answert_14: In the first chapter, Carson describes a town that was once filled with beautiful wildlife. There were many wild animals and plant life that people would travel to see. However, this activity ceases and the town changes. People become sick, animal populations dwindle, and plants are dying.
question_15: Why was Silent Spring banned?
answert_15: Kennedy ordered the President's Science Advisory Committee to examine the issues the book raised, its report thoroughly vindicated both Silent Spring and its author. As a result, DDT came under much closer government supervision and was eventually banned.
question_16: What chemical is Silent Spring about?
answert_16: Silent Spring presents a view of nature compromised by synthetic pesticides, especially DDT. question_17: Did scientists support Silent Spring?

question_18: Why was Silent Spring so important?
answert_18: Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, published in 1962, was a landmark in the development of the modern environmental movement. Carson's book promoted a paradigm shift in how chemists practice their discipline and helped to establish a new role for chemists in investigating the impact of human activity on the environment.

question_20: What was the most important legacy of Silent Spring?
answert_20: The most important legacy of Silent Spring, though, was a new public awareness that nature was vulnerable to human intervention. Carson had made a radical proposal: that, at times, technological progress is so fundamentally at odds with natural processes that it must be curtailed.
question_21: Why was Silent Spring a revolutionary book?
answert_21: Carson's willingness to lead in the effort to expose the harms of pesticides meant a campaign against the powerful industries, the government, and public opinion. Silent Spring was revolutionary; it shattered the misconception that man and nature were separate entities.

question_1: What is the thesis of Silent Spring?
answert_1: Carson's thesis throughout Silent Spring was that pesticides and chemicals used to kill pests on crops bleed into the environment and affect our water sources. These chemicals are involuntarily ingested by larger creatures when they eat poisoned insects.

question_4: What is the mood of Silent Spring?
answert_4: The mood of Silent Spring is one of urgency. Carson employs the literary conventions and the language of melodrama to inspire the reader's admiration for the beauty and harmony of nature and also to inspire the reader's repugnance for the reckless destruction caused by chemical pesticides.
question_5: What is the main subject of Silent Spring?

question_6: What did Silent Spring warn about?
answert_6: In 1962, Rachel Carson published her most popular book, Silent Spring. The book warned about the use of man-made pesticides, especially DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane). DDT was a popular pesticide mass manufactured during World War II.
question_7: What was the goal of Silent Spring?
answert_7: In 1970, the Environmental Protection Agency was established, in large part due to environmental consciousness raised by Silent Spring. Rachel Carson's goal, to alert the public and to build a fire under the Government, was an astounding success.
question_8: What was the significance of Rachel Carson and her book Silent Spring?
answert_8: The book was published on September 27, 1962, documenting the adverse environmental effects caused by the indiscriminate use of pesticides. Carson accused the chemical industry of spreading disinformation, and public officials of accepting the industry's marketing claims unquestioningly.

question_10: What was the impact of Silent Spring?
answert_10: Silent Spring was met with fierce opposition by chemical companies, but it spurred a reversal in national pesticide policy, led to a nationwide ban on DDT for agricultural uses, and inspired an environmental movement that led to the creation of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
question_11: What is the main theme of Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring?
answert_11: The overarching theme of Silent Spring is the powerfuland often negativeeffect humans have on the natural world. Carson's main argument is that pesticides have detrimental effects on the environment; she says these are more properly termed biocides because their effects are rarely limited to solely targeting pests.

question_13: Is Silent Spring banned?

question_2: Is silicon dioxide a crystal structure?
answert_2: In the majority of silicates, the silicon atom shows tetrahedral coordination, with four oxygen atoms surrounding a central Si atom (see 3-D Unit Cell). Thus, SiO2 forms 3-dimensional network solids in which each silicon atom is covalently bonded in a tetrahedral manner to 4 oxygen atoms.

answert_23: In the future, mineralogists expect to identify additional polymorphs and related forms of silicon dioxide to further demonstrate that, while all quartz is indeed silicon dioxide, all silicon dioxide is not quartz.
question_24: Is silica a quartz?
answert_24: Silica, often referred to as quartz, is a very common mineral. It is found in many materials common on construction and oil gas sites, including soil, sand, concrete, masonry, rock, granite, and landscaping materials.
question_25: What type of rock is silicon dioxide?
answert_25: siliceous rock, any of a group of sedimentary rocks that consist largely or almost entirely of silicon dioxide (SiO2), either as quartz or as amorphous silica and cristobalite; included are rocks that have formed as chemical precipitates and excluded are those of detrital or fragmental origin.

question_1: What is a summary of Silent Spring?
answert_1: 1-Sentence-Summary: Silent Spring is the story that sparked the global grassroots environmental movement in 1962, explaining how chemical pesticides work, what their drawbacks are, and how we can protect crops in better, more sustainable ways.
question_2: What was chapter 1 of Silent Spring about?
answert_2: Chapter 1: A Fable for Tomorrow In the first chapter of her book, Carson introduces her point through a short imaginary story of a town in the heart of America. She describes this town as full of life, with blooming flowers, numerous plants and animals and creates a peaceful and relaxed image in her audiences mind.
question_3: What are the main points in Silent Spring?
answert_3: The overarching theme of Silent Spring is the powerfuland often negativeeffect humans have on the natural world. Carson's main argument is that pesticides have detrimental effects on the environment; she says these are more properly termed biocides because their effects are rarely limited to solely targeting pests.
question_4: Why was Silent Spring banned?
answert_4: Kennedy ordered the President's Science Advisory Committee to examine the issues the book raised, its report thoroughly vindicated both Silent Spring and its author. As a result, DDT came under much closer government supervision and was eventually banned.
question_5: What was the goal of Silent Spring?
answert_5: In 1970, the Environmental Protection Agency was established, in large part due to environmental consciousness raised by Silent Spring. Rachel Carson's goal, to alert the public and to build a fire under the Government, was an astounding success.
question_6: What did Silent Spring warn about?
answert_6: In 1962, Rachel Carson published her most popular book, Silent Spring. The book warned about the use of man-made pesticides, especially DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane). DDT was a popular pesticide mass manufactured during World War II.
question_7: What is the meaning of the title Silent Spring?
answert_7: Published in 1962, Silent Spring was widely read by the general public and became a New York Times best seller. The title Silent Spring was inspired by a line from the John Keats poem La Belle Dame sans Merci and evokes a ruined environment in which the sedge is wither'd from the lake, / And no birds sing.
question_8: What is Silent Spring summary about?
answert_8: Silent Spring is considered the book that started the global grassroots environmental movement. Released in 1962, it focuses on the negative effects of chemical pesticides that were, at the time, a large part of US agriculture. Rachel Carson and her work began initiating a shift in global environmental consciousness.

question_1: Why was Silent Spring banned?

question_2: What was the main message of Rachel Carson's Silent Spring?
answert_2: The overarching theme of Silent Spring is the powerfuland often negativeeffect humans have on the natural world. question_3: Is Silent Spring a true story?
answert_3: Silent Spring began with a fable for tomorrow a true story using a composite of examples drawn from many real communities where the use of DDT had caused damage to wildlife, birds, bees, agricultural animals, domestic pets, and even humans.
question_4: What was Carson's main point in the other road?
answert_4: Carson argues that pesticides, although a tempting reflection of man's newfound power in the world, have inflated our sense of that power to a point that will lead to our destruction.
question_5: Why was Silent Spring so controversial?
answert_5: Silent Spring presents a view of nature compromised by synthetic pesticides, especially DDT. Once these pesticides entered the biosphere, Carson argued, they not only killed bugs but also made their way up the food chain to threaten bird and fish populations and could eventually sicken children.
question_6: What did Silent Spring ban?
answert_6: Changes in federal law in 1964 required companies to prove that something did not cause harm before they could sell it. In 1972, activists pushed for and won a ban on DDT, the pesticide that started Carson's research for Silent Spring.
question_7: Is Silent Spring banned?
answert_7: Silent Spring marked the beginning of an environmental movement, and DDT's agricultural use in the United States was banned in 1972. But unfortunately Rachel did not survive to see the day. She was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

answert_8: The Consequences of Silent Spring. Before her book Silent Spring was published in 1962, Rachel Carson knew it would be controversial. Carson had written about how the reckless use of pesticides was contaminating the natural environment and slowly poisoning living things

question_16: What is the other road in Silent Spring?

question_17: What issue did Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring address that sparked the environmental movement?

question_11: What was the objective of Silent Spring?
answert_11: Silent Spring: A Change in Perspective Silent Spring seeded important new ideas in the public mind: That spraying chemicals to control insect populations can also kill birds that feed on dead or dying insects. That chemicals travel not only through the environment, but through food chains.
question_12: What is the significance of Rachel Carson's Silent Spring?
answert_12: The most important legacy of Silent Spring, though, was a new public awareness that nature was vulnerable to human intervention. Carson had made a radical proposal: that, at times, technological progress is so fundamentally at odds with natural processes that it must be curtailed.
question_13: Is sulfanilamide still used today?
answert_13: Sulfanilamide is a vaginal antifungal cream that was used to treat vaginal yeast infections. It works by stopping the growth of fungus causing the infection. Is sulfanilamide still available? No, there are currently no brand or generic versions available in the United States
question_14: Is sulfanilamide toxic?
answert_14: The AMA laboratory isolated diethylene glycol as the toxic ingredient and immediately issued a warning, through newspapers and radio, that Elixir Sulfanilamide was toxic and deadly. A New York physician learned of the deaths on the 14th and promptly notified Food and Drug Administration headquarters.
question_15: What caused the elixir tragedy of 1937?
answert_15: The Elixir Sulfanilamide disaster of 1937 occurred shortly after the introduction of sulfanilamide, the first sulfa antimicrobial drug.

question_1: What is the plot of the book silence?
answert_1: Silence is the story of the Japanese persecution of Christians that occurred in the 1600s. More specifically, Endo traces the life of Sebastian Rodrigues, a Portuguese missionary from the Society of Jesus, as he tries to survive as a Christian priest working in Japan.
question_2: What is the theme of silence?
answert_2: Martin Scorsese has always favored religion-based stories. Scorsese's filmography includes several religious-themed movies, from 1988's Last Temptation of Christ, known for its notoriously humane depiction or Jesus, and 1997's Dali Lama picture, Kundun.
question_3: How many pages is Silence by Shusaku Endo?
question_4: What causes Garrpe and Rodrigues to split up in the story?
answert_4: Father Rodrigues and Father Garrpe have just received bad news: their former teacher, Father Ferreira, has renounced his faith after being captured by the Japanese government. question_1: What are the main themes in Silas Marner?
answert_1: The major theme of Silas Marner is of course the influence of pure, natural human relationships, but there are several others. Some of these are never the subject of a direct statement, but constant repetition brings them to the reader's attention, and the novel draws some sort of conclusion about them.
question_2: What is the moral of Silas Marner?
answert_2: The moral of the story is that everyone is rewarded or punished for their action or conduct to others. I think that justice has been done with all of the main characters, but the minor characters such as Molly and William, for differing reasons, have not had justice.
question_3: What does Silas Marner symbolize?
answert_3: Silas'renewal of faith and human contact in this way becomes a symbolic rebirth. Both through his fits and through his alienation from other men, he is a man who has seemed dead and has come back to life.
question_4: What are some symbols in Silas Marner?

Silas Marner Symbols

  • Raveloe.

  • The Hearth.
question_5: What is the major theme of Silas Marner?

question_6: What is the main plot of Silas Marner?
answert_6: Silas Marner is a respected member of the small 19th Century rural religious community of Lantern Yard, but his world is shaken when he is wrongfully accused of a theft and expelled as a pariah. He settles anonymously in the town of Raveloe in a hermit-like existence in an isolated cottage.
question_7: What can you learn from Silas Marner?
answert_7: Another lesson that the novel exemplifies is that money cannot buy happiness. Silas took to collecting gold pieces, paid to him for his work as a weaver in Raveloe. As a result, he felt grieved, lonely, and hurt. Collecting gold, silver, and money in general became a habit for him and helped him feel better.
question_8: What sort of thematic unity do you find in the tale of Silas Marner?
answert_8: The theme of interdependence of faith and community is portrayed dramatically in the story. Symbols like Silas'loom, Lantern yard, the hearth, etc. have been used to represent abstract ideas and concepts.
question_9: What is the point of Silas Marner?
answert_9: Though he does not struggle to find purpose and connection in his life, the novel is about his recovery of purpose, faith, and community through his finding Eppie. rising action Silas spends fifteen years in relative isolation, amassing a hoard of gold coins that is then stolen by Dunstan Cass.
question_10: What is the conclusion of Silas Marner?
answert_10: Silas Marner Conclusion Eppie tells Silas that she will always be with him, and Aaron will be with Silas as well. She looks ethereal and angel-like in her wedding gown, provided by Mrs. Godfrey Cass.
question_11: How would you describe Silas Marner?
answert_11: A simple, honest, and kindhearted weaver. After losing faith in both God and his fellow man, Silas lives for fifteen years as a solitary miser. After his money is stolen, his faith and trust are restored by his adopted daughter, Eppie, whom he lovingly raises.
question_12: What was the story of Silas Marner about?
answert_12: The novel is set in the early years of the 19th century. Silas Marner, a weaver, is a member of a small Calvinist congregation in Lantern Yard, a slum street in Northern England. He is falsely accused of stealing the congregation's funds while watching over the very ill deacon.
question_13: What is symbolism in Silas Marner?
answert_13: Silas'door stands open as a symbol of his spiritual condition, and evil and good in turn come and work their influence on him. Silas'renewal of faith and human contact in this way becomes a symbolic rebirth.
question_14: What is the message of Silas Marner?
answert_14: The major theme of Silas Marner is of course the influence of pure, natural human relationships, but there are several others. Some of these are never the subject of a direct statement, but constant repetition brings them to the reader's attention, and the novel draws some sort of conclusion about them.
question_15: What does gold symbolize in Silas Marner?
answert_15: The gold symbolizes Marner's isolation and his exclusion from human love and affection. His heart is directed toward the cold and unfeeling gold, and he appears cold and unfeeling to those around him. His love for gold isolates him; his love for Eppie re-connects him to the community.
question_16: What does Silas Marner's cottage represent?
answert_16: Silas Marner's cottage represents warmth, light, and happiness for the orphan child Eppie.
question_17: What does the loom symbolize in Silas Marner?
answert_17: The gold symbolizes Marner's isolation and his exclusion from human love and affection. His heart is directed toward the cold and unfeeling gold, and he appears cold and unfeeling to those around him. His love for gold isolates him; his love for Eppie re-connects him to the community.
question_18: What does the hearth symbolize in Silas Marner?
answert_18: Silas's loom embodies many of the novel's major themes. On a literal level, the loom is Silas's livelihood and source of income. The extent to which Silas's obsession with money deforms his character is physically embodied by the bent frame and limited eyesight he develops due to so many hours at the loom.
question_19: How is industrial machinery symbolized in Silas Marner?
answert_19: The cottage and hearth represent the center of love and family for Eppie and Marner. It is the place where Eppie appears in Marner's life, a place of warmth and familiarity, and it remains the center of their home throughout the novel.
question_20: What does Silas Marner represent?

question_21: What are the two plots in Silas Marner?
answert_21: There are two plots in Silas Marner: Silas'rejection of humanity and his redemption, and the plot involving Godfrey and his two wives. The two plots are not unrelated, however. In the beginning, there is little connection between them, but by the end of the tale they are inseparable.
question_22: What is the climax of the main plot in Silas Marner?
answert_22: Climax: The climax occurs with the theft of Silas'gold and the arrival of Eppie. From this point forward, his dormant springs of love are rejuvenated and his world changes for the better. Outcome: The novel ends in comedy.

He tells Eppie how he initially hoped she might somehow turn back into the gold, but later grew fearful of that that prospect because he loved her more than the money.
question_6: What is the ending of Silas Marner?
answert_6: Summary: Chapter 16. The action resumes sixteen years later, as the Raveloe congregation files out of church after a Sunday service. Silas Marner is also in the departing congregation. His eyes have a more focused look than they did before, but otherwise he looks quite old for a man of fifty-five.
question_7: What happens in chapter 15 of Silas Marner?
answert_7: Silas Marner Chapter 17 Now managing their father's farm, Priscilla tells Nancy that she should have started a dairy, to take her mind off things - namely, children. Reflecting over her marriage and Godfrey's desire to have children, Nancy wonders where her husband might be.
question_8: How does Silas discover the child and her mother?
answert_8: Silas Marner Chapter 15 He sees that Eppie is content with Silas, and he is happy knowing that she is cared for so well. Adding to his happiness is that Dunsey still has not returned to Raveloe, and he feels that he will get all of what he wished: Nancy's love and the approval of the townspeople.
question_9: What was Godfrey's proposal to Silas Eppie?
answert_9: Godfrey finally says that Silas should not stand in the way of the child's welfare. He wants to save her from marrying a workingman and leading a hard life forever. Silas then tells him to ask Eppie what she wants. Godfrey gently asks Eppie to come live with him, and Nancy also urges her.
question_10: Does Eppie owe to her biological father?
answert_10: Nancy reminds Eppie that what she says is a natural way to feel, but that she also owes a duty to her true father. Eppie chooses to see Marner as her true father, whom she loves and obeys, rather than Godfrey who is her father only by birth.
question_11: Who married EP pie at the end?
answert_11: Aaron Winthrop
question_12: What happens at the end of Silas Marner?
answert_12: Silas Marner ends with a wedding, a curiously optimistic send-off for a novel that has led its protagonist Silas (and its secondary protagonist Godfrey) through one misfortune after another. The pat endingEppie sighing delightedly that nobody could be happier than we areshould satisfy even the pickiest romantic.
question_13: When Godfrey confesses to Eppie that he is her father What is her reaction?
answert_13: He says he noticed that Eppie took a dislike to him when he confessed that he was her father, and he decides that it must be his punishment in life to be disliked by his daughter. Godfrey tells Nancy that he is grateful, despite everything, to have been able to marry her, and vows to be satisfied with their marriage.
question_14: What is Nancy's attitude toward Godfrey?
answert_14: At the moment, her attitude toward her erring lover is of prime importance. She does not know how badly Godfrey has erred, but she has clearly convinced herself that he has erred too greatly to be attractive to her. It is equally clear that he is still attractive to her.
question_15: What was the secret that Godfrey had lived with?
answert_15: Godfrey Cass, Dunsey's elder brother, also harbours a secret past. He is married to, but estranged from, Molly Farren, an opium-addicted working-class woman living in another town. This secret prevents Godfrey from marrying Nancy Lammeter, a young middle-class woman.
question_16: Did Godfrey marry Nancy?
answert_16: Godfrey marries Nancy Lammeter, but their only child dies as a baby. Dustan's body is discovered sixteen years later at the bottom of the quarry, and Godfrey confesses everything to Nancy. Godfrey tells Eppie and Silas that Eppie is his child and offers to adopt her, but she refuses.
question_17: Who did Godfrey marry?
answert_17: Molly Farren
question_18: What does Godfrey confess to Nancy?
answert_18: Godfrey is greatly shaken by the discovery, and it convinces him that all hidden things eventually come to light. Thus, Godfrey goes on to make his own confession, telling Nancy of his secret marriage to Molly and of Eppie's true lineage
question_19: What did Nancy Lammeter represent to Godfrey?
answert_19: To Godfrey, Nancy represented a chance for a future filled with joy, even though, because of his marriage to Molly, he saw no way at present for it to happen. He still held out hope for some sort of miracle.
question_20: How does Molly get revenge on Godfrey?
answert_20: Her addiction to opium, far more than her husband's neglect, is the cause of her present ragged appearance. Nevertheless, she intends to revenge herself on Godfrey by appearing at the dance and revealing that she is his wife.
question_21: What happens in the book Silas Marner?
answert_21: Silas Marner is a tale of love and overcoming setbacks. In the beginning of the novel, the protagonist, Silas, loses his friends, his faith, and his fiancxe9 when he is framed for theft. Exiled, he moves from Lantern Yard to the idyllic English country side of Raveloe, a farming community.
question_22: Who gets married at the end of Silas Marner?
answert_22: Summary and Analysis Part 2: Conclusion Eppie is married on a morning when the lilacs are blooming and the sun is shining. Her gown was provided by Mrs. Godfrey Cass.
question_23: Who dies in Silas Marner?
answert_23: Summary: Chapter 14 Molly is given an anonymous pauper's burial, but her death, the narrator notes, will have great consequences for the inhabitants of Raveloe. The villagers are surprised by Silas's desire to keep the child, and once again they become more sympathetic toward him.
question_24: What is the climax in Silas Marner?
answert_24: climax Eppie appears in Silas's cottage, and he decides to adopt her. falling action When Godfrey fails to claim Eppie as his daughter and marries Nancy, Silas raises Eppie. Silas's love and care for Eppie make him a revered member of the Raveloe community, ending his isolation.
question_25: What has been decided about Dunstan Chapter 15?
answert_25: Dunstan is still missing, which is great for Godfrey: he's turned his life around and has even managed to marry Nancy. Even as he imagines a hearth full of Nancy's children, he promises himself that he won't forget his other child.

answert_15: Makina breaks the stereotypes of the usual qualities and roles that we are used to seeing from female Latino/minorities. question_16: What did Makina do?
answert_16: At home, Makina is in charge of running the Village's switchboard, which requires her to receive, make, and translate calls in three languages (Spanish, English, and her area's Indigenous language).
question_17: Why does Makina cross the border?
answert_17: This lines up with Makina's philosophyher act is crossing the border. She isn't trying to stay in the country. She is just trying to check on her brother.

question_1: What is the symbol for a in Japanese?
answert_1: A (hiragana: u3042, katakana: u30a2) is one of the Japanese kana that each represent one mora. u3042 is based on the sdsho style of kanji u5b89, and u30a2 is from the radical of kanji u963f.
question_2: Do Japanese have zodiac signs?
answert_2: Japanese zodiac signs Japan follows the Chinese astrological system divided into 12 signs (Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Goat, Monkey, Rooster, Dog, Pig). Every year is represented by a different zodiac sign and the related characteristics.
question_3: What is the Japanese sign for love?
answert_3: u611b
question_4: Are signs in Japan in kanji?
answert_4: The road signs in most places in Japan have been standardised, such that any directional signs will typically have both Japanese (typically kanji with kana where appropriate) and English for place names.
question_5: What are the ABC's in Japanese?
answert_5: The Japanese language has three types of characters: Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji.

question_6: What is the significance of federalism?
answert_6: Federalism is the division of power between the national and state governments. The system reserves certain powers for the states, delegates certain powers to the federal government, and allows both the states and the national governments to hold certain powers concurrently.
question_7: Why federalism is an important constitutional principle?

question_16: Why is federalism important to the Constitution?
answert_16: Two important aspects of the U.S. Constitutionfederalism and the separation of powersrepresent, in part, the framers'efforts to divide governmental power. Federalism limits government by creating two sovereign powersthe national government and state governmentsthereby restraining the influence of both.
question_17: Why is the principle of federalism important?
answert_17: Federalism helped to solve the problem. The division of powers between the states and the national government was a kind of compromise, ensuring that states would continue to exercise a great deal of local control even while the new national government would take on more and more responsibilities.
question_18: What is the constitutional principle of federalism?
answert_18: Federalism is the system of government in which sovereignty is constitutionally divided between a central governing authority and constituent political units. It is based upon democratic rules and institutions in which the power to govern is shared between national and state governments, creating a federation.
question_19: What is the most important principle in federalism?
answert_19: Federalism aside, three key principles are the crux of the Constitution: separation of powers, checks and balances, and bicameralism.

question_22: What are the key features of Indian federalism mention three features?
answert_22: Indian federalism is a threefold distribution based on three lists: I Union List on which centre make laws such as defence currency etc.II State List on which state make laws such as police trade agriculture etc. III Concurrent List on which both Centre and State Legislates such as education marriage etc.

answert_23: India is a federal system but with more tilt towards a unitary system of government. question_1: What is the significance of the title to who or to what does it refer?
answert_1: To who or to what does it refer? Solution: The title refers to the great quality boots Mr Gessler made. It is an ideal title for the lesson.
question_2: What is the significance of the title the address?
answert_2: The story 'The Address'is all about the address that the author had received from her mother years ago so that she can reclaim her belongings back after the the war. The whole plot develops from this address of Mrs Dorling 'House no:46 Marconi street'.
question_3: What is significance of the title?
answert_3: The importance of titles. The title of your manuscript is usually the first introduction readers have to your published work. Therefore, you must select a title that grabs attention, accurately describes the contents of your manuscript, and makes people want to read further.
question_4: What is the importance of the title Quality?
answert_4: It gives the lesson about the hard work, compassion, and humility. It also shows the loss and death of a person by ending the story with the death of Mr. Gessler's.
question_5: Do you think Mr Gessler was a failure as a bootmaker or as a competitive businessman?
answert_5: Do you think Mr Gessler was a failure as a bootmaker or as a competitive businessman? Answer: Mr Gessler was successful as a bootmaker because his customers were immensely satisfied with the boot he made. This perfectly fit them and lasted long. Yes, he was a failure as a competitive businessman.

question_1: What is the dramatic significance of the opening scene?
answert_1: The opening scene of Romeo and Juliet is of great dramatic significance for a number of reasons. First of all, there's a lot of action involved, which immediately grabs our attention. This is a very dynamic play with quite a lot going on at any given time, and the opening scene establishes this fundamental dynamism.
question_2: What is the function of the opening scene or scenes of drama Macbeth?
answert_2: Analysis: Act 1, scenes 14. These scenes establish the play's dramatic premisethe witches'awakening of Macbeth's ambitionand present the main characters and their relationships. At the same time, the first three scenes establish a dark mood that permeates the entire play.
question_3: What is the significance of the opening scene in The Tempest?
answert_3: The storm scene that opens The Tempest establishes nature as an important element of the play and emphasizes the role of nature in society.
question_4: What is the significance of the opening scene of Macbeth?
answert_4: The first scene in Macbeth plays a vital role. We as the readers are introduced to the three Witches. The witches were believed to be attendants of the devil who had sold their souls to be given the possession of evil powers. The presence of the witches sets the tone for the rest of the tragic play.
question_5: What is the significance of the opening scene of Julius Caesar?
answert_5: The opening scene is expository. It establishes the time and place and gives the audience an indication of what happened before the play began. It shows the political climate in Rome and the conflict surrounding Caesar
question_6: What is the dramatic significance of Romeo and Juliet opening with a fighting scene?
answert_6: Introduces tension by letting us know what the Prince will do to anyone who fights in the streets again. This will be important later on in Act 3 Scene 1, when Romeo fights Tybalt. We will remember the Prince's words.
question_7: What is the purpose of the opening scene in the play Macbeth?
answert_7: The opening scene of Macbeth not only introduces the audience to the supernatural element that will be carried throughout the play, but it also establishes a theme of disorder through the presence of the witches, the stormy weather, and the bleak landscape.
question_8: What is the importance of the opening scene of the drama?
answert_8: The opening scene provides the audience with a good deal of background information about what is going on, the characters, etc. Characters are introduced, and situations and relationships established.
question_9: How is Macbeth presented in the opening scenes of the play?
answert_9: In the beginning of the play Macbeth is portrayed as a loyal, valiant warrior who it seems would do anything for his King and Country. When we hear There to meet with Macbeth the audience immediately associates Macbeth with this evil.
question_10: What is the importance of the first scene?
answert_10: Your opening shot sets the tone of the rest of your film. It introduces your audience to you. It gives you a chance to touch upon important themes and elements, and apply certain techniques, such as foreshadowing and juxtaposition.
question_11: What is dramatic significance of the storm in the first scene of the play?
answert_11: The storm is both a magical creation of Ariel that sets the entire plot in motion and also the upheaval in the human world that restores the rightful rulership of Naples. Thus the title of the play both works on the literal level, that the plot is what happens in the aftermath of the storm, and on a symbolic level.
question_12: What is the purpose of the opening scene in Macbeth?
answert_12: The opening scene of Macbeth not only introduces the audience to the supernatural element that will be carried throughout the play, but it also establishes a theme of disorder through the presence of the witches, the stormy weather, and the bleak landscape.
question_13: What is the purpose of the first scene in Act 1 of Macbeth?
answert_13: Literally, the witches are deciding when they shall meet again. This scene sets the mood for the entire play, and introduces several major motifs: the witches (supernatural influences in the play), the idea of fair being foul, and the stormy fate of Scotland.
question_14: What does the opening scene foreshadow in Julius Caesar?
answert_14: Caesar's visit foreshadows Brutus's death by suggesting that Brutus will join him in the afterworld. In addition to Brutus's death, Cassius, another one of the conspirators, sees birds circling his troops. In Act 5, Scene 1, Cassius says the birds 'Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us /As we were sickly prey.
question_15: What is the significance of the closing scene in Julius Caesar?
answert_15: Despite their celebration of Brutus's honor, the two men still implicitly condemn the murder to which Brutus's commitment to Rome led him. The play's ending is therefore ambivalent, meaning that it registers mixed feelings about what has come to pass. For anyone who knows Roman history, the ending also proves ironic.
question_16: What do the opening scene of Act Five foreshadow about the resolution of the tragedy of Julius Caesar?
answert_16: What do the opening scenes of act 5 foreshadow about the resolution of The Tragedy of Julius Caesar? Brutus and Cassius will be victorious over Octavius and Mark Antony's army; because Octavius and Mark Antony took over the tyranny after Caesar, they will die during the battle.
question_17: What is the significance of the opening scene of Romeo and Juliet?
answert_17: The opening scene of Romeo and Juliet is effective because it's full of humour and violence. These two characteristics are powerful on their own, but together they make the first scene witty and dramatic. The opening scene is important as it sets the whole atmosphere of the families on going feud.
question_18: Why do you think that Shakespeare chose to start play with a fight scene?
answert_18: To show just how deep the family feud between the Capulets in the Montagues actually run- Servants who have no family ties to either house fight for the house that they serve. The townspeople choose a side to join in the fight
question_19: What is the dramatic effect of having two servants start the fight Romeo and Juliet?
answert_19: The Impact of the Opening Quarrel between the Servants in Romeo and Juliet. whole effect is one of ignorance and increasing unrest. between Tybalt and Benvolio.
question_20: What is the dramatic significance of the opening scene in the play Tempest?
answert_20: The main dramatic part of Shakespeare's play is in this opening scene because it challenges all theatrical convention. Nature does not care for social hierarchy and overrules this and the boatswain alerts the others on board by saying, 'When the sea is. Hence!
question_21: What is the purpose of the opening scene of Macbeth?
answert_21: The opening scene of Macbeth not only introduces the audience to the supernatural element that will be carried throughout the play, but it also establishes a theme of disorder through the presence of the witches, the stormy weather, and the bleak landscape.
question_22: What is the purpose of the opening scene of the play?
answert_22: The opening scene is meant to create a certain impact on the audience, perhaps to shock them, or keep them gripped, perhaps through the creation of tension. The opening scene provides the audience with a good deal of background information about what is going on, the characters, etc.
question_23: What is the importance of the opening scene?
answert_23: Your opening shot sets the tone of the rest of your film. It introduces your audience to you. It gives you a chance to touch upon important themes and elements, and apply certain techniques, such as foreshadowing and juxtaposition.

question_25: What does opening mean in drama?

question_1: Why is the handkerchief so important to Othello quizlet?
answert_1: Terms in this set (5) Because Othello gave it to Desdemona as a first gift, the handkerchief functions as a token of his love, which Desdemona cherishes (3.3. 1). The handkerchief symbolizes Desdemona's fidelity. When it shows up in Cassio's possession, Othello is convinced that Desdemona is unfaithful.
question_2: How does the handkerchief function in Act 4 Why is the handkerchief so important to Othello?
answert_2: Why is the handkerchief so important to Othello? In Act IV the handkerchief is used by Iago to almost represent Desdemona. Because this handkerchief is so important to Othello, it is the perfect thing to use to symbolize Desdemona's love.
question_3: What is the significance of the handkerchief to Othello How was it responsible for Desdemona's death?
answert_3: The handkerchief symbolizes Othello's love and trust to Desdemona and Desdemona's marital fidelity to Othello. To put him to ill thinking. Desdemona is concerned over the loss of the handkerchief but maintains that its loss will not cause Othello to grow angry.
question_4: What is the importance of the handkerchief in Othello Act 3?
answert_4: The handkerchief, a gift to Desdemona from Othello, symbolizes so much more than a mere token of affection. To Othello, the handkerchief symbolizes fidelity and his giving it to Desdemona represents a promise that he will be true to her, and a request that she stay true to him.
question_5: Why is the handkerchief important to Othello?
answert_5: The handkerchief, a gift to Desdemona from Othello, symbolizes so much more than a mere token of affection. To Othello, the handkerchief symbolizes fidelity and his giving it to Desdemona represents a promise that he will be true to her, and a request that she stay true to him.
question_6: Why is the handkerchief that Desdemona has lost so important to Othello Scene 4?
answert_6: More immediately, to Othello the handkerchief represents Desdemona's chastity, and her giving it away is a sign that she has given her body away.
question_7: What is the function of the handkerchief in this act?
answert_7: The handkerchief, which belonged to Othello's mother and was given to Desdemona as a love token, becomes extremely important in the second half of the play when Iago decides to use it to serve his scheme. When Desdemona drops the handkerchief after trying to mop Othello's forehead with it, it is Emilia who picks it up.
question_8: What was the significance of the handkerchief to Othello and Desdemona?

question_9: Why is the handkerchief that Desdemona has lost so important to Othello What does Cassio do with the handkerchief he found?

Othello's mother gave him the magic handkerchief on her deathbed, instructing him to give it to the woman he desired to marry
question_10: What is the significance of Desdemona's death?
answert_10: Desdemona is innocence personified, and by killing her character, Shakespeare makes a cynical commentary about how innocence cannot survive in the fallen world.
question_11: What is the importance of the handkerchief in Othello?
answert_11: The handkerchief initially is a gift given to Desdemona by Othello as a love token. It is subsequently symbolically transformed into Desdemona's bedsheets, which she uses to reveal her true innocence and fidelity to Othello; and finally, Desdemona requests that the bedsheets be used to cover her as a death shroud.

question_13: How is the handkerchief a prominent symbol in Act 3?

question_14: Who has the handkerchief at the end of Act III Why?

It is subsequently symbolically transformed into Desdemona's bedsheets, which she uses to reveal her true innocence and fidelity to Othello; and finally, Desdemona requests that the bedsheets be used to cover her as a death shroud.
question_18: How does the handkerchief function in Act 4?
answert_18: An Egyptian sorceress gave it to his mother and told her that it would make her desirable and keep Othello's father loyal, but if she lost it or gave it away, Othello's father would leave her. Othello's mother gave him the magic handkerchief on her deathbed, instructing him to give it to the woman he desired to marry
question_19: How does the handkerchief function in Act IV?
answert_19: In Act IV, the handkerchief falls to the ground and Iago picks it up; this is showing that love is lost and that now Iago is in control of manipulating Othello's feelings. Why is the handkerchief so important to Othello? The handkerchief represents Othello's love for Desdemona.
question_20: Why is a handkerchief so important in Act III?
answert_20: As a charmed gift given to Othello by his mother, the handkerchief represents Othello's mysterious and exotic heritage, a heritage that he has repudiated as a Christian and Venetian citizen.
question_21: What is the importance of the handkerchief in Iago's plot?
answert_21: The handkerchief is significant to the plot, mainly to Iago's manipulation of Othello and his convincing the latter of Desdemona's infidelity. Moreover, it sheds light over Iago, Desdemona, Othello and Emilia's characters, and is thus important to characterisation.
question_22: What is the role of the handkerchief in the play Othello?
answert_22: The handkerchief initially is a gift given to Desdemona by Othello as a love token. It is subsequently symbolically transformed into Desdemona's bedsheets, which she uses to reveal her true innocence and fidelity to Othello; and finally, Desdemona requests that the bedsheets be used to cover her as a death shroud.
question_23: What was the significance of the handkerchief in Othello?
answert_23: The handkerchief initially is a gift given to Desdemona by Othello as a love token. It is subsequently symbolically transformed into Desdemona's bedsheets, which she uses to reveal her true innocence and fidelity to Othello; and finally, Desdemona requests that the bedsheets be used to cover her as a death shroud.
question_24: What does Othello tell Desdemona is so special about the handkerchief he gave her?
answert_24: The handkerchief symbolizes Othello's love and trust to Desdemona and Desdemona's marital fidelity to Othello. To put him to ill thinking. Desdemona is concerned over the loss of the handkerchief but maintains that its loss will not cause Othello to grow angry.
question_25: What does Cassio do with Desdemona's handkerchief?
answert_25: Cassio gives Bianca Desdemona's handkerchief, which he found in his lodgings (Iago had placed it there) and asks her to make a copy of it for him, as he will have to return the original when he finds the owner.

question_1: What carries the message across the synapse?
answert_1: The axon carries messages away from the cell body. Usually, there is a small gap between the two cells. This gap is called a synapse. Chemicals released by the axon carry messages across the synapse to the dendrites of the next neuron.
question_2: How does the signal cross the synapse between neurons?
answert_2: An electrical impulse travels down the axon of a neuron and then triggers the release of tiny vesicles containing neurotransmitters. These vesicles will then bind to the membrane of the presynaptic cell, releasing the neurotransmitters into the synapse.
question_3: How do messages travel across a synapse?
answert_3:
Synapses
  • An electrical nerve impulse travels along the first axon.
  • When the nerve impulse reaches the dendrites at the end of the axon, chemical messengers called neurotransmitters are released.
  • These chemicals diffuse across the synapse (the gap between the two neurons).
question_4: What flows across the synapse?
answert_4: The Synapse. Neurons have specialized projections called dendrites and axons. Dendrites bring information to the cell body and axons take information away from the cell body. Information from one neuron flows to another neuron across a synapse.
question_5: How do signals cross the synapse?
answert_5: When the nerve impulse reaches the dendrites at the end of the axon, chemical messengers called neurotransmitters are released. These chemicals diffuse across the synapse (the gap between the two neurons). The signal therefore has been carried from one neuron to the next.
question_6: How do messages cross the synapse between neurons?
answert_6: When neurons communicate, an electrical impulse triggers the release of neurotransmitters from the axon into the synapse. The neurotransmitters cross the synapse and bind to special molecules on the other side, called receptors. Receptors receive and process the message.

question_1: What is the moral of the Sign of the Beaver?
answert_1: Summary: The Sign of the Beaver is about a young boy who becomes friends with a Native American and they grow into manhood with each other. I would say that both friendship and survival are the two major themes in this book. Matt must survive on his own using the skills taught to him by his father.
question_2: What is the Sign of the Beaver and why is it important?
answert_2: Literally speaking, the sign of the beaver is a scratched pattern the Beaver clan uses to mark their territory. Symbolically, though, it lets other clans know not to hunt on the land it marks.
question_3: Is the Sign of the Beaver a true story?
answert_3: The Sign of the Beaver was inspired by a true story dating from 1802 and documented in a history of the small town of Milo, Maine; in it, a teenage boy left to care for his family's cabin was helped by the local Natives when his supplies were ravaged by a bear.
question_4: Why Is Sign of the Beaver called Sign of the Beaver?
answert_4: The sign of the beaver represents the clan that Attean and Saknis come from. So while it is literally a simple drawing found on trees, as a title it references how important getting to know Attean and Saknis is for Matt.
question_5: What is the lesson of the Sign of the Beaver?
answert_5: Left alone to guard the family's wilderness home in eighteenth-century Maine, Matt is hard-pressed to survive until neighboring Indians teach him their skills. This is a timeless story of courage, commitment, friendship, values, and overcoming cultural divides
question_6: What is the main problem in the Sign of the Beaver?
answert_6: Being left alone in the Maine wilderness was a big problem for Matt because he was lonely and didn't really know how to take care of himself. Another conflict was trying to gain Attean's friendship and respect. With Attean's help, Matt eventually learned how to survive on his own.
question_7: Is the book Sign of the Beaver a true story?
answert_7: The Sign of the Beaver was inspired by a true story dating from 1802 and documented in a history of the small town of Milo, Maine; in it, a teenage boy left to care for his family's cabin was helped by the local Natives when his supplies were ravaged by a bear.
question_8: What is the lesson of Sign of the Beaver?
answert_8: Left alone to guard the family's wilderness home in eighteenth-century Maine, Matt is hard-pressed to survive until neighboring Indians teach him their skills. This is a timeless story of courage, commitment, friendship, values, and overcoming cultural divides

answert_19: Matt can't even grill up a crow or two for fear of wasting his gunpowder trying to hit them, and he tries to combat the pesky birds by staying up all night and sleeping during the day. It's an epic failure and the fire goes out.
question_20: What happened in the Sign of the Beaver?
answert_20: The Sign of the Beaver is a historical fiction novel about a boy left alone in the wilderness of Maine for an entire summer. He survives with the help of the Native Americans, who teach him many things. The book was written by Elizabeth George Speare, a two-time Newbery Medal winner.
question_21: Why was Matt feeling uneasy in the Sign of the Beaver?

question_24: What did Attean teach Matt in The Sign of the Beaver?
answert_24: One of the first lessons he teaches Matt is how to build a snare, and next, how to make his own fishing hooks from roots. Through Attean's guidance Matt is able to learn that there are other ways of doing things beyond 'the white man's way'. Matt is often impressed with Attean's knowledge and his sense of independence.
question_25: What is the meaning of the sign of the beaver?
answert_25: Literally speaking, the sign of the beaver is a scratched pattern the Beaver clan uses to mark their territory. It's the equivalent of a no trespassing sign on someone's property, and Indians from other clans get the message loud and clear when they see it.

question_1: What is the role of signal man?
answert_1: A signalman or signaller is an employee of a railway transport network who operates the points and signals from a signal box in order to control the movement of trains.
question_2: What is the summary of The Signal-Man by Charles Dickens?
answert_2: The Story. 'The Signal-Man'(1866) is a short story by the English writer Charles Dickens (1812-1870). In the story, a practical-minded narrator meets a railway worker who has been seeing supernatural visions. The narrator doubts the man at first, but at the story's conclusion a strange event makes him a believer.
question_3: How does The Signal-Man end?
answert_3: In a moment, however, he realizes that there are other men around him, and that the figure is a railroad worker. Climbing down the steep cliff into the dusky bowels of the cutting, he sees a corpse covered in a sheet and is crushed to learn that the signalman was just killed by a passing train
question_4: What's the definition of signalman?
answert_4: Definition of signalman : a person who signals or works with signals (as on a railway)
question_5: What are the roles and responsibilities of a signaller?
answert_5: Role of a Signaller Signallers operate railway signals or points to monitor train motion or course. They ensure the trains are running quickly and responsibly. Relaying this data to other control centers, signal stations, or level crossing agents ensures that trains safely transition from one route segment to another.
question_6: How much do Signallers earn?
answert_6: The average Slinger signaller salary is xa338,621. This is 10.7% above the national average advertised salary of xa334,899. Most Slinger signaller job ads are for Trade Construction Jobs and Engineering Jobs.
question_7: What is the theme of The Signal-Man?
answert_7: A major theme in ''The Signal-Man''is responsibility. The signalman is haunted not only by his own future ghost but by his duty to protect train passengers, conductors, and other crewmen on his line.
question_8: What is the setting in The Signal-Man?
answert_8: Time setting The story The Signal-Man by Charles Dickens takes place in and around a cabin station of a railway signalman, next to the entrance to a tunnel. The action spans over a couple of nights, from the time the narrator meets the signal-man up to his death.
question_9: How does the narrator describe The Signal-Man?
answert_9: The narrator describes that the signalman seems like a dutiful employee at all times, except when he twice looks at his signal bell when it is not ringing.
question_10: Who is the narrator in The Signal-Man?
answert_10: The unnamed narrator, a cheerful and logical man, befriends the signalman at the start of the story.
question_11: How was the signal man killed?
answert_11: The narrator discovers that the signalman is dead, having been struck by an oncoming train. He had been standing on the line, looking intently at something, and failed to get out of the way.
question_12: What happened at the end of the story the signalman Were you happy with the climax of you had to change the end how would you do it?
answert_12: Towards the end of the story, however, when the narrator returns to the signal box on the night following this disclosure, he is taken by surpriseoppressed by a nameless horror at the sight of a man passionately waving his right arm under the danger light, exactly as the signalman described.
question_13: What happens in the signal man story?
answert_13: In the story, the unnamed narrator befriends a railroad signalman at his lonely post outside a tunnel. The signalman confides that he is being haunted by a ghost. The apparition warned him on two previous occasions of impending tragedies; a horrible accident and a sudden death of a passenger.
question_14: What is the plot and conflict in the signalman?
answert_14: He lives in a world that would reject supernatural explanations, and yet in his own life, he is confronted with a reality that can only be explained by an appeal to the supernatural. His entire story is unbelievable (something which he is well aware of).
question_15: What is the job of signalman?
answert_15: A signalman or signaller is an employee of a railway transport network who operates the points and signals from a signal box in order to control the movement of trains.
question_16: What does signaling someone mean?
answert_16: A signal is a gesture, sound, or action which is intended to give a particular message to the person who sees or hears it. If you signal to someone, you make a gesture or sound in order to send them a particular message.
question_17: What did a signalman do in ww2?
answert_17: The signalman was to be in charge of the communications between the front lines and the headquarters and every branch of the services was recorded and returned back or communicated back to, you know, whatever areas where it was necessary.
question_18: Does the Navy still have signalman?
answert_18: The U.S. Navy disestablished the rating of Signalman in late 2003, reassigning visual communications duties to the Quartermaster rating. Signalmen were either absorbed into the Quartermaster rating, or allowed to switch to other job fields in the Navy.
question_19: What is the role of the signaller?
answert_19: A signalman or signaller is an employee of a railway transport network who operates the points and signals from a signal box in order to control the movement of trains.
question_20: What do you need to be a signaller?
answert_20:
THE SKILLS AND QUALITIES REQUIRED TO BECOME A RAILWAY SIGNALLER
  • Excellent awareness of safety (being safety conscious).
  • Outstanding communication skills.
  • Capable of concentrating for long periods of time.
  • Able to work alone, often unsupervised.
  • Willing to learn and retain large amounts of job-specific information.
question_21: What does a Grade 7 signaller do?
answert_21: Job Introduction Our signallers help us do this by overseeing train movements, protecting maintenance work and managing other unexpected issues to ensure the safety of the line through the control of the signalling equipment and communications with train drivers through specialist lineside equipment.
question_22: What does a Grade 9 signaller do?
answert_22: Decision Making - By its nature, the signaller role requires you to make safety critical decisions throughout the course of your shift. You will be reacting to planned and business as usual activity but will also experience unusual and unfamiliar situations which you have to manage.
question_23: How much do Signallers get paid UK?
answert_23: The average salary for a Signaller is xa335,379 per year in United Kingdom, which is 14% lower than the average Network Rail salary of xa341,365 per year for this job.
question_24: Is a signaller a good job?
answert_24: Decent pay BUT Varied work day, dealing with all sorts of operating incidents, generally using interesting equipment, often while fitting engineering work round a busy train service. A serious job where mistakes are generally unrecoverable - but in quiet spells you'll get a chance to enjoy some banter.
question_25: What is the salary of a signalman?
answert_25: Salary range for the majority of workers in Railway brake, signal and switch operators - from u20b98,291 to u20b941,707 per month - 2022. A Railway brake, signal and switch operators typically earns between u20b98,291 and u20b917,155 net per month at the start of the job.

question_1: What does the sigmoid curve indicates?
answert_1: A sigmoid growth curve indicates that the living organism is growing in a natural environment.
question_2: What is a sigmoid growth curve called?
answert_2: If we plot the increase in cell number (growth rate) against time, a typical S-shaped curve is obtained. This has been called as the growth curve or sigmoid growth curve by Sachs (1873) as the shape of the curve obtained was sigmoid.
question_3: Why is sigmoidal curve obtained?
answert_3: A sigmoid curve is obtained when percentage saturation of haemoglobin with O2 is plotted against the P O2 .
question_4: What is the sigmoid growth curve called?

question_5: Why is a sigmoid curve so called?
answert_5: Population development declines with logistic growth as resources become limited. It falls off when the environment's carrying capacity is exhausted, resulting in an S-shaped curve.
question_6: How do you describe a sigmoidal curve?
answert_6: an S-shaped curve that describes many processes in psychology, including learning and responding to test items. The curve starts low, has a period of acceleration, and then approaches an asymptote. Often, the curve is characterized by the logistic function.
question_7: What does the sigmoid growth curve indicate?
answert_7: A sigmoid growth curve indicates that the living organism is growing in a natural environment.
question_8: What is the name of a growth curve?
answert_8: There are four distinct phases of the growth curve: lag, exponential (log), stationary, and death. The initial phase is the lag phase where bacteria are metabolically active but not dividing. The exponential or log phase is a time of exponential growth.
question_9: Why is sigmoid curve important?

question_1: What is Sigmund Freud Civilization and Its Discontents summary?
answert_1: A brooding book that sounds the death knell for optimistic views on humanity's progress through civilization, Civilization and its Discontents begins with a recapitulation of Freud's disdainful views on religion as a psychological salve and then goes on to challenge enduring platitudes about human society: that
question_2: What is Freud's theory about civilization and misery?
answert_2: Paradox: Civilization, although its purpose would seem to be amelioration of human misery and suffering, is actually partially responsible for that suffering, according to Freud. This explains our subliminal hostility toward civilization.
question_3: Why is civilization and its discontents important?
answert_3: Civilization and Its Discontents is one of th. It is both witness and tribute to the late theory of mindthe so-called structural theory, with its stress on aggression, indeed the death drive, as the pitiless adversary of eros. Man, by nature aggressive and egotistical, seeks self-satisfaction.
question_4: What is the relationship between human happiness and civilization in Freud's view?
answert_4: Each of us is born into a threatening world and we seek to avoid pain and gain pleasure. Thus, on Freud's view, the birth of civilization is rooted in egoism -- each of us striving in an often hostile world, to create the greatest amount of personal happiness and avoid pain as best we can.
question_5: What is Freud telling us in his work Civilization and Its Discontents?
answert_5: In 1930, Sigmund Freud wrote Civilization and Its Discontents and laid out his theory of civilization: civilization's a problem, and it makes us unhappy. Freud felt humans were aggressive creatures by nature, that we delight in exercising our aggression and hurting one another.
question_6: What is Freud's assessment of civilization?
answert_6: 2) Freud conceives of civilizationin parallel to his conception of the individual psycheas a product of the struggle between these two fundamental instincts. Civilization itself, thus, is conflicted, the product of antagonistic drives and impulses.
question_7: What is the summary of civilization?
answert_7: A civilization is a complex human society, usually made up of different cities, with certain characteristics of cultural and technological development. In many parts of the world, early civilizations formed when people began coming together in urban settlements.
question_8: What did Freud say about civilization?
answert_8: In the book, Freud proposes that civilization is a way for individual human beings to deal with his violent and destructive nature. Freud argues that civilization emanates from the superego. He argues that man's drive to be civilized comes from the superego that is driven by guilt and remorse.
question_9: What is the point Freud is making about why civilization makes us unhappy?
answert_9: As the title of the book suggests, Freud addresses the question of why civilization seems to make us so unhappy. According to Freud, the reason why civilization fills us with discontent is because it restricts our individual freedom. In particular, civilization forces us to give up our natural aggressiveness.
question_10: What is Freud's main theory?
answert_10: In 1930, Sigmund Freud wrote Civilization and Its Discontents and laid out his theory of civilization: civilization's a problem, and it makes us unhappy. Freud felt humans were aggressive creatures by nature, that we delight in exercising our aggression and hurting one another.
question_11: What is the main point of civilization and its discontents?
answert_11: A brooding book that sounds the death knell for optimistic views on humanity's progress through civilization, Civilization and its Discontents begins with a recapitulation of Freud's disdainful views on religion as a psychological salve and then goes on to challenge enduring platitudes about human society: that
question_12: What is Freud's main idea in Civilization and Its Discontent?
answert_12: In the book, Freud proposes that civilization is a way for individual human beings to deal with his violent and destructive nature. Freud argues that civilization emanates from the superego. He argues that man's drive to be civilized comes from the superego that is driven by guilt and remorse.
question_13: What did Freud say about happiness?
answert_13: Freud suggested that we should seek happiness through love and through work. His opinion was that satisfying love relationships and creative, productive work hold the most value for the person who seeks to be happy. This accords well with the findings of the positive psychologists from the past few years.
question_14: What does Freud say about civilization?
answert_14: In the book, Freud proposes that civilization is a way for individual human beings to deal with his violent and destructive nature. Freud argues that civilization emanates from the superego. He argues that man's drive to be civilized comes from the superego that is driven by guilt and remorse.
question_15: What does Freud think about the relationship between human nature and civilization?
answert_15: Freud suggested that much of human behaviour is controlled by forces outside our awareness and the relationship between a person and society is controlled by primitive urges buried deep within our unconscious.
question_16: How does Sigmund Freud view humanity and human nature according to his writings in Civilization and Its Discontents?
answert_16: In 1930, Sigmund Freud wrote Civilization and Its Discontents and laid out his theory of civilization: civilization's a problem, and it makes us unhappy. Freud felt humans were aggressive creatures by nature, that we delight in exercising our aggression and hurting one another.
question_17: What is civilization simple words?
answert_17: Civilization (or civilisation) comes from the Latin word civis meaning someone who lives in a town. A civilization is generally an advanced stage of organization. That means it has laws, culture, a regular way of getting food and protecting the people.
question_18: What is civilization explain with example?
answert_18: The definition of civilization refers to a society or group of people or the process of achieving a higher state of social development. An example of civilization is the Mesopotamian civilization. An example of civilization is an industrial society that has arts, sciences, and machines such as cars. noun. 2.
question_19: What is the purpose of civilization?
answert_19: Civilization allows people to live at a degree above the survival level. It gives them leisure to create things. It provides a place in society for people who would otherwise not have such by creating specializations.
question_20: What is world civilization?
answert_20: 1. An advanced state of intellectual, cultural, and material development in human society, marked by progress in the arts and sciences, the extensive use of record-keeping, including writing, and the appearance of complex political and social institutions.
question_21: What is Freud saying in Civilization and Its Discontents?
answert_21: In 1930, Sigmund Freud wrote Civilization and Its Discontents and laid out his theory of civilization: civilization's a problem, and it makes us unhappy. Freud felt humans were aggressive creatures by nature, that we delight in exercising our aggression and hurting one another.
question_22: What does Freud think is a threat to civilization?
answert_22: If you remember Freud 1929 essay from when you didn't read it in college, the father of psychoanalysis argued that aggression is not only humanity's natural instinct but that this inclination to aggression constitutes the greatest impediment to civilization.
question_23: Why does Freud argue that civilization causes individual unhappiness in modern society?
answert_23: Freud views civilization as a way which modern man deals with the extremities of realities. Despite this fact, civilization brings man a lot of grief. Consequently, Freud argues that the reason for most mental illness is man's inability to deal with the realities of civilized society

question_1: What are some character traits about Matt from a Sign of the Beaver?
answert_1: Initially, Matt alternates between feeling lonely and feeling glad to be in charge of himself, which is quite understandable for a twelve year old in his situation! Matt shows his youth when he trusts a wanderer named Ben. Allowing the stranger to share his dinner and sleep in his cabin, Matt makes himself vulnerable.
question_2: Is the Sign of the Beaver a true story?
answert_2: The Sign of the Beaver was inspired by a true story dating from 1802 and documented in a history of the small town of Milo, Maine; in it, a teenage boy left to care for his family's cabin was helped by the local Natives when his supplies were ravaged by a bear.
question_3: What is Matt's sisters name in Sign of the Beaver?
answert_3: sister Marie
question_4: What does Attean look like in Sign of the Beaver?
answert_4: During this interaction, Attean is described as having 'black eyes that held no expression whatsoever. 'He wears a breechcloth around his waist and has black hair the length of his shoulders. This Indian boy couldn't be more different from Matt.
question_5: What is Matt like in Sign of the Beaver?
answert_5: Initially, Matt alternates between feeling lonely and feeling glad to be in charge of himself, which is quite understandable for a twelve year old in his situation! Matt shows his youth when he trusts a wanderer named Ben. Allowing the stranger to share his dinner and sleep in his cabin, Matt makes himself vulnerable.
question_6: How are Matt and Attean different?
answert_6: Matt/Attean Matt and Attean start out as opposites. One is a white boy who doesn't trust Indians, and the other is an Indian who doesn't trust white folks. It's a pretty major difference, to say the least.
question_7: How old is Matt in Sign of the Beaver?
answert_7: The Sign of the Beaver tells the story of 13-year-old Matthew James Matt Hallowell, an 18th-century American settler.
question_8: What Did Matt make for his sister?
answert_8: He makes some wooden dishes for his mother, a cradle for the baby, and a doll for his sister Sarah. While making the doll, he thinks about Sarah and then about Attean's sister, Marie.
question_9: Is the Sign of the Beaver fiction or nonfiction?
answert_9: The Sign of the Beaver is a children's historical novel by American author Elizabeth George Speare, which has won numerous literary awards.
question_10: What happened to Matt's family Sign of the Beaver?
answert_10: Lesson Summary In Chapter 25 of The Sign of the Beaver, Matt, the novel's protagonist is finally reunited with his family members, who have been delayed due to a bout with typhus (an infectious disease).
question_11: What happened to Atteans mother Sign of the Beaver?
answert_11: like the fact that Attean and his sister are orphans, thanks to the brutality of white men who shot his mother as a trophy and killed his father when he sought revenge. Matt's white; Attean is American Indian.
question_12: What is the Sign of the Beaver and why is it important?
answert_12: Literally speaking, the sign of the beaver is a scratched pattern the Beaver clan uses to mark their territory. Symbolically, though, it lets other clans know not to hunt on the land it marks.
question_13: What is Matt's sister name?

question_17: Why did Attean give Matt his dog?
answert_17: Matt's not so surehe's heard plenty about the open land in the westbut before he says anything, Attean surprises him with another gift: his dog. He goes into the cabin to find a gift for Attean, but the only thing worth enough to Matt to be worthy to give is the watch his father gave him.
question_18: How does Attean feel about his dog?
answert_18: Attean's Dog The dog is a mangy old thing--ugly and surly, and it most decidedly does not like Matt! The dog always growls at him and it won't let Matt touch it. Attean teaches Matt his word for dog: 'aremus'. Attean tells Matt with pride that the dog is useless at hunting and will fight anything that moves.
question_19: What tribe is Attean from Sign of the Beaver?
answert_19: Penobscot Indians
