question_1: What is the meaning of the word shrike?
answert_1: Definition of shrike : any of numerous usually largely gray or brownish oscine birds (family Laniidae) that have a hooked bill, feed chiefly on insects, and often impale their prey on thorns.
question_2: Why are shrikes called shrikes?
answert_2: because of their feeding habits.Shrike.ShrikesOrder:PasseriformesSuperfamily:CorvoideaFamily:Laniidae Rafinesque, 1815Genera7 more rows
question_3: What is shrike known as?
answert_3: Taxonomy. The genus name, Lanius, is derived from the Latin word for butcher, and some shrikes are also known as butcher birds because of their feeding habits. The common English name shrike is from Old English scrxedc, shriek, referring to the shrill call.
question_4: Are shrikes rare?
answert_4: Shrikes are rare among songbirds for their lifestyle of hunting and eating animals.
question_5: What does the name shrike mean?
answert_5: Shrikes (/rau026ak/) are carnivorous passerine birds of the family Laniidae. The family name, and that of the largest genus, Lanius, is derived from the Latin word for butcher, and some shrikes are also known as butcherbirds because of their feeding habits.
question_6: Is there a bird called a shrike?
answert_6: Northern and loggerhead shrikes are just two of the 33 shrike species worldwide. Their family name, Laniidae, is derived from the Latin word for butcher, and shrikes are also known as butcherbirds. Most of the 33 species are found in Eurasia and Africa; there are just 2 in North America and one in New Guinea.
question_7: Where are shrikes from?
answert_7: Shrikes are predatory songbirds, with bills adapted for killing prey. Most members of the family are found in Eurasia and Africa, but two are resident in North America. These solitary birds perch in conspicuous spots on top of fence posts, on wires, and in trees and shrubs.
question_8: How many shrikes are there?
answert_8: 33 species
question_9: How did the loggerhead shrike get its name?
answert_9: Loggerhead Shrikes have several distinguishing characteristics including a mean-looking hooked beak and a black facial mask but it's their very large head that gave them their common name. In the 16th century a logger was a large block of wood for hobbling a horse.
question_10: What is a group of shrikes called?
answert_10: The species name of the Northern Shrike, Lanius excubitor, means, Butcher watchman. Their nest is so deep that while incubating, all that can be seen of the female is the tip of her tail. A group of shrikes are collectively known as an abattoir and a watch of shrikes
question_11: Do all shrikes impale their prey?
answert_11: Both species regularly impale prey often still alive on spikes, thorns, or barbed wire, and leave them there for days or weeks. We dive into the fascinating story behind shrikes and their grisly table manners.

answert_15: No, shrikes do not make good pets. They are wild birds, and need lots of space to hunt and stretch their wings. Additionally, in many areas it is illegal to own a shrike as a pet
question_16: Where can I find shrikes?
answert_16: Find This Bird Northern Shrikes breed in the remote north, so it's best to look for them in winter, when they may come as far south as Utah or Pennsylvania. They occur in open but brushy habitats, and on calm, sunny days they may sit up on utility wires, bushes, and trees.
question_17: Is the great GREY Shrike rare?
answert_17: Great grey shrikes are regular but scarce visitors to the UK. They arrive, on the east coast at first, in autumn and many stay throughout winter and into spring (sometimes as late as April or May), when they migrate back to their breeding grounds in Scandinavia.

question_22: What happens when shout?
answert_22: Shouting will make them tune out and discipline will be harder, since each time you raise your voice lowers their receptivity. question_23: What happens if we shout more?

question_24: What happens when you shout at a child?

question_25: Is it normal to shout?

question_1: What is the first chapter of Tom Sawyer about?
answert_1: SummaryChapter 1: Tom Plays, Fights, and Hides The novel opens with Aunt Polly scouring the house in search of her nephew, Tom Sawyer. She finds him in the closet, discovers that his hands are covered with jam, and prepares to give him a whipping.
question_2: What is the short summary of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer?
answert_2: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'Summary. Tom Sawyer is a young boy living with his Aunt Polly on the banks of the Mississippi River. He seems to most enjoy getting into trouble.After missing school one day (and getting into a fight), Tom is punished with the task of whitewashing a fence.
question_3: What does the first chapter tells you about Tom character?
answert_3: Tom's character is very well established in the first chapter. He is wealthy, arrogant, condescending, unfaithful to his wife, and really not very smart. Tom tries to discuss a book he has read recently (Daisy is amazed he has actually read a book), and his comments show that he doesn't understand it particularly well.
question_4: Why does Tom get into a fight in CH 1?
answert_4: Tom picks a fight with him to show the new boy that he is the boss in the town. This might be because Tom was feeling threatened by the new boy and also slightly jealous of his fancy clothes.
question_5: What does the beginning of the story reveal about little Tom?
answert_5: Tom's character is very well established in the first chapter. He is wealthy, arrogant, condescending, unfaithful to his wife, and really not very smart. Tom tries to discuss a book he has read recently (Daisy is amazed he has actually read a book), and his comments show that he doesn't understand it particularly well.
question_6: Why does Tom fight at the end of Chapter 1?
answert_6: The opening of the story tells us that Tom Sawyer is a bit of a troublemaker. We can reasonably infer this because, in this scene, the young lad is hiding from his Aunt Polly in a closet with jam all over his hands; it would seem that Tom has been sneaking into the pantry.

question_1: What is a shortened sentence?
answert_1: Truncated sentences are often referred to as short sentences, but there is a difference between short sentences and truncated sentences. A truncated sentence has to have been cut short there need to be words missing. For example: I like reading I like reading more than Diane [does]
question_2: What is shortening a sentence called?
answert_2: An abbreviation is a shortening of a word or a phrase. An acronym is an abbreviation that forms a word. An initialism is an abbreviation that uses the first letter of each word in the phrase (thus, some but not all initialisms are acronyms).
question_3: How do you shorten a wordy sentence?
answert_3:
Together, these changes create a stronger, more concise sentence.
  • Use the Key Noun.
  • Use Active Voice rather than Passive Voice Verbs.
  • Avoid Unnecessary Language.
  • Use Nouns rather than Vague Pronouns as Subjects.
  • Use Verbs rather than Nouns to Express Action.
  • Avoid a String of Prepositional Phrases.
question_4: What is shortening in writing?

question_1: What are short prepositions?
answert_1: A preposition is a word or group of words used before a noun, pronoun, or noun phrase to show direction, time, place, location, spatial relationships, or to introduce an object. Some examples of prepositions are words like in, at, on, of, and to.
question_2: What are the 4 types of preposition?
answert_2:
There are five different types of prepositions:
  • Simple prepositions.
  • Double prepositions.
  • Compound prepositions.
  • Participle prepositions.
  • Phrase prepositions.
question_3: What are the 10 prepositions?
answert_3: A preposition usually precedes a noun or a pronoun. Here is a list of commonly used prepositions: above, across, against, along, among, around, at, before, behind, below, beneath, beside, between, by, down, from, in, into, near, of, off, on, to, toward, under, upon, with and within
question_4: What are the 3 types of prepositions?

  • Double Preposition. When a preposition consists of more than one word, it is called double preposition.
  • Compound Preposition.
  • Participle Preposition.
  • Disguised Prepositions.
  • Phrase Prepositions.

question_1: What is the difference between long and short run economic growth?
answert_1: Short run where one factor of production (e.g. capital) is fixed. This is a time period of fewer than four-six months. Very long run Where all factors of production are variable, and additional factors outside the control of the firm can change, e.g. technology, government policy.
question_2: Is economic growth a short term process?
answert_2: economic growth, the process by which a nation's wealth increases over time. Although the term is often used in discussions of short-term economic performance, in the context of economic theory it generally refers to an increase in wealth over an extended period.
question_3: How is short term economic growth measured?
answert_3: Economic growth is defined as the increase in the market value of the goods and services produced by an economy over time. It is measured as the percentage rate of increase in the real gross domestic product (GDP). To determine economic growth, the GDP is compared to the population, also know as the per capita income.
question_4: What is long term economic growth?
answert_4: Economic Growth In macroeconomics, long-run growth is the increase in the market value of goods and services produced by an economy over a period of time. The long-run growth is determined by percentage of change in the real gross domestic product (GDP).
question_5: What is long term and short term economic growth?
answert_5: Short-run growth is simply an increase in a country's 'gross domestic product'or 'GDP', whereas long-run growth is an increase in the country's productive capacity.
question_6: What is short run economic growth?
answert_6: Short Run Economic Growth This simply means an increase in GDP in a given period of time. If the economy is operating below capacity (inside the production possibility frontier), short run growth is possible without any increase in productive capacity; it is simply a matter of employing unused resources.
question_7: Is economic growth short term?
answert_7: In the short term, economic growth is caused by an increase in aggregate demand (AD). If there is spare capacity in the economy, then an increase in AD will cause a higher level of real GDP.
question_8: Is economic growth long term or short term?
answert_8: In economics, growth is defined as the increase in output per capita of a country over a long period of time. One primary factor that influences the growth of an economy is technological change.
question_9: Is economic development a long term process?
answert_9: Existing theories mostly grasp economic development - at least under conditions of market economy - as a relatively stable process of growth, as result of which the technological and economic parameters steadily improve.
question_10: Why is economic growth short term?
answert_10: Short run growth will result from an increase in aggregate demand. If any of the components of AD increase, the AD curve will shift to the right, resulting in a higher equilibrium level of real output. The economy will return to full employment output without the boost to AD (which just results in higher inflation).
question_11: How is short run economic growth measured?
answert_11: Short Run Economic Growth This simply means an increase in GDP in a given period of time. If the economy is operating below capacity (inside the production possibility frontier), short run growth is possible without any increase in productive capacity; it is simply a matter of employing unused resources.
question_12: What is short term economic growth?
answert_12: Economists usually measure economic growth in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) or related indicators, such as gross national product (GNP) or gross national income (GNI) which are derived from the GDP calculation.
question_13: What are two measures of economic growth?
answert_13: Economic growth is the increase in the market value of the goods and services that an economy produces over time. It is measured as the percentage rate change in the real gross domestic product (GDP). Long-run growth is directly impacted by the GDP.
question_14: What is the difference between long term and short term economic growth?
answert_14: Short run where one factor of production (e.g. capital) is fixed. Very long run Where all factors of production are variable, and additional factors outside the control of the firm can change, e.g. technology, government policy. A period of several years.
question_15: What is a long term advantage of economic growth?
answert_15: Higher economic growth leads to higher tax revenues and this enables the government can spend more on public services, such as health care and education e.t.c. This can enable higher living standards, such as increased life expectancy, higher rates of literacy and a greater understanding of civic and political issues.
question_16: How long is short term economic growth?
answert_16: Short Run Economic Growth This simply means an increase in GDP in a given period of time. If the economy is operating below capacity (inside the production possibility frontier), short run growth is possible without any increase in productive capacity; it is simply a matter of employing unused resources.

question_18: What is the difference between short run and long run economic growth?
answert_18: Short run where one factor of production (e.g. capital) is fixed. Very long run Where all factors of production are variable, and additional factors outside the control of the firm can change, e.g. technology, government policy. A period of several years.
question_19: What causes economic growth in the short run?
answert_19: In the short term, economic growth is caused by an increase in aggregate demand (AD). If there is spare capacity in the economy, then an increase in AD will cause a higher level of real GDP.
question_20: What is an example of short run in economics?
answert_20: The short run in this microeconomic context is a planning period over which the managers of a firm must consider one or more of their factors of production as fixed in quantity. For example, a restaurant may regard its building as a fixed factor over a period of at least the next year.
question_21: Is economic growth a short run process?
answert_21: Economic growth is a long-run process that occurs as an economy's potential output increases. Changes in real GDP from quarter to quarter or even from year to year are short-run fluctuations that occur as aggregate demand and short-run aggregate supply change.
question_22: What is the term for economic growth?
answert_22: In economics, growth is defined as the increase in output per capita of a country over a long period of time. One primary factor that influences the growth of an economy is technological change.
question_23: Is economic growth forever?
answert_23: economic growth, the process by which a nation's wealth increases over time. Although the term is often used in discussions of short-term economic performance, in the context of economic theory it generally refers to an increase in wealth over an extended period.
question_24: Is economic growth long run or short run?
answert_24: In the short term, economic growth is caused by an increase in aggregate demand (AD). If there is spare capacity in the economy, then an increase in AD will cause a higher level of real GDP.
question_25: What is short term and long term economic growth?
answert_25: Economic growth is the increase in the market value of the goods and services that an economy produces over time. It is measured as the percentage rate change in the real gross domestic product ( GDP ). Determinants of long-run growth include growth of productivity, demographic changes, and labor force participation.

question_1: What was Shostakovich known for?
answert_1: Petersburg, Russiadied August 9, 1975, Moscow, Russia, U.S.S.R.) , Russian composer, renowned particularly for his 15 symphonies, numerous chamber works, and concerti, many of them written under the pressures of government-imposed standards of Soviet art.
question_2: What is Shostakovich style?
answert_2: Shostakovich's music is characterized by sharp contrasts, elements of the grotesque, and ambivalent tonality; the composer was also heavily influenced by the neo-classical style pioneered by Igor Stravinsky, and (especially in his symphonies) by the post-Romanticism associated with Gustav Mahler.
question_3: What are the notes of Shostakovich musical signature in English?
answert_3: Imagining oneself in Germany where the composer was when he wrote the piece, and where his name is transliterated as Schostakowitsch the first four letters of D. Schostakowitsch could be rendered as a musical motto by the notes DSCH, which English-speakers know as DE-flatCB-natural.
question_4: What happened to Shostakovich?
answert_4: Shostakovich died of heart failure on 9 August 1975. A civic funeral was held; he was interred in Novodevichy Cemetery, Moscow.

question_6: What did Stalin do to Shostakovich?
answert_6: Stalin liked it because he thought Shostakovich was glorifying him, not realizing the composer's true intent! The government dubbed the symphony A constructive creative answer of a Soviet artist to well deserved criticism. Stalin accepted it and never caught on to Shostakovich's trick.
question_7: Who did Shostakovich teach?
answert_7: He taught and promoted many talented musicians, such as Andrei Petrov, Georgi Sviridov, Karen Khachaturyan, and Boris Tishchenko among others. Shostakovich and Evgeniy Evtushenko worked together on the famous Symphony No. 13 titled Babi Yar, a vocal setting of poems by Yevtushenko.
question_8: Is Shostakovich great?
answert_8: Dmitri Dmitriyevich Shostakovich (25 September [O.S. 12 September] 1906 9 August 1975) was a Soviet-era Russian composer and pianist. He is regarded as one of the major composers of the 20th century and one of its most popular composers.
question_9: Is Shostakovich romantic or modern?
answert_9: Shostakovich's works are broadly tonal and in the Romantic tradition, but with elements of atonality and chromaticism. In some of his later works (e.g., the Twelfth Quartet), he made use of tone rows. His output is dominated by his cycles of symphonies and string quartets, each totaling 15.

question_13: What are the notes of Shostakovich musical signature in English )?
answert_13: In the third-movement waltz, the composer introduces himself into the music with a motto derived from the German transliteration of his name, D. Schostakowitsch. He creates a musical signature D, E-flat, C, and B, the D-S-C-H motive from his first initial and the first three letters of his last name.

question_15: What is the form of Shostakovich Symphony 5?
answert_15: Instead of writing in the approved ultra-nationalist style, Shostakovich wrote his Fifth Symphony on the model pioneered by Beethoven; he begins his symphony with a sonata, albeit with a hesitant feel.
question_16: Did Shostakovich speak English?
answert_16: The return of compliments came the following year when Shostakovich dedicated his 14th Symphony to his English friend. Interestingly, Britten and Shostakovich had no common language except for a smattering of Aldeburgh Deutsch, yet were said to understand each other perfectly.
question_17: How did Shostakovich died?

question_23: What did Shostakovich think of Stalin?
answert_23: Shostakovich lived and worked throughout Stalin's dictatorship, was twice publicly denounced for his work and was for many years in fear of his life, and yet he was decorated and celebrated by the Soviet Union, was a Deputy of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR and, despite several opportunities, never defected to the West
question_24: Why was Shostakovich depressed?

question_1: What shifts short run Phillips curve?
answert_1: The expected rate of inflation will also cause the short-run Phillips curve to shift. When the expected rate of inflation is decreases, the SRPC shifts to the (left/right) and the actual rate of inflation (increases/decreases).
question_2: Why is Phillips curve vertical in long run?
answert_2: Therefore, we can say that in the long-run, the Phillips Curve will be vertical because irrespective of the price level, unemployment will return to its natural rate (Natural Rate of Unemployment a.k.a NRU)
question_3: How do you draw a short run and long run Phillips curve?
answert_3: Each short run Phillips curve intersects the long run Phillips curve at the expected inflation rate.
question_4: What are the three main reasons why the short-run Phillips curve shifts?
answert_4: Decreases in aggregate supply shift the short run Phillips Curve to the right, and they include: An increase in expected inflation. An increase in the price of oil from abroad. A negative supply shock, such as damage from a hurricane.
question_5: What shifts the short-run Phillips curve quizlet?
answert_5: A sudden monetary contraction moves the economy up a short-run Phillips curve, reducing unemployment and increasing inflation. Other things the same, a decrease in aggregate demand decreases both inflation and unemployment. An adverse supply shock shifts the short-run Phillips curve right.
question_6: What do the short-run Phillips curves shift upward or downward?
answert_6: In particular, when inflation expectations rise from 3 percent to 6 percent, the short-run Phillips curve shifts upward until the inflation rate is 6 percent when the economy is at the natural rate of unemployment.
question_7: What causes the Phillips curve to shift quizlet?
answert_7: When the money supply changes, the aggregate demand curve shifts, and the economy moves along a given short-run aggregate supply curve. an event that directly alters firms'costs and prices, shifting the economy's aggregate-supply curve and thus the Phillips curve.
question_8: Why is the long run Phillips curve vertical quizlet?
answert_8: Why is the long run Phillips Curve vertical? Changing the natural rate of unemployment (NRU) can only be achieved by very specific supply side policies, so NRU shifts back to same rate each time, even though price level rises.
question_9: Why is the short run Phillips curve downward sloping but the long run Phillips curve vertical?
answert_9: Originally Answered: Why is the short run Phillips Curve negatively sloped while the long run Philips Curve is Vertical? People get used to inflation. Roughly, the point is that in the short run people treat a rise in the inflation rate as a rise in wealth.
question_10: Why is the Phillips curve upwards sloping?
answert_10: One can get from the Phillips curve to an upward sloping curve by putting employment rate rather than unemployment rate on the axis. As the decade passed, the U.S. economy got lower and lower unemployment rates and higher and higher rates of inflation.
question_11: Is the long run Phillips curve downward sloping?
answert_11: The short-run Phillips curve is downward sloping and the long-run Phillips curve is vertical.
question_12: What is Phillips curve in short run and long run?
answert_12: The Phillips curve shows the relationship between inflation and unemployment. In the short-run, inflation and unemployment are inversely related; as one quantity increases, the other decreases. In the long-run, there is no trade-off. In the 1960's, economists believed that the short-run Phillips curve was stable.
question_13: What causes shifts in the short run Phillips curve?
answert_13: The reason the short-run Phillips curve shifts is due to the changes in inflation expectations. Workers, who are assumed to be completely rational and informed, will recognize their nominal wages have not kept pace with inflation increases (the movement from A to B), so their real wages have been decreased.
question_14: What shifts the short run Phillips curve quizlet?
answert_14: A sudden monetary contraction moves the economy up a short-run Phillips curve, reducing unemployment and increasing inflation. Other things the same, a decrease in aggregate demand decreases both inflation and unemployment. An adverse supply shock shifts the short-run Phillips curve right.
question_15: Why do the short run Phillips curve shift upward and downward?
answert_15: When the money supply changes, the aggregate demand curve shifts, and the economy moves along a given short-run aggregate supply curve. an event that directly alters firms'costs and prices, shifting the economy's aggregate-supply curve and thus the Phillips curve.
question_16: What shifts the short run Phillips curve?
answert_16: The expected rate of inflation will also cause the short-run Phillips curve to shift. When the expected rate of inflation is increases, the SRPC shifts to the (left/right) and the actual rate of inflation (increases/decreases).
question_17: What causes short run Phillips curve to shift up?
answert_17: The reason the short-run Phillips curve shifts is due to the changes in inflation expectations. Workers, who are assumed to be completely rational and informed, will recognize their nominal wages have not kept pace with inflation increases (the movement from A to B), so their real wages have been decreased.
question_18: What can shift long-run Phillips curve?
answert_18: When the money supply changes, the aggregate demand curve shifts, and the economy moves along a given short-run aggregate supply curve. an event that directly alters firms'costs and prices, shifting the economy's aggregate-supply curve and thus the Phillips curve.
question_19: What shifts the short run Phillips curve upwards?
answert_19: The expected rate of inflation will also cause the short-run Phillips curve to shift. When workers expect inflation they bargain for higher wage rates, and employers are more willing to grant higher wage rates when they expect to sell their product for higher prices in the future.
question_20: Is the Phillips curve upward or downward sloping?
answert_20: A Phillips curve shows the tradeoff between unemployment and inflation in an economy. From a Keynesian viewpoint, the Phillips curve should slope down so that higher unemployment means lower inflation, and vice versa.
question_21: Is the short run Phillips curve upward sloping?
answert_21: The Keynesian Perspective introduced the Phillips curve and explained how it is derived from the aggregate supply curve. The short run upward sloping aggregate supply curve implies a downward sloping Phillips curve; thus, there is a tradeoff between inflation and unemployment in the short run.
question_22: Is the short run Phillips curve downward sloping?
answert_22: In the short run, the Philips curve slopes downward because it captures the impact of the unemployment rate on the inflation rate. When the unemployment rate rises, it lowers the inflation rate, and when the unemployment rate lowers, it increases inflation rates.
question_23: What causes the Phillips curve to shift?
answert_23: The reason the short-run Phillips curve shifts is due to the changes in inflation expectations. Workers, who are assumed to be completely rational and informed, will recognize their nominal wages have not kept pace with inflation increases (the movement from A to B), so their real wages have been decreased.
question_24: What causes the long run Phillips curve to shift quizlet?
answert_24: An increase in price expectations shifts the Phillips curve upward and makes the inflation-unemployment trade-off less favorable. In the long run, the unemployment rate is independent of inflation and the Phillips curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment.
question_25: What shifts the Phillips curve to the left?
answert_25: Increases in aggregate supply shift the short run Phillips Curve to the left, and they include: Improvements in technology across the economy. A decrease in expected inflation. A decrease in the price of oil from abroad.

question_18: What is the thesis in The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber?
answert_18: A Literary Analysis of the Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber by Ernest Hemingway. One theme present in Ernest Hemingway's short story, The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber, is that the way a person views his life can change completely in one fulfilling moment, if only for an instant.
question_19: What are the symbols in The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber?
answert_19: The savanna represents Wilson's world, the wild, savage force of nature. The lion and the buffalo, representations of nature itself in all its brutal force, also come to symbolize the differences in courage and manhood that exist between Macomber and Wilson. Similarly, the guns themselves operate as symbols of manhood.
question_20: Why is Macomber afraid during the lion hunt?
answert_20: He was afraid . . . [and] there was no one to tell he was afraid. Next morning, Margot recognizes that Macomber is upset, but he tells her simply that he's nervous because of the lion's roaring throughout the night. Thus Macomber's cowardice in this scene is the central motivating force for the entire story.
question_21: Who killed the lion in The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber?

question_22: What is the Somali proverb regarding hearing a lion roar?

question_1: What is very short answer type questions?
answert_1: In a short answer question, the student types in a word or phrase in response to a question (that may include an image). Answers may or may not be case sensitive. The answer could be a word or a phrase, but it must match one of your acceptable answers exactly.
question_2: What is short type test?
answert_2: Introduction to Short Answer Type Test: The modern trend is to include more short answer questions in the question papers in order to improve their reliability, validity and sampling capacity.
question_3: What is very short answer questions?
answert_3: Short-answer questions are open-ended questions that require students to create an answer. They are commonly used in examinations to assess the basic knowledge and understanding (low cognitive levels) of a topic before more in-depth assessment questions are asked on the topic. Structure of Short Answer Questions.
question_4: What is short answer type items?
answert_4: The Short Answer (SA) is a constructed response item type in which the examinee types a short response. Like the fill-in-the-blank (FIB) and essay item types, SA items prompt examinees to produce their responses by typing, rather than selecting from a list as in a MC item.
question_5: How do you write short answer questions?
answert_5:
Short answer questions in exams
  • Deconstruct the question.
  • Rephrase the question in your own words.
  • Plan the structure of your answer before starting to write.
  • Use examples to give evidence and help give your writing credibility.
  • Use plain language and keep your writing straight to the point.
question_6: What is short answer type test?
answert_6: What is a short-answer exam? On a short-answer exam you are asked to provide a concise, yet thorough, written answer to a question, usually using complete sentences. These exams test your ability to integrate what you've learned in the lectures, readings, and discussions, and to apply that knowledge.
question_7: What is very short type question?
answert_7: Short Answer Questions do not have a generic structure. Questions may require answers such as complete the sentence, supply the missing word, short descriptive or qualitative answers, diagrams with explanations etc. The answer is usually short, from one word to a few lines. Often students may answer in bullet form.
question_8: How do you write a short answer type test?
answert_8:
Short Answer Test Preparation Tips
  • Study for understanding.
  • Focus on topics and concepts.
  • Employ self testing.
  • Use flashcards.
  • If in doubt, make an educated guess.
  • Answer the easy questions first.
  • Read all instructions.
  • Budget your time.
question_9: What are the short answer type of items?
answert_9: Short-answer items can be answered by a word, phrase, or number. The two types of short-answer items-question and completion-also referred as fill-in-the blank, are essentially the same except for format.

question_2: Who is the main character in shooting the moon?

question_3: What genre is shooting the moon?

question_4: What is the theme of shooting the moon?

question_21: When should you shoot the moon?
answert_21: Shooting the moon is when you want to win all the hearts and the Queen of spades. If you succeed, you gain no points that round and every other player gains 26 points (in some circles, you have an option to instead take 26 points off your score).
question_22: Can you shoot the moon?
answert_22: It is theoretically possible to shoot a bullet onto the moon, but practially not. The bullet would have to resist large acceleration, and a pass through the atmosphere at a very high speed.
question_23: What happens if you shoot the moon?
answert_23: Shoot the Moon in the Game Hearts. Generally speaking, your goal in a round of Hearts is to take the fewest points. However, if you manage to take all 26 points in a round, this is called shooting the moon, and you get to subtract 26 points from your total instead
question_24: Do you need the Jack of Diamonds to shoot the moon?
answert_24: If you allow shooting the moon, you generally don't need to take the Jack of Diamonds to shoot the moon, but some versions of the game require that you win this card, too. For example, capturing the 10 of Clubs and three heart cards costs you 6 points, not 3. The Ace of Hearts may be charged at 5 points, not 1.

question_1: What happened in Chapter 1 of shooting Kabul?
answert_1: In Chapter 1 the family travelled by taxi from their home in Kabul to the city of Jalalabad in eastern Afghanistan. During the journey, Fadi remembered the night his father Habib told the family that they were leaving the country.
question_2: What happens in the book Shooting Kabul?
answert_2: In the summer of 2001, twelve year old Fadi's parents make the difficult decision to illegally leave Afghanistan and move the family to the United States. When their underground transport arrives at the rendezvous point, chaos ensues, and Fadi is left dragging his younger sister Mariam through the crush of people.
question_3: What happened in Chapter 2 of shooting Kabul?
answert_3: In Chapter 2, an army truck arrived in Jalalabad to help people escape from Afghanistan over the border into Pakistan. As Fadi and his family approached the truck, lots of other people appeared suddenly from the shadows who were also trying to get on board the truck.
question_4: Was Mariam found in shooting Kabul?
answert_4: In Chapter 21, the family received a phone call informing them that the family who rescued Mariam in Jalalabad had been found. Unfortunately, the family had lost Mariam and didn't know where she was. In Chapter 22, the results of the photography competition were delivered to Ms. Bethune at school.
question_5: What happened in the book Shooting Kabul?
answert_5: In the summer of 2001, twelve year old Fadi's parents make the difficult decision to illegally leave Afghanistan and move the family to the United States. question_6: How old is Mariam from shooting Kabul?
answert_6: In Chapter 2, an army truck arrived in Jalalabad to help people escape from Afghanistan over the border into Pakistan. As Fadi and his family approached the truck, lots of other people appeared suddenly from the shadows who were also trying to get on board the truck.
question_7: Do they find Mariam in shooting Kabul?
answert_7: The rest of the family made it safely to America but were unable to properly move on with their lives until they found out what became of Mariam. Once in America, Fadi had to adjust to a life in a new country.
question_8: What happened at Toys R Us in shooting Kabul?
answert_8: What happened at Toys R Us? While Fadi was shopping, he wandered to the Barbie section of the store.They reminded him of Mariam so he flew into a rage and destroyed several of the dolls
question_9: What happened in Shooting Kabul Chapter 6?
answert_9: In Chapter 6, Fadi and his family began to adjust to their new life in America. Fadi finished reading From the Mixed-up Files of Mrs. One night, Fadi overheard Noor giving her wages to Habib because she knew that the family had very little money. Noor told Habib that it was her fault Mariam was lost.
question_10: What does Fadi do in shooting Kabul?
answert_10: Fadi is the central character / protagonist. He is a 12-year-old Muslim boy from Afghanistan with a passion for photography whose parents move his family to San Francisco in order to build a safer and happier life for their children.
question_11: Who is Gulmina shooting Kabul?

question_12: Did they find Mariam in shooting Kabul?
answert_12: The rest of the family made it safely to America but were unable to properly move on with their lives until they found out what became of Mariam. Once in America, Fadi had to adjust to a life in a new country.
question_13: What happens to Mariam in shooting Kabul?
answert_13: When their underground transport arrives at the rendezvous point, chaos ensues, and Fadi is left dragging his younger sister Mariam through the crush of people. But Mariam accidentally lets go of his hand and becomes lost in the crowd, just as Fadi is snatched up into the truck.
question_14: Who is Miriam in shooting Kabul?
answert_14: Mariam, Fadi's 6-year-old sister, slips from his grasp and is left behind. The family can't go back for her. Fadi blames himself. As he struggles to adapt to life in the United States, he doesn't stop thinking about rescuing Miriam.

answert_16: It is theoretically possible to shoot a bullet onto the moon, but practially not. The bullet would have to resist large acceleration, and a pass through the atmosphere at a very high speed.
question_17: What happens if you shoot the moon?
answert_17: Shoot the Moon in the Game Hearts. Generally speaking, your goal in a round of Hearts is to take the fewest points. However, if you manage to take all 26 points in a round, this is called shooting the moon, and you get to subtract 26 points from your total instead
question_18: Do you need the Jack of Diamonds to shoot the moon?
answert_18: If you allow shooting the moon, you generally don't need to take the Jack of Diamonds to shoot the moon, but some versions of the game require that you win this card, too. question_1: Why does the narrator decide to shoot the elephant choose the best answer?

question_2: What does the elephant symbolize in Shooting an Elephant?
answert_2: The elephant is the central symbol of the story. Orwell uses it to represent the effect of colonialism on both the colonizer and the colonized. The elephant, like a colonized populace, has its liberty restricted, and it becomes violently rebellious only as a response to being shackled.
question_3: What is the theme of Shooting an Elephant?
answert_3: The main themes of Shooting an Elephant include conscience, culture clash, and order and disorder. Conscience: In the essay, colonial law contrasts with the conscience of the narrator both in his killing of the elephant and his treatment of the Burmese.
question_4: What is the main event in Shooting an Elephant?
answert_4: The main story which Orwell relates takes place in Moulmein, in Lower Burma. An elephant, one of the tame elephants which the locals own and use, has given its rider or mahout the slip, and has been wreaking havoc throughout the bazaar. It has destroyed a hut, killed a cow, and raided some fruit stalls for food.

question_2: What does the elephant represent in Shooting an Elephant?

question_3: Why does Orwell shoot the elephant?
answert_3: It is apparent why Orwell shot the elephant; he flat-out admits that he shot the elephant so as not to look like a fool (Orwell 625). It would have taken a stronger character to stand up to all of those people and declare that the elephant no longer posed a threat.
question_4: What is the main point of the essay Shooting an Elephant by George Orwell?

answert_8: Shooting an Elephant'is a 1936 essay by George Orwell (1903-50), about his time as a young policeman in Burma, which was then part of the British empire. The essay explores an apparent paradox about the behaviour of Europeans, who supposedly have the power over their colonial subjects.

question_1: What is the metaphor in Shooting an Elephant?
answert_1: Because the locals expect him to do the job, he does so against his better judgment, his anguish increased by the elephant's slow and painful death. question_2: What is the reason behind shooting the elephant in George Orwell's essay Shooting an Elephant?
answert_2: Orwell makes it clear in this essay that he was not a particularly talented rifleman. question_4: What was the elephant destroyed in Shooting an Elephant?

question_16: What is the main point or theme of the essay Shooting an Elephant?
answert_16: Shooting an Elephant'is a 1936 essay by George Orwell (1903-50), about his time as a young policeman in Burma, which was then part of the British empire. The essay explores an apparent paradox about the behaviour of Europeans, who supposedly have the power over their colonial subjects.

question_2: Why does Orwell shoot the elephant?
answert_2: It is apparent why Orwell shot the elephant; he flat-out admits that he shot the elephant so as not to look like a fool (Orwell 625). It would have taken a stronger character to stand up to all of those people and declare that the elephant no longer posed a threat.
question_3: Does the elephant fall on the first shot?

answert_5: A Symbol for Good Luck, Wisdom, and More Elephants are revered symbols in many cultures, as they are the largest living land mammals. In feng shui they represent strength, protection, wisdom, and good luck! As with all symbols, touch into your own connection.
question_6: Why does he shoot the elephant in the story Shooting an Elephant?
answert_6: Although he does not want to kill the elephant since it now seems peaceful, the narrator feels pressured by the demand of the crowd for the act to be carried out. After inquiring as to the elephant's behavior and delaying for some time, he shoots the elephant several times and wounds it but is unable to kill it.

question_1: Is Shogun historically accurate?
answert_1: It's surprisingly accurate. Only the names have been changed to protect the guilty. It is based on the story of William Adams (John Blackthorne in Shogun), an English Pilot on a Dutch ship that made its way to Japan. He eventually became a trusted advisor to Tokugawa Ieyasu (Lord Toranaga).
question_2: Why you should read Shogun?
answert_2: It's a story that forces you to stay on guard, to appreciate the characters who stitch themselves to your core and to question the ways we approach living life. Shdgun is a wondrous epic set in feudal Japan and it will blot out every concern of your life until you finish it.
question_3: Who was the main character in Shogun?
answert_3: Shdgun

question_5: Was Shogun a true story?
answert_5: But the real Shogun who inspired the bestseller and subsequent television drama was Lord Tokugawa Ieyasu, one of the most outstanding figures in Japanese history and a lord still revered in his homeland 400 years after his death.
question_6: Who is John Blackthorne based on?
answert_6: navigator William Adams
question_7: What time period is Shogun set in?
answert_7: This best-selling historical novel by the British author, James Clavell, is set in Japan around 1600. It begins when The Erasmus, a Dutch ship, reaches Japan by mistake.
question_8: Is Shogun a great read?
answert_8: I read several of Clavell's other books and they were also good but Shogun is by far my favorite. It has it all: action, romance, wonderful historical detail, intrigue, great plot and things that caught me by surprise. I read it probably five-six years ago and I re-read it over and over since then.

answert_12: Habibi (male) and habibti (female) Both mean darling, and can be used with friends and good colleagues. It is one of the most widely used terms of endearments in the region, and chances are they are the first Arabic words learned by a new arrival.
question_13: Why does he call habibti?

question_14: Can a girl say Habibi to a guy?
answert_14: Habibi is a term of affection for a male, and habibti is the feminine form of that word. The words literally mean my love (male) and my love (female) but are used quite loosely in conversation. Men can and do easily call each other habibi, especially in heated arguments.

question_24: What does Shukr mean?
answert_24: Shukr (Arabic: u0634u0643u0631) is an Arabic term denoting thankfulness, gratitude or acknowledgment by humans, being a highly esteemed virtue in Islam. The term may also be used if the subject is God, in which case it takes the meaning of divine responsiveness.

question_1: What is the overall message of Shooting an Elephant?
answert_1: The main themes of Shooting an Elephant include conscience, culture clash, and order and disorder. Conscience: In the essay, colonial law contrasts with the conscience of the narrator both in his killing of the elephant and his treatment of the Burmese.
question_2: What does the shooting of the elephant symbolize for Orwell?
answert_2: The British officer, the executioner, acts as a symbol of the imperial country, while the elephant symbolizes the victim of imperialism.  The shooting of the elephant in the incident that reveals that imperialism inflicts damage on both parties in an imperialistic relationship.

question_1: What is the theme of Shoeless Joe Jackson Comes to Iowa?
answert_1: Shoeless Joe is a wish-fulfillment, fantasy novel in which the dead come back to life, dreams come true, and old wounds are healed. It asserts the primacy of imagination over the demands of practical life.
question_2: Did Shoeless Joe take the money?
answert_2: Shoeless Joe played flawlessly in left field. Lefty Williams came to Shoeless Joe's room a night after the Series ended and gave him $5,000. Shoeless was unaware his name was used in the fix and refused to accept the Williams'delivery. Williams then threw the money on the floor and left Jackson's room.
question_3: Is Shoeless Joe a true story?
answert_3: Shoeless Joe Jackson, byname of Joseph Jefferson Jackson, (born July 16, 1888, Greenville, S.C., U.S.died Dec. 5, 1951, Greenville), American professional baseball player, by many accounts one of the greatest, who was ultimately banned from the game because of his involvement in the 1919 Black Sox Scandal.
question_4: How does the book Shoeless Joe end?

question_6: What is the plot of Shoeless Joe Jackson?
answert_6: Plot. Ray Kinsella lives and farms in Iowa where he grows corn with his wife Annie and their five-year-old daughter Karin. Kinsella is obsessed with the beauty and history of American baseball, specifically the plight of his hero, Shoeless Joe Jackson, and the Black Sox Scandal of the 1919 World Series.

answert_20: When Iowa farmer Ray (Kevin Costner) hears a mysterious voice one night in his cornfield saying "If you build it, he will come," he feels the need to act. Despite taunts of lunacy, Ray builds a baseball diamond on his land, supported by his wife, Annie (Amy Madigan). Afterward, the ghosts of great players start emerging from the crops to play ball, led by "Shoeless" Joe Jackson. But, as Ray learns, this field of dreams is about much more than bringing former baseball greats out to play.

question_23: Why is Joe Jackson called Shoeless?

question_1: What is the point of Symposium Plato?

question_4: What does Pausanias say about Love?
answert_4: Pausanias argues that loving is in itself neither a good nor a bad activity. If it is done properly, it is good, and if not, it is bad. Common Love, according to Pausanias, is bad because its attraction is indiscriminating, directed toward bodies rather than toward minds.
question_5: Why is the symposium important?
answert_5: The symposium (or symposion) was an important part of ancient Greek culture from the 7th century BCE and was a party held in a private home where Greek males gathered to drink, eat and sing together. Various topics were also discussed such as philosophy, politics, poetry and the issues of the day.
question_6: What can we learn from Plato's symposium?

question_7: What happens at the end of the symposium?

question_8: What was the symposium in ancient Greece?

question_11: What is Plato's view of love?
answert_11: The idea of romantic love initially stems from the Platonic tradition that love is a desire for beauty-a value that transcends the particularities of the physical body. question_13: What is the nature of love in Symposium?

question_14: How does Pausanias describe the nature of Love?

question_15: Why does Pausanias think that Love is valuable to a city and its citizens?

question_16: What are the two types of Love according to Pausanias?
answert_16: Pausanias points out two types of love: Common Love and Heavenly Love, with Heavenly Love being the better of the two. Common Love occurs between a man and a woman or a man and a young boy, while Heavenly Love occurs between an older man and a younger man.
question_17: What is Love according to Eryximachus?

In practicing Love, whether by means of music or medicine, one is promoting order, and may thus improve people.

question_1: What is the graph of SHM?

question_10: Is SHM always in straight line?
answert_10: Linear simple harmonic motion (S.H.M.) is defined as the linear periodic motion of a body, in which the restoring force (or acceleration) is always directed towards the mean position and its magnitude is directly proportional to the displacement from the mean position.
question_11: What is the phase in SHM?

question_12: What is the phase of a wave?
answert_12: Phase specifies the location or timing of a point within a wave cycle of a repetitive waveform. Typically, it is the phase difference between sound waves that is relevant, rather than the actual absolute phases of the signals. Two sound waves that are in phase add to produce a sound wave of greater amplitude.
question_13: What is the phase of oscillation?

question_14: What is phase and epoch?
answert_14: Epoch is the initial phase of a particle and it remains constant all the time for a given motion. question_15: How do you describe the motion of a graph?

question_16: What is simple harmonic motion in simple terms?
answert_16: simple harmonic motion, in physics, repetitive movement back and forth through an equilibrium, or central, position, so that the maximum displacement on one side of this position is equal to the maximum displacement on the other side.
question_17: What is an oscillation on a graph?

question_24: What is meant by the phase of a wave?
answert_24: The phase involves the relationship between the position of the amplitude crests and troughs of two waveforms. Phase can be measured in distance, time, or degrees. If the peaks of two signals with the same frequency are in exact alignment at the same time, they are said to be in phase.
question_25: How do you find the phase of a wave?
answert_25: Phase Difference: The difference in phase between two points on a wave. It is usually expressed in radians. Phase: A measure of how far through the wave's cycle a given point on the wave is. Polarisation: The restriction of a wave so that it can only oscillate in a single plane.

question_14: What is difference between Yarimasu and Shimasu?
answert_14: Shimasu is the polite form of tsuru, while yarimasu is the common form. So if you're speaking to your social peer in an informal setting, you would say (nani nani) yarimasu, OR simply yaru.
question_15: What's the meaning of Onegaishimasu?

In many cases, these two Japanese words, which translate roughly as please or please give me, are interchangeable.

question_1: What is the tree grows in Brooklyn about?
answert_1: A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a 1943 semi-autobiographical novel written by Betty Smith. The story focuses on an impoverished but aspirational adolescent girl and her family living in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, New York City, during the first two decades of the 20th century.
question_2: Was A Tree Grows in Brooklyn banned?
answert_2: No, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is not banned now. It was banned in the past for having strong themes (e.g., alcoholism, sex, child abuse).
question_3: What does the tree symbolize In A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_3: It symbolizes perseverance and hope amidst hardship. The tree is a recurring symbol throughout the novel; when Francie is born, Katie explicitly likens her life to the tree's. Katie knows she will keep living, no matter how sick she becomes.
question_4: What is the message of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_4: Perseverance through hardship This theme relates closely to the American dream motif and the symbol of the tree. The strength of the Rommely women suggests that they can withstand any hardship. When Francie is born sickly, she perseveres like the tree; her mother never doubts her strength.
question_5: What is the main idea of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_5: Perseverance through hardship This theme relates closely to the American dream motif and the symbol of the tree. The strength of the Rommely women suggests that they can withstand any hardship. When Francie is born sickly, she perseveres like the tree; her mother never doubts her strength.
question_6: Is A Tree Grows in Brooklyn a true story?
answert_6: A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a largely autobiographical work. Like Francie Nolan, Smith grew up in an impoverished Williamsburg in the early twentieth century. She and Francie even share the same birth date, although Smith was born five years before.
question_7: Does A Tree Grows in Brooklyn have a happy ending?
answert_7: The end of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn ties things up nicely and slaps a pretty bow on top. Seriouslythings come together pretty neatly. Francie is off to college at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor. This resolves the main conflict in Francie's life, and her dreams of education are pretty much fulfilled.
question_8: Why was A Tree Grows in Brooklyn banned?
answert_8: No, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is not banned now. It was banned in the past for having strong themes (e.g., alcoholism, sex, child abuse).
question_9: What is the problem in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_9: In the book, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, man versus society conflicts are revealed in Johnny Nolans love of alcohol and his job preferences, Aunt Sissy Rommelys mode of marrying and divorcing, and Francie Nolans unfair treatment due to her social standing.
question_10: Is A Tree Grows in Brooklyn in the public domain?
answert_10: A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a largely autobiographical work. Like Francie Nolan, Smith grew up in an impoverished Williamsburg in the early twentieth century. She and Francie even share the same birth date, although Smith was born five years before.
question_11: What was hung out the window in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_11: This work is in the public domain because it was published in the United States between 1927 and 1963, and although there may or may not have been a copyright notice, the copyright was not renewed.
question_12: What tree is in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_12: The tree in question was an Ailanthus glandulosa, the tree of heaven, a Chinese sumac common to every Brooklyn tenement yard metaphorically indestructible even when you chopped it down and the point was that things live and things die and yet life goes on somehow, as it must, and this was precisely the kind of
question_13: What is the main metaphor of the book A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_13: the hardy Tree of Heaven
question_14: What do the pearl studs symbolize In A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_14: They symbolize Katie's love for Johnny, but they also symbolize her expectation that he will use them as he supports his family. At the end of Chapter 36, after Johnny's funeral, the narrator states that Johnny was buried with the pearl studs.
question_15: What is the meaning of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_15: It symbolizes perseverance and hope amidst hardship. The tree is a recurring symbol throughout the novel; when Francie is born, Katie explicitly likens her life to the tree's. Katie knows she will keep living, no matter how sick she becomes.
question_16: What is the authors purpose in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_16: Smith wrote A Tree Grows in Brooklyn to inform others about what it was like growing up in a small neighborhood in Brooklyn in the early 1900s. In one chapter, she recalls with a peculiar tenderness how Brooklynites celebrated Thanksgiving (Smith 1).
question_17: What is American Dreams In A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_17: American Dream The dream of a better life in America drives the Nolans to live life the way they do.
question_18: What is the significance of Molly Malone in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_18: Since it is Saturday, Francie sleeps in the front room, and hears Johnny Nolan come home at two in the morning. He sings Molly Malone on his way up the stairs, and Katie opens the door before the end of the verse, which means that she won the little game they all play
question_19: What is the story A Tree Grows in Brooklyn about?
answert_19: Betty Smith's classic 1943 novel A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a story that focuses on the growth of Francie Nolan from childhood to early adulthood. It also revolves around her parents and brother as they struggle to survive in the tenements of Brooklyn in the early 20th century.
question_20: What is Francie's goal in regards to reading?
answert_20: Francie's goal is to save the memory of the day that the United States entered the war.
question_21: What is the author's point of view about the tree in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_21: Point of View Broadens the Story This is what makes this third person omniscient. A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is much more than a plain old coming of age story. Francie is definitely the protagonist, but since there is a third person narrator, we know the struggles and joys of so many of the people around her.
question_22: What is the significance of the tree in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_22: It symbolizes perseverance and hope amidst hardship. The tree is a recurring symbol throughout the novel; when Francie is born, Katie explicitly likens her life to the tree's. Katie knows she will keep living, no matter how sick she becomes.
question_23: Is A Tree Grows in Brooklyn an autobiography?
answert_23: No, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is not banned now. It was banned in the past for having strong themes (e.g., alcoholism, sex, child abuse).
question_24: Does A Tree Grows in Brooklyn have romance?
answert_24: Francie's first bout with romantic love mirrors the political and economic changes in the world. One day Francie meets a young soldier, Lee Rynor who she falls in love with in 48 hours. Lee goes home and marries his fiancxe9e before going to war, leaving Francie with a broken heart.
question_25: Who does Katie marry in A Tree Grows in Brooklyn?
answert_25: Johnny Nolan

question_14: What are five interesting facts that you learned about Shirley Jackson?
answert_14:
Here are some surprising facts from my biography.
  • She was a California girl.
  • Her family believed in Christian Science.
  • She flunked out of college.
  • Her parents didn't attend her wedding.
  • Her agent shielded her from rejection.
  • She wrote The Lottery in a single morning.
  • People thought The Lottery was a factual report.

question_20: What was the Lottery by Shirley Jackson based on?
answert_20: For the rest of her life, Jackson would receive letters demanding an explanation for The Lottery. She reportedly told one friend that it was based in anti-Semitism, and another that all the characters were modeled on actual people in North Bennington.

question_22: What inspired Shirley Jackson to write?
answert_22: Jackson's socialite mother verbally abused her daughter, who consequently grew up with low self-esteem and a fragile sense of identity. Jackson began writing when she was a teenager and focused seriously on her work in high school and college
question_23: What was Shirley Jackson interested in?
answert_23: Jackson became interested in witchcraft during her early years in college and continued studying it for the rest of her life. Many of her books, including Life Among the Savages, contain references to historical witchcraft chronicles or manuals (known as grimoires).
question_24: What type of writing style is The Lottery?
answert_24: Gothicism. Gothic literature typically features such elements as horror, the supernatural, suspense, and violence. question_1: What is the Shipman's tale about?
answert_1: It is based on an old French fabliau and resembles a story found in Giovanni Boccaccio's Decameron. In the tale told by Chaucer's Shipman, the wife of a rich merchant convinces a young monk that her husband refuses to pay for her clothes and asks him to lend her 100 francs
question_2: What is the moral of the Shipman's tale?
answert_2: Moral. The presented moral is that you can't trust anyone, even your closest friends. The monk was a close friend to the Shipman and a man of the church, yet he still deceived the Shipman by being involved with his wife.
question_3: What is The Canterbury Tales about short summary?
answert_3: In The Canterbury Tales, a group of pilgrims traveling to Canterbury Cathedral compete in a storytelling contest. This overarching plot, or frame, provides a reason for the pilgrims to tell their stories, which reflect the concerns sparked by the social upheavals of late medieval England.
question_4: What did the Shipman do in Canterbury Tales?
answert_4: The Shipman's tale is about a monk who befriends a merchant who is so stingy with his wife that she sleeps with the monk in exchange for money. The monk borrows the money from the merchant claiming he will use it to buy cattle. When the merchant leaves town, the monk and the merchant's wife make the exchange.
question_5: What is the message of the Shipman's tale?
answert_5: Moral. The presented moral is that you can't trust anyone, even your closest friends. The monk was a close friend to the Shipman and a man of the church, yet he still deceived the Shipman by being involved with his wife.

question_7: What kind of tale is the Shipman's tale?
answert_7: The Shipman's Tale (also called The Sailor's Tale) is one of The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. It is in the form of a fabliau and tells the story of a merchant, his wife and her lover, a monk.
question_8: How does Chaucer describe the Shipman?
answert_8: In Geoffrey Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales, the Shipman is a rough-and-tumble, wild man of the sea, but he is thought to be a good man that tells a tale that is a departure from his character.
question_9: What is the moral of the Prioress tale?
answert_9: 'The Prioress's Tale''in ''The Canterbury Tales''concerns a small boy who is killed, his grieving mother, and a miracle of the Virgin Mary that causes him to go on singing after he has died. This tale involves themes of motherhood, innocence, and antisemitism
question_10: What is the main idea of Canterbury Tales?
answert_10: Social satire is the major theme of The Canterbury Tales. The medieval society was set on three foundations: the nobility, the church, and the peasantry. Chaucer's satire targets all segments of the medieval social issues, human immorality, and depraved heart.
question_11: Why is The Canterbury Tales so important?
answert_11: The Canterbury Tales is considered Chaucer's masterpiece and is among the most important works of medieval literature for many reasons besides its poetic power and entertainment value, notably its depiction of the different social classes of the 14th century CE as well as clothing worn, pastimes enjoyed, and language/

answert_19: The central theme in this tale is the various ways to use power within relationships. The merchant has the most monetary power, Sir John uses his social power, and the merchant's wife wields sexual power.
question_20: Why is the Shipman's tale A Fabliau?
answert_20: Judged by its storya monk borrows money from a merchant, buys the wife's favours with it and then refers the merchant to his wife for repaymentthis Tale is a fabliau, 1 which plays variations on the motifs of illicit sex, tricky intrigue and poetic justice. Yet these elements are handled with a blandness, an
question_21: What kind of tale is the merchant's tale?
answert_21: The Merchant's Tale, one of the 24 stories in The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. The story draws on a folktale of familiar theme, that of an old man whose young wife is unfaithful. Old Januarie is deceived by his young wife, May, and her lover, Damyan, after Januarie suddenly goes blind.
question_22: What is the name of the Shipman in Canterbury Tales?
answert_22: Minute Summary/Abstract: The Skipper, also known as the Shipman was exactly that in the Canterbury tales, he was a shipman. The ship he helped run was owned by the Merchant. He went about just trying to stay out of trouble. When he could he would steal wine from the ship's captain, and he often got into fights.
question_23: What social class is the Shipman in Canterbury Tales?
answert_23: Definition of shipman 1 : sailor, seaman. 2 : shipmaster.
question_24: What is the moral of the Prioress?
answert_24: 'The Prioress's Tale''in ''The Canterbury Tales''concerns a small boy who is killed, his grieving mother, and a miracle of the Virgin Mary that causes him to go on singing after he has died. This tale involves themes of motherhood, innocence, and antisemitism
question_25: What is the meaning of the Prioress tale?
answert_25: The Prioress's Tale, one of the 24 stories in The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. The Prioress describes how a widow's devout young son is abducted by Jews, who are supposedly prompted by Satan to murder the child to stop him from singing the hymn O Alma redemptoris to the Virgin Mary.

question_1: What is Shitsureshimasu?
answert_1: Shitsureishimasu literally means I will do something rude. u2605 When entering or leaving a room, shitsureishimasu is a polite expression that means excuse my interrupting. u2605 You can also use shitsureishimasu before doing something rude, such as answering your cell phone during dinner.
question_2: How do you pronounce Shitsurei?
answert_2: In shitsurei, the 'i'sound in 'shi'and the 'u'sound in 'tsu'are pretty deemphasized. The result is a kindof rolling action with your tongue as you start the 'shi'and then glide over the 'tsu'directly into the 're-i'.
question_3: In what situations can Shitsurei Shimasu be used?
answert_3: Shitsurei shimasu is most commonly used in the workplace. It is used in the sense of excuse me in this case. For example, if your cell phone rings and you need to answer it, you can say Shitsurei Shimasu(u3057u3064u308cu3044u3057u307eu3059) to say excuse me or more literally, I am about to do something impolite so please excuse me.
question_4: What's the meaning of Onegaishimasu?

In many cases, these two Japanese words, which translate roughly as please or please give me, are interchangeable.
question_5: When should I use Shitsurei?
answert_5: Shitsurei shimasu is most commonly used in the workplace. It is used in the sense of excuse me in this case. For example, if your cell phone rings and you need to answer it, you can say Shitsurei Shimasu(u3057u3064u308cu3044u3057u307eu3059) to say excuse me or more literally, I am about to do something impolite so please excuse me.
question_6: What is the meaning of Hajimemashite?
answert_6: How do you do? This is a standard greeting, when you meet somebody for the first time. When somebody said to you HAJIMEMASHITE, you also say, HAJIMEMASHITE.
question_7: What do Japanese say when leaving work?
answert_7: At the end of a work day, most people simply want to leave and go home. However in Japan it is usually considered good manners to announce that you are leaving and the common phrase for this is u304a u5148 u3055u304d u306b u5931u793c u3057u3064u308cu3044 u3057u307eu3059.

question_9: How do you say excuse me in Japanese when passing someone?
answert_9: Sumimasen. Pronounce it: Soo-mee-mah-sen. It's means pardon me, excuse me, sorry and is a generally useful verbal tick. It's written in hiragana as u3059u307fu307eu305bu3093.

question_12: How do you respond to Shitsurei Shimasu?
answert_12: Replying to Osaki ni Shitsureishimasu Be a good sport and answer back with a cheerful Otsukaresama desu or Otsukaresama deshita. Yes, even if you have to put up with a late night at the office! As the latter expression means good work, be careful not to confuse it with Osaki ni Shitsureishimasu.
question_13: Does Shitsurei Shimasu mean goodbye?

question_14: What does Osaki ni Shitsurei Shimasu mean?
answert_14: pardon me for leaving first
question_15: How do you reply to Onegaishimasu?
answert_15: Generally the correct response is yoroshiku onegai shimasu. Or kochira koso yoroshiku onegai shimasu, if you want to get fancy. The subtext to the phrase is basically, We're going to be dealing with each other frequently, so let's be on good terms, and saying it back indicates you feel the same way.
question_16: What does onegai mean?
answert_16: Onegai [u304au9858u3044] comes from the ideogram [u9858] which means desire, vote, request and prayer. The word can literally mean request and desire, in addition to please. O shimasu It's from verb suru it means to do. OnegaiAlso derives from the verbdenyWhich literally means to pray for (something) or to wish (something) .
question_17: Is Onegaishimasu a greeting?
answert_17: To ask someone to do something for you, add ONEGAI SHIMASU at the end. Japanese people also use ONEGAI SHIMASU as a kind of greeting. So ONEGAI SHIMASU is a helpful phrase to remember. You can use it to ask someone to do something for you, or as a greeting.
question_18: How do I use onegai?
answert_18: Both kudasai and onegai shimasu are used when making a request for items. Kudasai follows the object and the particle o, like mizu o kudasai. Onegai shimasu can be replaced with kudasai when you want an object. It sounds a little more polite than using 'kudasai'.
question_19: What does Hajimemashite mean literally?
answert_19: The greeting that the Japanese people use in their own language when meeting somebody for the first time is hajimemashite. This translates to either, Nice to meet you, in the English language.
question_20: What is the difference between Yoroshiku and Hajimemashite?
answert_20: Hajimemashite is Nice to meet you for the first time. Douzo yoroshiku is a saying that means, please do good things for me. Another example is like you say it to a superior at work and it's their responsibility to guide you.
question_21: How do you say Hajimemashite in English?
answert_21: Hajimemashite is an expression which roughly translates to, It is the first time (meeting you). However, to make it closer to the equivalent English expression, it is more often translated as Nice to meet you. Hajimemashite is usually the first step to introducing yourself in Japanese.
question_22: What language is Hajimemashite?
answert_22: Hajimemashite (u306fu3058u3081u307eu3057u3066) is a Japanese greeting.

question_25: How do you say goodbye in Japanese?
answert_25: The phrase Irasshaimase! is a more polite version of irasshai, an imperative form of the honorific verb irassharu (u3044u3089u3063u3057u3083u308b) which means to be/come/go. The phrase was originally used by marketplace sellers trying to bring customers closer to their particular stall.

question_1: What is the plot of Ship of Fools?
answert_1: When an eclectic group of passengers boards a cruise ship bound for prewar Germany, they form a microcosm of 1930s society. One passenger, a mysterious countess (Simone Signoret), is headed for a German prison camp. The charming Dr. Schumann (Oskar Werner) harbors a debilitating heart condition. Then theres American divorcxe9e Mary Treadwell (Vivien Leigh), who vainly attempts to outrun time itself. During their weeks at sea, the group forges bonds and rivalries, and unearths secrets.
question_2: What is the purpose of Ship of Fools?
answert_2: The ship of fools is an allegory, originating from Book VI of Plato's Republic, about a ship with a dysfunctional crew. The allegory is intended to represent the problems of governance prevailing in a political system not based on expert knowledge
question_3: What was the name of the ship of fools?
answert_3: The metaphor of a ship filled with fools emerged anew in 1494 when a German theologian named Sebastian Brant wrote a popular book of verse called The Ship of Fools, known as Narrenschiff in German or Stultifera Navis in Latin.
question_4: What year does Ship of Fools take place?
answert_4: Ship of Fools is a 1965 drama film directed by Stanley Kramer, set on board an ocean liner bound to Germany from Mexico in 1933. It stars a prominent ensemble cast, including Vivien Leigh (in her final film role), Simone Signoret, Josxe9 Ferrer and Lee Marvin.

question_22: What does Plato's ship metaphor mean?
answert_22: In the metaphor, found at 488a489d, Plato's Socrates compares the population at large to a strong but near-sighted shipowner whose knowledge of seafaring is lacking. The quarreling sailors are demagogues and politicians, and the ship's navigator, a stargazer, is the philosopher.
question_23: What is the ship a metaphor for?
answert_23: The ship is a metaphor for the United States, which has been battered with heavy loss of life and property during the Civil War. Despite the difficulties, the ship is ultimately 'anchor'd safe and sound. 'The United States have stayed together, and having passed through the war, are safe again.
question_24: What is the purpose of the editorial ship of fools?

question_25: Who coined the phrase ship of fools?
answert_25: Sebastian Brant

question_1: What is the meaning of ship of state?
answert_1: Definition of ship of state : the affairs of a state symbolized as a ship on a course.
question_2: What is the ship of state Creon is referring to?
answert_2: government
question_3: What is the ship analogy?
answert_3: The State is Like a Ship: on Plato's Critique of the Athenian Democracy. In Book 6 of Plato's Republic, in the context of a damning appraisal of the way the democracy at Athens works, Socrates compares the Athenian state to a ship. In this analogy, the citizen population of Athens are the owners of the ship
question_4: What does the phrase ship mean?
answert_4: Shipping refers to the phenomenon; a ship is the concept of a fictional couple; to ship a couple means to have an affinity for it in one way or another; a shipper or a fangirl/boy is somebody significantly involved with such an affinity; a shipping war is when two ships contradict each other, causing fans
question_5: What is Plato's ship of state?
answert_5: The Ship of State is an ancient and oft-cited metaphor, famously expounded by Plato in the Republic (Book 6, 488a489d), which likens the governance of a city-state to the command of a naval vessel.
question_6: Where does the expression ship of fools come from?
answert_6: government
question_7: What is the exact meaning of state?
answert_7: The ship of fools is an allegory, originating from Book VI of Plato's Republic, about a ship with a dysfunctional crew. The allegory is intended to represent the problems of governance prevailing in a political system not based on expert knowledge.
question_8: What is the ship of state and what are the recent storms that threaten it?
answert_8: In Creon's first words to the Chorus, what were the storms that threatened to destroy the Ship of State? Polynieces was the storm that threatened to destroy the ship of state.
question_9: What is the metaphor of the ship Antigone?
answert_9: As he tells Antigone, conjuring the storm-tossed ship as an extended metaphor for the beleaguered Thebes, the ship of state demands that all on board lose their names. Only the ship and the storm remain. To save the ship, Creon has had to terrorize the mob into obedience.
question_10: What is Creon's view of government?
answert_10: Scene 3 What is Creon's view of government, as stated at line 35? How can his views be applied to Antigone's situation? Whoever is chosen to govern should be obeyed..;He is the leader; therefore, she should obey him.
question_11: What does Creon represent?
answert_11: Rather, he represents the very real power of human law and of the human need for an orderly, stable society. When we first see Creon in Oedipus the King, Creon is shown to be separate from the citizens of Thebes.
question_12: What is Plato's analogy of the ship?
answert_12: In Plato's allegory, the ship is equal to the governing system and, in it, the captain represents the ship's owner, who is the peopleit is worth mentioning that Plato's Athens was a democracy.
question_13: What is the lesson of the sailors on the ship analogy?
answert_13: This is an idea that is certainly of a piece with the picture sketched in the analogy to the ship: there the sailors need to acknowledge their own reckless and grasping behaviour if they are ever to stand a chance of benefiting from the wisdom of the navigator on board.
question_14: What is the ship of Theseus problem?
answert_14: The ship of Theseus, also known as Theseus'paradox, is a thought experiment that raises the question of whether an object that has had all of its components replaced remains fundamentally the same object. The paradox is most notably recorded by Plutarch in Life of Theseus from the late first century.
question_15: What is meant by the ship of state?
answert_15: Definition of ship of state : the affairs of a state symbolized as a ship on a course.

question_12: How do you use desu?
answert_12: Desu is the polite form of the copula verb meaning to be or is. It is the verb used to describe two things as being equal, that is, X Y. Typically, this will be done using the pattern: X wa Y desu

question_17: What is the meaning of Deshita?
answert_17: Today's expressions are ikimasu, meaning to go, and kimasu, meaning to come. Ikimasu. You use this phrase to express that someone or something moves from where it is now to another location. Kimasu is used when someone or something moves from a certain place to where the speaker is.
question_18: What is Shimasu?
