question_19: Is the shamisen still used today?
answert_19: Forever Young. The shamisen is still a very popular musical instrument in Japan and now even outside the country. Its use spreads from a classical solo, chamber or concert instrument to folk music and to contemporary versions of some kind of improvised jazz music.
question_20: Where is the shamisen played?
answert_20: While only used in Japan since modern times, from kabuki theatre, puppet plays and other such theatre music, accompaniment to singing, and folk songs from many regions, the shamisen is widely loved.
question_21: Is shamisen made of cat skin?
answert_21: Cat and dog skins have been the material used for shamisen since the Edo period about 400 years ago, says Sakichi Kineya, 63, the latest in seven generations of players. But as you'd expect, using cat or dog skins is not regarded favourably.
question_22: Is shamisen popular in Japan?
answert_22: In the latter half of the Edo era, the foreigners introduce the shamisen as the most popular instrument in Japan and it reached its heyday in the Meiji era around the 19th century.
question_23: What is the meaning of shamisen in music?
answert_23: Definition of shamisen : a 3-stringed Japanese musical instrument resembling a banjo.
question_24: What type of musical instrument is shamisen?
answert_24: Japanese lute
question_25: How does a shamisen work?
answert_25: The shamisen is played with a plectrum (bachi). The notes are produced by pressing the strings on the fingerboard with the index finger, the thumb and sometimes the middle finger. There are other playing techniques, such as the uchi, which does not require a plectrum.

question_1: What happens in chapter 1 of ship breaker?
answert_1: By Paolo Bacigalupi Nailer crawls through an old oil tanker's belly to collect copper wiring for his crew. As he resurfaces on the deck, people around him are tearing apart the oil tanker, scavenging it for parts. Sloth, one of his crewmates, razzes him for taking too long while they take the wire to make a profit.
question_2: What happened in ship breaker?
answert_2: While searching for salvage, they find a girl who is almost dead, and after much debate, decide to rescue the girl instead of killing her. The girl, once she regains consciousness, says people will reward them, and Nailer and Pima reluctantly decide to trust her.
question_3: What happens in chapter 6 of ship breaker?

question_10: Is our DNA our destiny?
answert_10: Your DNA is not your destiny -- or a good predictor of your health. Summary: In most cases, your genes have less than five per cent to do with your risk of developing a particular disease, according to new research. question_25: How do you tell if a verb is transitive or intransitive?
answert_25: When there's an object in a sentence containing an action word, you're dealing with transitive verbs. If there is no object in a sentence containing an action word, yet the sentence still makes sense, then the action word is an intransitive verb

question_8: What is the summary of Shiloh Season?
answert_8: Young Marty (Zachary Browne) adopts Shiloh, a beagle mistreated by its former owner, local hunter and town drunk Judd (Scott Wilson). Realizing that the injured Judd is basically alone in the world, Marty -- with the assistance of his parents, Louise (Ann Dowd) and Ray (Michael Moriarty) -- attempts to forge a friendship with the emotionally stunted man.

question_1: What is Plato's analogy of the ship?
answert_1: In Plato's allegory, the ship is equal to the governing system and, in it, the captain represents the ship's owner, who is the peopleit is worth mentioning that Plato's Athens was a democracy.
question_2: What is the lesson of the sailors on the ship analogy?
answert_2: This is an idea that is certainly of a piece with the picture sketched in the analogy to the ship: there the sailors need to acknowledge their own reckless and grasping behaviour if they are ever to stand a chance of benefiting from the wisdom of the navigator on board.
question_3: What is the meaning of Ship of Theseus?
answert_3: In the metaphysics of identity, the Ship of Theseus is a thought experiment that raises the question of whether an object that has had all of its components replaced remains fundamentally the same object.
question_4: Was the ship of Theseus real?
answert_4: Theseus owned a ship and the ship was entirely made of wood. Every time a piece of the ship needed replacing it was replaced with a metal part. This went on for a few years until eventually it was entirely made of metal.
question_5: What is the significance of the ship analogy?
answert_5: The analogy of the ship thus forms part of Plato's broader argument, but it encapsulates many of his key points on politics in general on the state of Athenian society, on the inadequacy of democracy as a form of government, and on the nature of the alterations to it that he would like to see.
question_6: What was Plato's famous analogy?
answert_6: The Allegory of the Cave
question_7: What does the crew represent in Plato's story of the ship?
answert_7: The crew of the ship, meanwhile, are the disputatious demagogues and politicians who hold sway in Athens'political assembly, each vying for influence and power over their fellow citizens.
question_8: What is meant by the ship of state?
answert_8: Definition of ship of state : the affairs of a state symbolized as a ship on a course.
question_9: What is the point of the ship analogy?
answert_9: Plato expands the established metaphor and ultimately argues that the only people fit to be captain of the ship (Greek: u03bdu03b1u1fe6u03c2) are philosopher kings, benevolent men with absolute power who have access to the Form of the Good.
question_10: How is the role of the good in the intelligible world comparable to the role of the sun in the visible world?
answert_10: In Plato's allegory, the ship is equal to the governing system and, in it, the captain represents the ship's owner, who is the peopleit is worth mentioning that Plato's Athens was a democracy.
question_11: What was the main topic of Book VI of the Republic?
answert_11: Just as the sun is responsible for the world of sight, so the Form of the Good is the cause of the reality of everything else. The Form of the Good alone makes it intelligible that there should be good things like knowledge, truth, and beauty.
question_12: What lesson is learned with the example of ship of Theseus?
answert_12: The story of Theseus's Ship is tremendously important to strong leaders because your people are the ships that your organization's success is depending on. And ships are always in need of repair and improvements. Ask anyone who owns a boat. Never allow your people to feel or think or say that that's just how I am.
question_13: Is the ship of Theseus the same ship?
answert_13: According to Aristotle, the what-it-is of a thing is its formal cause, so the ship of Theseus is the 'same'ship, because the formal cause, or design, does not change, even though the matter used to construct it may vary with time.
question_14: What is the answer to the ship of Theseus?
answert_14: Originally Answered: What is the answer to the Ship of Theseus problem? The answer is that there is no problem with the ship, because there is no ship. First, the world is in a certain state and we look at a part of this state. We name it the Ship of Theseus.
question_15: Is the ship of Theseus still the ship of Theseus?
answert_15: Is the ship of Theseus still the same ship? That is the paradox. Since the ship does not cease to exist after any single part is replaced, it seems that the answer must be yes.
question_16: Is the ship of Theseus a real ship?
answert_16: Applications. A literal example of a Ship of Theseus is DSV Alvin, a submersible that has retained its identity despite all of its components being replaced at least once. A similar example is the USS Constellation which may have been rebuilt using pieces from the original ship.
question_17: Is the ship of Theseus still the same ship?
answert_17: According to Aristotle, the what-it-is of a thing is its formal cause, so the ship of Theseus is the 'same'ship, because the formal cause, or design, does not change, even though the matter used to construct it may vary with time.
question_18: Are humans ships of Theseus?
answert_18: The human body can be considered a ship of Theseus considering that it grows and repairs constantly while still being 'you'.

answert_19: In Plato's allegory, the ship is equal to the governing system and, in it, the captain represents the ship's owner, who is the peopleit is worth mentioning that Plato's Athens was a democracy.
question_20: What is the analogy between the sun and the good?
answert_20: This is an idea that is certainly of a piece with the picture sketched in the analogy to the ship: there the sailors need to acknowledge their own reckless and grasping behaviour if they are ever to stand a chance of benefiting from the wisdom of the navigator on board.
question_21: What analogy does Plato use?
answert_21: Analogy of the Sun
question_22: What is Plato's line analogy?
answert_22: Definition: This is an analogy that Plato uses to distinguish among different forms of knowledge and truth. The visible portion of knowledge is further divided. At the lowest end of the visible are mere images of objects, but above this is understanding of visible objects.
question_23: What was Plato's famous analogy of the cave?
answert_23: In the allegory, Plato likens people untutored in the Theory of Forms to prisoners chained in a cave, unable to turn their heads. All they can see is the wall of the cave. Behind them burns a fire. Between the fire and the prisoners there is a parapet, along which puppeteers can walk.
question_24: What is Plato's most famous theory?
answert_24: His most famous contribution is the theory of Forms known by pure reason, in which Plato presents a solution to the problem of universals known as Platonism (also ambiguously called either Platonic realism or Platonic idealism). He is also the namesake of Platonic love and the Platonic solids.
question_25: Who are the sailors in Plato's metaphor?
answert_25: In the metaphor, found at 488a489d, Plato's Socrates compares the population at large to a strong but near-sighted shipowner whose knowledge of seafaring is lacking. The quarreling sailors are demagogues and politicians, and the ship's navigator, a stargazer, is the philosopher.

question_1: What is Shiloh by Mason about?
answert_1: Shiloh and Other Stories is a 1982 collection of short stories written by American author Bobbie Ann Mason. The short story alluded to in the collection's title, Shiloh, revolves around a man named Leroy who lives in rural Kentucky and is forced to quit his job as a truck driver after an accident.
question_2: What happens at the end of Shiloh?
answert_2: Despite Judd's pointed disapproval of his work, Marty continues to work for him. They begin discussing dogs and Judd's father who began physically abusing Judd when he was four years old. In the end, Judd warms to Marty, repents, and lets him keep Shiloh.
question_3: How does the theme of gender roles apply to the story Shiloh?
answert_3: The Instability of Gender Roles Leroy and Norma Jean swap traditional gender roles, which emasculates Leroy and leads to the breakdown of the Moffitts'marriage. As time goes on, the role-swap convinces Leroy that his wife will leave him. Norma Jean is confused by her own masculine behavior but also emboldened by it.
question_4: What is the theme of Shiloh short story?
answert_4: In Shiloh by Bobbie Ann Mason we have the theme of change, courage, independence, loss, conflict, insecurity, determination and uncertainty.
question_5: What is the central idea of Shiloh by Bobbie Ann Mason?
answert_5: Themes within ShilohWithin the story Shiloh by Bobbie Ann Mason, the three main reoccurring themes are self-fulfillment, independence, and marriage. From these themes, a variety of symbols emerge to demonstrate why both Leroy and Norma Jean have their own particular problems.
question_6: What is the point of view of Shiloh?
answert_6: Shiloh is narrated in the third-person limited point of view, which means that we get only Leroy's perspective. We see the other characters through Leroy's eyes, rather than getting a wholly objective view of them. In Shiloh, Mason's male viewpoint is wholly convincing.
question_7: What happened at the end of Shiloh?
answert_7: On April 7, 1862, the Civil War's Battle of Shiloh ended with a United States (Union) victory over Confederate forces in Pittsburg Landing, Tennessee. The two-day conflict was at that point the bloodiest battle in American history, with more than 23,000 dead and wounded.
question_8: What happens at the end of the story Shiloh?
answert_8: At the end of the story, Leroy sees Norma Jean in the distance, turning towards him from the bluffs overlooking the river:Now she turns towards Leroy and waves her arms. Is she beckoning to him? The final image of the story is of the sky being the color of the dust ruffle made for their bed (7.31).
question_9: What happened to Norma Jean in Shiloh?
answert_9: Something is happening. Norma Jean is going to night school. She has graduated from her six-week body-building course and now she is taking an adult-education course in composition at Paducah Community College.
question_10: Does Norma Jean leave Leroy?
answert_10: In the climactic scene during which Norma Jean says she wants to leave Leroy, she confusedly traces the change back to the day her mother caught her smoking, says she doesn't want to feel like a child anymore, and decides that she was unhappy even before the smoking incident.

question_13: What does the log cabin symbolize in Shiloh?
answert_13: The log cabin that Leroy dreams of building for his wife symbolizes his marriage. The cabin is an impractical idea, and the project does not interest Norma Jean. Leroy clings to his dreams of building the cabin with the same touching and misplaced tenacity with which he clings to his wife.

answert_25: Something is happening. Norma Jean is going to night school. She has graduated from her six-week body-building course and now she is taking an adult-education course in composition at Paducah Community College.

question_1: Who are the Shimerdas in My Antonia?
answert_1: Shimerda, xc1ntonia's father, is the most tragic character in Cather's story and his life is short-lived on the prairie. But his legacy lives on in his daughter xc1ntonia, her children, and in his influence on Jim Burden.
question_2: Why do Jim and Jake have a falling out with the Shimerdas?
answert_2: One event caused a rift between the Shimerdas and the Burdens. One day Jim and Jake rode over to the Shimerdas to get a horse-collar back that Ambrosch had borrowed. Ambrosch fights dirty, and Jake ends up smacking him in the head. xc1ntonia and her mother come running.

question_6: Why do the Shimerdas continue their relationship with Krajiek?
answert_6: During their first several months on the prairie, the Shimerdas never go to town, because Krajiek has convinced them that in town they will somehow be mysteriously separated from their money. question_7: What happens in chapter 10 of my Antonia?
answert_7: Summary: Chapter X Burden resolves to bring a gift of a rooster and foodstuffs to the Shimerdas. As they approach the Shimerda farm, Jim spots xc1ntonia working at the water pump, but she quickly flees back to the house. When Mrs. Shimerda answers the Burdens'call, she is in tears.
question_8: What happens in ntonia family that causes Jim and ntonia to grow apart?
answert_8: The directions that they will take in life are already becoming visible, and they begin to grow apart. Thrown into a more laborious role on the farm, xc1ntonia quickly loses her feminine softness, and Jim's entry into school sets him off on an altogether separate road.
question_9: How do the narrator and Jim become acquainted?
answert_9: How do the narrator and Jim become acquainted? They meet on the train.
question_10: What is the summary of a Nebraska prairie speaks?
answert_10: Book Summary. The novel begins on a train trip in which the narrator and a childhood friend, Jim Burden, share words about the past. Their conversation is a reminiscence about their small hometown of Black Hawk, Nebraska, and a Bohemian girl they both remember named xc1ntonia Shimerda.

question_13: How does Jim describe Antonia?
answert_13: MY xc0NTONIA, by Willa Cather, is a story about friendship, love, and immigration. In this early-20th-century novel, Cather provides a biographical narrative of Antonia Shimerda, a character based upon Annie Pavelka, a real-life childhood friend of Cather's.
question_14: Who is Mrs Harling in My Antonia?
answert_14: Harling. The matriarch of the Harling family, and a charismatic and active woman. Mrs. Harling develops a strong affection for xc1ntonia, and she provides myriad activities for her children, xc1ntonia, and Jim, to take part in.

question_16: Who is the protagonist of my ntonia ntonia or Jim?
answert_16: Who is the protagonist of My xc1ntonia, xc1ntonia or Jim? While many have argued that xc1ntonia is the protagonist of the novel, she always remains at arm's length from the reader, accessible only through Jim's imagination and memory of her.
question_17: What kind of person is Jim Burden?
answert_17: Intelligent and introspective, Jim is well qualified to be the narrator of the story. His thoughtfulness gives him the ability to portray himself and others with consistency and sympathy and to convey the sense of a lost Nebraska with an evocative, poetic accuracy.
question_18: How old is ntonia in my ntonia?
answert_18: At the beginning of the novel, Antonia is a few years older than Jim, who is 10. She is probably around 13
question_19: What is the main theme of My Antonia?
answert_19: Although there are many themes to teach from My Antonia, this guide will focus on nostalgia, perspective, Manifest Destiny, and the undertone of religion. When teaching about America's great expansion westward and the taming of the land, teachers may want to combine textbook work with a novel such as My Antonia.

answert_21: Shimerda, xc1ntonia's father, is the most tragic character in Cather's story and his life is short-lived on the prairie. But his legacy lives on in his daughter xc1ntonia, her children, and in his influence on Jim Burden.
question_22: What does Otto put on the Christmas tree that attracts everyone's attention?
answert_22: Narrator-Jim reflects fondly on his first autumn in Nebraska. He used to frolic around in the prairie. The roads are bordered with sunflowers, and Otto tells Jim that the Mormons planted those seeds in order to mark the way for future travelers.
question_23: Who slaps a boy who tries to kiss her in My Antonia?
answert_23: Harry Paine
question_24: What does Antonia do to the dying grasshopper?
answert_24: One afternoon, xc1ntonia picks up a frail, feebly chirping grasshopper that brings tears to her eyes because it reminds her of an old woman from her village who would sing songs to the children. Jim's nickname for xc1ntonia shows that their friendship has deepened.
question_25: What happens to Peter and Pavel in Nebraska?
answert_25: These two men came to America after a rather unfortunate wedding incident in which they, in order to save themselves, threw both the bride and the groom to a pack of hungry wolves. This ceaseless determination to survive, against all forms of suffering, is one of the hallmarks of the immigrants in this novel.

question_4: How do you use Keredomo in a sentence?
answert_4: KEREDOMO is what is called a paradoxical conjunction. It connects sentences with the meaning of but. So, if you want to say, Anna hurried, but she was unable to make it in time, you say ANNA WA ISOIDA KEREDOMO, MANIAIMASEN DESHITA. Aside from this, you can also use KEREDOMO to link one sentence to another.

question_10: How do I translate pinyin to English?
answert_10: You may know that u600eu4e48(zu011bnme) can mean how, but by adding to it and making it u600eu4e48u6837(zu011bnmeyxe0ng), you can ask how something is, or what it is like. This is useful in all manner of conversations, and is essential for building conversation skills.
question_11: Is Chinese SVO or SOV?
answert_11: Chinese. Generally, Chinese varieties all feature SVO word order. However, especially in Standard Mandarin, SOV is tolerated as well. There is even a special structure to form an SOV sentence.
question_12: What is the grammar structure of Chinese?
answert_12: For many simple cases, the basic sentence structure of Chinese is the same in Chinese as it is in English. Both languages use a subject-verb or subject-verb-object (SVO) formula for making simple sentences. This familiar pattern means that you shouldn't have much trouble with word order at first.
question_13: Is Chinese sentence structure the same as English?
answert_13: Mandarin sentence structure is topic-prominent. One of biggest differences between English and Mandarin sentence structure is that Mandarin is topic-prominent, whereas English is subject-prominent. Saying that English is subject-prominent means that English prefers to put the subject first, obeying its SVO word order.
question_14: Is Chinese sentence structure hard?

question_1: What are the crops grown in shifting cultivation?
answert_1: to practice shifting agriculture (jhum), whereby land is cleared by burning the vegetation, is cultivated for several years, and then is abandoned in favour of another site when the productivity of the soil declines. Rice, corn (maize), millet, and buckwheat are among the chief crops grown by that method.
question_2: Which is the shifting type of cultivation?
answert_2: Shifting cultivation is an agricultural system in which a person uses a piece of land, only to abandon or alter the initial use a short time later. This system often involves clearing of a piece of land followed by several years of wood harvesting or farming until the soil loses fertility.
question_3: Where is shifting cultivation used?
answert_3: The Jummas a group of several tribes in the Chittagong Hill Tracts of northern Bangladesh are named after Jhum, their form of shifting cultivation. The Jumma tribes have developed this farming system to suit the rugged, hilly landscape in which they live.
question_4: What is an example of shifting cultivation?
answert_4: Shifting cultivation is an example of arable, subsistence and extensive farming. It is the traditional form of agriculture in the rainforest. The land is then farmed for 2-3 years before the Indians move on to another area of the rainforest. This allows the area of rainforest to recover.
question_5: What are the main crops grown?

According to USDA Economic Research Service (ERS), the top 10 produce crops in the U.S. are:
  • Corn. It is the most widely produced feed grain in the United States, the majority of which goes towards feeding livestock.
  • Cotton.
  • Fruit.
  • Tree Nuts.
  • Rice.
  • Soybean and Oil Crops.
  • Sugar and Sweeteners.
  • Vegetables.

question_7: What do you mean by shifting cultivation Name one crop grown by shifting cultivation?

question_9: What are the names of shifting cultivation?
answert_9: Shifting Cultivation is known as Ladang in Indonesia, Caingin in Philippines, Milpa in central America Mexico, Ray in Vietnam, Taungya In Myanmar , Tamrai in Thailand, Chena in Sri Lanka, Conuco in Venezuela, Roca in Brazil, Masole in central Africa. In India, it is known by various local names.
question_10: What is shifting cultivation?
answert_10: Shifting agriculture is a system of cultivation in which a plot of land is cleared and cultivated for a short period of time, then abandoned and allowed to revert to producing its normal vegetation while the cultivator moves on to another plot.
question_11: Where is shifting cultivation practiced in the world?
answert_11: Shifting cultivation is practiced by nearly 250 million people, especially in the tropical rain forests of South America, Central and West Africa, and Southeast Asia.
question_12: Who uses shifting cultivation?
answert_12: In the forested upland regions of Laos, shifting cultivation is still the dominant land-use practice due to the limited market access, low population density, and surplus of forest lands. Up to 1.9 million people directly depend on food and income from shifting cultivation.
question_13: Where is shifting cultivation used in India?
answert_13: It is largely practised in the north-eastern region of India, including Assam, Manipur, Mizoram, Nagaland, etc. This way of farming is also known as Jhum Kheti.
question_14: What are some examples of shifting cultivation?
answert_14: Crops Of Shifting Cultivation: The predominant crops include upland rice in Southeast Asia, maize (corn) and manioc (cassava) in South America, and sorghum in Africa. Yams, sugarcane, plantain, and vegetables are also grown in some regions.
question_15: What is the name of shifting cultivation?
answert_15: Swidden agriculture, also known as shifting cultivation, refers to a technique of rotational farming in which land is cleared for cultivation (normally by fire) and then left to regenerate after a few years.
question_16: What is shifting agriculture write one example?
answert_16: Shifting agriculture is the type of cultivation in which the farmers cut trees and clear the land for cultivation. They also burn the uprooted trees and mix their ashes in the soil so as to fertile the soil.
question_17: What is shifting cultivation in short answer?
answert_17: Shifting agriculture is a system of cultivation in which a plot of land is cleared and cultivated for a short period of time, then abandoned and allowed to revert to producing its normal vegetation while the cultivator moves on to another plot.

question_22: Which crops are grown in shifting cultivation?
answert_22: to practice shifting agriculture (jhum), whereby land is cleared by burning the vegetation, is cultivated for several years, and then is abandoned in favour of another site when the productivity of the soil declines. Rice, corn (maize), millet, and buckwheat are among the chief crops grown by that method.
question_23: Which among the following is not a crop grown under shifting cultivation?
answert_23: Rice is not a crop grown in shifting cultivation.
question_24: What is shifting cultivation name the crops produced by shifting cultivation?
answert_24: Shifting agriculture is a system of cultivation in which a plot of land is cleared and cultivated for a short period of time, then abandoned and allowed to revert to producing its normal vegetation while the cultivator moves on to another plot.
question_25: What is shifting cultivation answer?
answert_25: The answer to this question is food grains, namely, maize and millets which are the principal crops. However, most of the communities have shifted to cultivation of cash crops like ginger,jute,turmeric,and pineapple

question_1: What is shift summary?
answert_1: Jennifer Bradbury's Shift is a young adult novel published by Atheneum in 2008. The story focuses on the coming-of-age of two best friends. Chris and Win are high school students who decide to travel on a bicycle trip from West Virginia to Washington state. They make plans to leave after graduation.
question_2: What is the book shift by EM Bailey about?
answert_2: Shift features around a girl, whose age we never know, called Olive. The story is almost two stories in a way, the tragic tale which centres around Katie whilst told from Olive's perspective, and the romantic yet thrilling tale of Olive. Olive is at school with her best friend Ami.
question_3: What happens to win in shift?
answert_3: Imagine riding bikes with your friend when he suddenly disappears for a year. That is what happened to Chris in the novel shift. Two lifelong friends Chris and Win go on a bike ride after graduation. Win disappeared during their journey and was not seen again until college starts.
question_4: Who is the main character in Shift?
answert_4: Chris
question_5: What is the meaning of shift report?
answert_5: Shift reports help improve communication between coworkers or team members, and they ensure proper execution, control and oversight. Managers use shift reports to pass information about proceedings that take place during a specific shift to others.
question_6: How do you write a shift report?
answert_6:
5 Tips for an Effective End-of-Shift Report
  • Give a Bedside Report. Check pertinent things together such as skin, neuro, pulses, etc.
  • Be Specific, Concise and Clear. Stay on point with the 'need to know'information.
  • When in Doubt, Ask for Clarification.
  • Record Everything.
  • Be Positive!
    • 06-Dec-2016
question_7: What should be discussed in a change-of-shift report?
answert_7: It should include the patient's medical history, current medication, allergies, pain levels and pain management plan, and discharge instructions. Providing these sorts of details about your patient in your end of shift report decreases the risk of an oncoming nurse putting the patient in danger.
question_8: Why is a shift report important?
answert_8: Bedside shift reports are viewed as an opportunity to reduce errors and important to ensure communication between nurses and communication. Nurse shift reports and nurse handovers are 2 of the most critical processes in patient care that can support patient safety and reduce medical errors in the United States.

question_1: What are three differences between shield and composite volcanoes?
answert_1: Composite volcanoes have a low magma supply rate, resulting in infrequent eruptions. Shield volcanoes feature basaltic lava. This type of lava is hot, fluid and low in gas content. Shield volcanoes are characterized by a high magma supply rate, lending itself to frequent eruptions.
question_2: What do shield and composite volcanoes have in common?
answert_2: Shield volcanoes erupt quietly. Explosive stratovolcanoes, or composite volcanoes, have steep, symmetrical, conical shapes built up over time by alternating layers of lava flows, volcanic ash, cinders and other volcanic particles. A central vent or cluster of vents is at the summit.
question_3: How are shield and composite volcanoes formed?
answert_3: Composite volcanoes are usually found at destructive plate margins. Examples of composite volcanoes include Mount Fuji (Japan), Mount St Helens (USA) and Mount Pinatubo (Philippines). Shield volcanoes are low with gently sloping sides and are formed from layers of lava. Eruptions are typically non-explosive.
question_4: What is the composition of a shield volcano?
answert_4: Shield volcanoes consist largely of thin lava flows, with minor pyroclastic (mainly ash) layers. Their subaerial (above sea-level) slopes are mostly 4-8 degrees, having steep-walled summit calderas and also pit craters (sinkholes) that are similar to calderas in form but much smaller.
question_5: What are the major differences between shield volcanoes and stratovolcanoes?
answert_5: Stratovolcanoes have relatively steep sides and are more cone-shaped than shield volcanoes. They are formed from viscous, sticky lava that does not flow easily. The lava therefore builds up around the vent forming a volcano with steep sides.
question_6: What are the 3 types of volcanoes describe the differences between each type?
answert_6: There are three main types of volcano - composite or strato, shield and dome. Composite volcanoes, sometimes known as strato volcanoes, are steep sided cones formed from layers of ash and [lava] flows. A pyroclastic flow is a superheated mixture of hot steam, ash, rock and dust.
question_7: What are the 3 characteristics of a composite volcano?
answert_7:
Composite volcanoes have the following characteristics:
  • Acidic lava, which is very viscous (sticky).
  • Steep sides as the lava doesn't flow very far before it solidifies.
  • Alternate layers of ash and lava. For this reason, they're also known as stratovolcanoes .
  • Violent eruptions.
  • Longer periods between eruptions.
question_8: How are shield and composite volcanoes similar?
answert_8: Composite cone volcanoes are cone-shaped volcanoes composed of layers of lava, ash and rock debris. Composite cone volcanoes can grow to heights of 8,000 feet or more and have explosive eruptions. Shield volcanoes are broad, domed-shaped volcanoes with long, gently sloped sides.
question_9: What do shield volcanoes and composite volcanoes have in common?
answert_9: Shield volcanoes erupt quietly. Explosive stratovolcanoes, or composite volcanoes, have steep, symmetrical, conical shapes built up over time by alternating layers of lava flows, volcanic ash, cinders and other volcanic particles. A central vent or cluster of vents is at the summit.
question_10: How are the 3 types of volcanoes similar?
answert_10: There are three main types of volcano - composite or strato, shield and dome. Composite volcanoes, sometimes known as strato volcanoes, are steep sided cones formed from layers of ash and [lava] flows. Composite volcanoes are usually found at destructive plate margins.
question_11: What do volcanoes have in common?
answert_11: Volcano Shapes Most land volcanoes have the same basic structure, but volcano shape and size varies considerably. There are several elements that these different volcano types have in common are: a summit crater - the mouth of the volcano, where the lava exists. a magma chamber - where the lava wells up underground.
question_12: How is the composite volcanoes formed?
answert_12: Composite cone volcanoes are also called stratovolcanoes. They form when different types of eruptions deposit different materials around the sides of a volcano. Alternating eruptions of volcanic ash and lava cause layers to form. Over time these layers build up.
question_13: How are volcanic shields formed?
answert_13: Shield volcanoes are formed by lava flows of low viscosity - lava that flows easily. Consequently, a volcanic mountain having a broad profile is built up over time by flow after flow of relatively fluid basaltic lava issuing from vents or fissures on the surface of the volcano.
question_14: What are composite volcanoes most likely to form?
answert_14: Composite volcanoes are some of the most dangerous volcanoes on the planet. They tend to occur along oceanic-to-oceanic or oceanic-to-continental boundaries because of subduction zones. They tend to be made of felsic to intermediate rock and the viscosity of the lava means that eruptions tend to be explosive.
question_15: How is each type of volcano formed?
answert_15: When magma erupts at the surface as lava, it can form different types of volcano depending on: the amount of gas in the magma. the composition of the magma. the way in which the magma reached the surface.
question_16: What composition do shield volcanoes have?
answert_16: lava flows
question_17: Are shield volcanoes Composite?
answert_17: Composite volcanoes are tall, steep cones that produce explosive eruptions. Shield volcanoes form very large, gently sloped mounds from effusive eruptions. Cinder cones are the smallest volcanoes and result from accumulation of many small fragments of ejected material.
question_18: Do shield volcanoes have mafic composition?
answert_18: Composite Cones - Stratovolcanoes Intermediate lavas are more viscous than the mafic lava which forms shield volcanoes (see above) and normally contain more volatiles.
question_19: What is volcanic composition?
answert_19: There are three basic types of magma: basaltic, andesitic, and rhyolitic, each of which has a different mineral composition. All types of magma have a significant percentage of silicon dioxide. Basaltic magma is high in iron, magnesium, and calcium but low in potassium and sodium.
question_20: What are the main characteristic differences between Shield and Strato volcano?
answert_20: Size Differences Composite volcanoes, also known as stratovolcanoes, are towering structures, often rising more than 10,000 feet. Shield volcanoes are broad, typically 20 times wider than they are high. These volcanoes can be massive.
question_21: What are 3 differences between shield and composite volcanoes?
answert_21: Composite cone volcanoes are cone-shaped volcanoes composed of layers of lava, ash and rock debris. Composite cone volcanoes can grow to heights of 8,000 feet or more and have explosive eruptions. Shield volcanoes are broad, domed-shaped volcanoes with long, gently sloped sides.

answert_22: Why do shield volcanoes have such a different shape than stratovolcanoes? vent and tumble to form slopes of about 30 degrees; they build the cone higher near the vent. Why do the Hawaiian Islands form a chain of volcanoes? An active hotspot volcano lies in the ocean basin near the Hawaiian Islands.
question_23: What are 3 different types of volcanoes?
answert_23: There are three types of volcanoes: cinder cones (also called spatter cones), composite volcanoes (also called stratovolcanoes), and shield volcanoes.

answert_22: As Hank Storm, Zits confronts the truth of the violence he committed. He must contrast the ugliness of people like Art and Horse to a hero like Jimmy, and realize he has acted more like the former.
question_23: What is zits real name?
answert_23: Flight is a novel written by Sherman Alexie. At the start of the novel Zits was ashamed of who he was and what he looked like. The reason he called himself Zits was because his face was full of zits. He felt like his real name was of no importance and so he decided to name himself after his pimples.
question_24: What does zits learn in flight?
answert_24: Ultimately, Zits learns that an individual's identity is defined more by his/her behavior than by his/her race or wealth. No magical identity solves every problem. Instead, each person must work hard to become someone he/she can be proud of.
question_25: What does zits learn from Hank?
answert_25: Hank is an FBI agent who lives a complex life. He is a father, husband, defender, and life-taker. Zits learns that there is more to people than that is on the surface

question_2: Who is the real monster in Shelley's Frankenstein?

question_3: How does the monster relate to Mary Shelley?

question_4: What is the story of Frankenstein monster?
answert_4: The book tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a Swiss student of natural science who creates an artificial man from pieces of corpses and brings his creature to life. Though it initially seeks affection, the monster inspires loathing in everyone who meets it.

question_1: What is the sheep look up about?
answert_1: The Sheep Look Up explores a future dystopia occurring as a result of rampant consumerism and pollution. It succeeds 1968's Stand on Zanzibar (overpopulation) and 1969's The Jagged Orbit (racial tension and violence), and precedes 1975's Shockwave Rider (technology and future shock) in the book series.
question_2: What did Stand on Zanzibar predict?
answert_2: In his 1968 novel Stand on Zanzibar, for instance, he peers ahead to imagine life in 2010, correctly forecasting wearable technology, Viagra, video calls, same-sex marriage, the legalisation of cannabis, and the proliferation of mass shootings.

question_5: What did HG Wells predicted?
answert_5: Nominated four times for the Nobel Prize in Literature, Wells, the futurist, foresaw the coming of aircraft, tanks, the sexual revolution, the atomic bomb, and created the classic templates for every story that has been written about alien invasion (his inspiration for The War of the Worlds, says Tomalin, was
question_6: Why is it called Stand on Zanzibar?
answert_6: Title. The primary engine of the novel's story is overpopulation and its projected consequences. The title refers to an early twentieth-century claim that the world's population could fit onto the Isle of Wightwhich has an area of 381 square kilometres (147 sq mi)if they were all standing upright.

question_7: How do you draw a shell diagram?
answert_7:
How to draw an electron configuration diagram
  • Find the element on the periodic table.
  • Draw a small circle and write the symbol in the centre.
  • Draw a circle around the nucleus.

  • Draw another circle around the first shell.
  • Add up to eight electrons to the second shell.

answert_19: Shell elements are used to model structures in which one dimension, the thickness, is significantly smaller than the other dimensions. Conventional shell elements use this condition to discretize a body by defining the geometry at a reference surface.
question_20: What is the shell model of an atom?
answert_20: In this model, electrons (negatively charged fundamental particles) in atoms are thought of as occupying diffuse shells in the space surrounding a dense, positively charged nucleus. The first shell is closest to the nucleus. The others extend outward from the nucleus and overlap one another.

question_1: What is an example of alliteration the She Walks in Beauty?
answert_1: In She Walks in Beauty, alliteration is employed here: Of cloudless climes and starry skies; (l. 2); The smiles that win, the tints that glow, (l. 15). There are more examples of this in the poem.
question_2: What two contrasting images are discussed in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_2: Night and Day, Dark and Light The contrast between night and day, and dark and light, is the image that sets up the whole poem.
question_3: What does the figurative language and imagery suggest about the theme of the poem She Walks in Beauty?
answert_3: The opening lineShe walks in beauty, like the night/ of cloudless climes and starry skiesis a simile which initiates the woman's harmony with nature as well as her ethereal beauty, evoked by the second line: Of cloudless climes and starry skies. The light/dark imagery introduced in the first line is continued in
question_4: What kind of poem is She Walks in Beauty?
answert_4: short lyrical poem
question_5: What rhyme is used in the text She walks in beauty?
answert_5: She Walks In Beauty is a rhyming poem of 3 equal stanzas, 18 lines in total. All the end rhymes are full (except for brow/glow which is a near rhyme) and the rhyme scheme is: ababab where alternate rhymes add to and complement the idea of balance and harmony. For example: night/bright.
question_6: What sound devices are used in She walks in beauty?
answert_6: For instance, in the first stanza there are two examples of alliteration in the second line ('Of cloudless climes and starry skies') while a pattern of assonance weaves around this (the 'i'sounds of: 'night', 'climes', 'skies', 'bright', 'eyes', 'light'and 'denies').
question_7: What are the poetic devices used in the poem beauty?
answert_7: In the poem, the poet uses visual imagery (beauty is seen), olfactory imagery (beauty is heard), sensory imagery (beauty is in yourself). Repetition: It is the repetition of words and phrases for poetic effect.
question_8: What does She walks in beauty like the night mean?
answert_8: The speaker compares this woman to a lovely night with a clear starry sky, and goes on to convey her beauty as a harmonious meeting between darkness and light. After its discussion of physical attractiveness, the poem then portrays this outer beauty as representative of inner goodness and virtue
question_9: What is the contrast in She walks in beauty?
answert_9: The poem is about an unnamed woman. She's really quite striking, and the speaker compares her to lots of beautiful, but dark, things, like night and starry skies. The second stanza continues to use the contrast between light and dark, day and night, to describe her beauty.
question_10: What kind of love is presented in She walks in beauty?
answert_10: The beauty of the woman the speaker describes is in both her external appearance and her inner goodness. Although it might generally be classified as a love poem the poet never actually declares that love. He concentrates on the subject's captivating attractiveness and purity.
question_11: What does the figurative language and imagery suggest about the theme of the poem She walks in beauty?
answert_11: The opening lineShe walks in beauty, like the night/ of cloudless climes and starry skiesis a simile which initiates the woman's harmony with nature as well as her ethereal beauty, evoked by the second line: Of cloudless climes and starry skies. The light/dark imagery introduced in the first line is continued in
question_12: How does Byron use the technique of comparison in She walks in beauty?
answert_12: The very first line contains a simile (comparing two things using like or as): She walks in beauty like the night. Byron then goes on to expand on that simile, saying, that like the night, her eyes have all that's best of dark and bright, referring to the beauty of the dark skies, and the light of the stars.
question_13: What figurative language is used in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_13: There is one simile used in the opening line of the poem, She walks in beauty, like the night. Lord Byron compares the walk of that lady with a dark and clear night which also means that her footsteps are not heard.
question_14: What is the main theme of the poem She Walks in Beauty?
answert_14: The primary theme of She Walks in Beauty is the perfect beauty and goodness of an idealized woman. Byron makes no attempt to give his subject any individuality, instead making her universal, so that any man in love can see his inamorata in the poem.
question_15: What is the theme of when we two parted?
answert_15: A brief lyric consisting of four short stanzas, When We Two Parted is a poem about grief and regret in which the first-person speaker mourns not only the loss of a romantic relationship, but also a loss of innocence. From the present tense, the poem looks back in time, to when the affair was ended.
question_16: What is the main allusion in the poem She Walks in Beauty?
answert_16: Inspired by the beauty of Byron's cousin while she was wearing a black mourning gown. When the poem says with all below this alludes to the woman is high above everyone else with her beauty and grace.
question_17: Is She Walks in Beauty a romantic poem?
answert_17: She Walks in Beauty by Lord Byron is a good example of romantic poetry because of his use of imagination, nature, emotion, and appreciation to convey his thoughts to the reader in the poem. Throughout She Walks in Beauty Lord Byron compares the woman's appearance to the beauty of nature multiple times.
question_18: What is the theme of the poem She Walks in Beauty?
answert_18: Major Themes: The major themes of the poem include beauty and harmony of mind and body. Lord Byron describes and compares beauty with a variety of phrases such as tender light as he creates beautiful imagery for her charming features, the eloquence of speech and purity of love.
question_19: What is the beauty in poetry?
answert_19: Interestedness requires sympathy, so poetic beauty might be defined as the result of subjective sympathy: paying enough attention to a poem for it to teach us how to read it and (crucially) feeling that it fulfills the terms it lays out.
question_20: What is the rhyme of She Walks in Beauty?
answert_20: The rhyme scheme is regular and follows the pattern ababab. The rhythm of the poem is highly regular. This consistent rhythm emphasises the regularity of the subject's walk but also her faultless perfection.
question_21: What is the rhyme scheme of Stanza 2 in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_21: The poem follows a rhyme scheme of ABABAB. The poem's meter is also written in iambic tetrameter. This means that the lines contain four sets of two beats, the first of which is an unstressed syllable and the second of which is a stressed syllable. These two syllables together make one iamb.
question_22: What is the figure of speech in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_22: There is one simile used in the opening line of the poem, She walks in beauty, like the night. Lord Byron compares the walk of that lady with a dark and clear night which also means that her footsteps are not heard. Metaphor: There are two metaphors in the poem, in lines eleven and twelve.
question_23: What is an example of alliteration the She walks in beauty?
answert_23: In She Walks in Beauty, alliteration is employed here: Of cloudless climes and starry skies; (l. 2); The smiles that win, the tints that glow, (l. 15). There are more examples of this in the poem.
question_24: What sound devices are used in the poem She walks in beauty?
answert_24: By George Gordon, Lord Byron Of cloudless climes and starry skies; Byron mostly chooses long vowel sounds that make you open up your mouth as you read it out loud. The alliteration in the second line sounds particularly soothing and musical. (After all, Byron did intend for the poem to be set to music.)
question_25: How is alliteration used in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_25: By alliteration, we understand the repetition of the initial consonant in a series of words. In She Walks in Beauty, alliteration is employed here: Of cloudless climes and starry skies; (l. 2); The smiles that win, the tints that glow, (l. 15).

question_1: What is the summary of She Walks in Beauty?
answert_1: While She walks in Beauty primarily focuses on physical beauty, it also explores the relationship between inner beauty and outer beauty. It portrays these concepts as closely interconnected. Indeed, the woman's outer appearance is read as a sign of her inner serenity, peacefulness, and innocence.

question_7: Is She Walks in Beauty a romantic poem?

Throughout She Walks in Beauty Lord Byron compares the woman's appearance to the beauty of nature multiple times.
question_8: What is the theme of the poem She Walks in Beauty?

question_9: What is the beauty in poetry?
answert_9: Interestedness requires sympathy, so poetic beauty might be defined as the result of subjective sympathy: paying enough attention to a poem for it to teach us how to read it and (crucially) feeling that it fulfills the terms it lays out.

question_20: What kind of beauty is Byron defining in She Walks in Beauty?
answert_20: In the poem She Walks in Beauty, Byron describes the beauty of an unnamed woman. He describes this beauty in terms of the contrast and balance of light and dark. In this way, he shows that the woman's beauty is not unearthly, but it is still unusual.
question_21: Why did Lord Byron Write She walks in beauty?
answert_21: Lord Byron's poem She Walks in Beauty was written in praise of a beautiful woman. History holds that he wrote it for a female cousin, Mrs. Wilmot, whom he ran into at a party in London one night when she was in mourning, wearing a black dress with glittering sequins.

question_17: What is the main theme of the poem She Walks in Beauty?
answert_17: The primary theme of She Walks in Beauty is the perfect beauty and goodness of an idealized woman. Byron makes no attempt to give his subject any individuality, instead making her universal, so that any man in love can see his inamorata in the poem.

question_1: What is the main theme of She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_1: The main themes in She Stoops to Conquer are concealment and revelation, class distinctions, and freedom and constraint. Concealment and revelation: Much of the play's plot depends on characters'misinterpretations of reality, usually due to deception.
question_2: What is the social message of She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_2: The overriding theme of She Stoops to Conquer is how reality is often distorted by social status. The rigid English social system effectively encourages people to be someone other than who they really are. This is illustrated by Marlow's awkwardness around women of his own class.
question_3: What is the moral lesson of She Stoops to Conquer by Oliver Goldsmith?
answert_3: She Stoops to Conquer satirizes the inability of the landed gentry to adapt to a changing world, placing too much emphasis on class distinctions and a marriage market based on money and class rather than love and compatibility.
question_4: What is the meaning of stoop to conquer?
answert_4: To adopt a role, position, attitude, behavior, undertaking, etc., that is seen as being beneath one's abilities or social position in order to achieve one's end.
question_5: What is the book She Stoops to Conquer about?
answert_5: The overriding theme of She Stoops to Conquer is how reality is often distorted by social status. The rigid English social system effectively encourages people to be someone other than who they really are. This is illustrated by Marlow's awkwardness around women of his own class.
question_6: What are the themes in the play by Oliver Goldsmith?
answert_6: The play centers around the desire of Hardcastle, a wealthy landowner in the country, for his daughter, Kate Hardcastle, to marry the well-educated Charles Marlow. Together with Marlow's father, Sir Charles Marlow, they arrange for the younger Marlow to visit the Hardcastle's house and court Kate.
question_7: What is the main conflict and climax Oliver Goldsmith's She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_7: Contradiction in Human Nature: One of the major themes of the play is that of contradiction in human nature. Most characters in the play want others to be simple to understand. This in many ways mirrors the expectations of an audience that Goldsmith wishes to mock.
question_8: What is the moral lesson of the play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_8: A main moral message of this play is that truth does not necessarily appear on the surface, but has to be searched out. Although it can often seem immoral to use stratagems to discover the truth about people, this play shows that sometimes truth only appears in a roundabout wayand that's OK.
question_9: What is the meaning of She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_9: stoop to conquer. To adopt a role, position, attitude, behavior, undertaking, etc., that is seen as being beneath one's abilities or social position in order to achieve one's end.
question_10: What does Goldsmith wants to convey through his play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_10: In this exquisite comedy of manners, Goldsmith seeks to lay bare the many hypocrisies and double standards at the heart of upper-class English society. In particular, he wants to draw attention to the enormous gap between how the characters perceive themselves and how they really are
question_11: Who is the central character of She Stoops to Conquer and why?
answert_11: The play centers around the desire of Hardcastle, a wealthy landowner in the country, for his daughter, Kate Hardcastle, to marry the well-educated Charles Marlow. question_1: What does it mean if a girl says sorry for replying late?
answert_1: It usually just means that she forgot or something came up. You don't know what's happening on her end. Maybe she got a call from her mom, or someone rang the doorbell and she forgot to come back to her phone. Maybe she was texting while doing homework and got caught up in what she was doing.
question_2: How do you respond to Sorry for the late reply?
answert_2: Once again, apologies, and I look forward to hearing from you. Please accept my sincere apologies for this late reply to your email. With so much time gone by, can I ask if you still need answers to your questions? I would be delighted to help.
question_3: Is Sorry for the late response correct?
answert_3: sorry for the late response vs sorry for late response. Sorry for late response is missing the article the. The correct version is sorry for the late response.
question_4: Do you apologize for texting back late?
answert_4: Really sorry to text you so late. Short and simple, this apology shows that you're aware of the late hour. If your message just can't wait, let your recipient know that you understand how late it is (and you're not too happy about it either). You might also say something like, I know it's late, sorry about that.
question_5: What does it mean when a girl reply late?
answert_5: Late replies only mean she has a life and isn't glued to her phone. Short replies mean she's not really interested.
question_6: What does it mean when a girl says sorry?
answert_6: Once again, apologies, and I look forward to hearing from you. Please accept my sincere apologies for this late reply to your email. With so much time gone by, can I ask if you still need answers to your questions? I would be delighted to help.
question_7: Should you reply late if she replies late?
answert_7: Sometimes saying sorry is habitual, its a habit she gained after years of being insecure and not wanting people to dislike her. Saying sorry can be a quick cop-out essentially. Even if she might be a completely confident person she may be self-conscious around you in certain situations ( Or this may be vice versa ).
question_8: How do you respond to an apology for late reply?
answert_8:
If this is not a super common thing, accept the apology and move on.
  • Not the end of the world. This is a smooth response that still acknowledges she did something wrong.
  • All good.
  • It's alright. If you want to subtly hint that you're annoyed, this works well.
question_9: What is the reply when someone says sorry?
answert_9: 5 English Phrases to Respond to an Apology It happens. No problem. Don't worry about it. I forgive you.
question_10: How do I say sorry for my late response?
answert_10: If you're apologizing for the late response, make sure you lead by acknowledging your response is late. A simple, Apologies for the delayed response or, Sorry for not getting back to you sooner does the trick.
question_11: Is it correct to say sorry for the late?
answert_11: This is not correct. Don't use this phrase. While this phrase is technically not incorrect, it sounds better to say sorry for sending this late.
question_12: Should you apologize for responding late?
answert_12: While non-urgent emails don't always require an apology for a delayed response, urgent ones almost always do. As important as it is to apologize for a late email reply, it's just as important to say sorry only in situations when an apology is really warranted.
question_13: Should you apologize for texting back late?
answert_13: How you handle the response depends a great deal on the sender, but in general it's best to simply apologize for the delay with any relevant reason, such as not having your phone with you, being overwhelmed with a project, or the simple fact that the message was lost in your inbox.

question_1: Shall Not Be Moved means?
answert_1: I Shall Not Be Moved, also known as We Shall Not Be Moved, is an African-American slave spiritual, hymn, and protest song dating to the early 19th century American south. The song describes being like a tree planted by the waters who shall not be moved because of faith in God.
question_2: What is the meaning of Psalm 46 5?
answert_2: This psalm reminds us that, if we are filled with the spirit of God, we may experience falls and failures but He is right there to pick us up and help us during those times. God will rescue us if we are being defeated.

question_1: What is the summary of she stoop to conquer?
answert_1: The play centers around the desire of Hardcastle, a wealthy landowner in the country, for his daughter, Kate Hardcastle, to marry the well-educated Charles Marlow. Together with Marlow's father, Sir Charles Marlow, they arrange for the younger Marlow to visit the Hardcastle's house and court Kate.
question_2: What is the main theme of the play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_2: The main themes in She Stoops to Conquer are concealment and revelation, class distinctions, and freedom and constraint. Concealment and revelation: Much of the play's plot depends on characters'misinterpretations of reality, usually due to deception.
question_3: Who wrote She Stoops to Conquer summary?
answert_3: Oliver Goldsmith
question_4: Who is the central character of She Stoops to Conquer and why?
answert_4: Character Analysis in She Stoops to Conquer. Charles Marlow: Charles Marlow, the play's central male character, is a modest and well-educated man who has set out to court Kate Hardcastle.
question_5: How does Kate stoop conquer Marlow?
answert_5: The main themes in She Stoops to Conquer are concealment and revelation, class distinctions, and freedom and constraint. Concealment and revelation: Much of the play's plot depends on characters'misinterpretations of reality, usually due to deception.
question_6: What is the conflict in She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_6: Oliver Goldsmith
question_7: What is the social message of She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_7: The overriding theme of She Stoops to Conquer is how reality is often distorted by social status. The rigid English social system effectively encourages people to be someone other than who they really are. This is illustrated by Marlow's awkwardness around women of his own class.
question_8: What are the themes in the play by Oliver Goldsmith?
answert_8: Contradiction in Human Nature: One of the major themes of the play is that of contradiction in human nature. Most characters in the play want others to be simple to understand. This in many ways mirrors the expectations of an audience that Goldsmith wishes to mock.
question_9: What is the book She Stoops to Conquer about?
answert_9: The play centers around the desire of Hardcastle, a wealthy landowner in the country, for his daughter, Kate Hardcastle, to marry the well-educated Charles Marlow. Together with Marlow's father, Sir Charles Marlow, they arrange for the younger Marlow to visit the Hardcastle's house and court Kate.
question_10: What is the significance of the title She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_10: The title of this novel refers to the stooping down of Kate Hardcastle from her position in high society to the position as a barmaid. She does this in order to test the feelings of Marlow, to make sure that he loves her for herself and not for her money.
question_11: Who wrote a sequel to She Stoops to Conquer in 1778?

question_13: Who is the central character of the play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_13: Kate Hardcastle is the character with whom the audience sympathizes the most. The central plot revolves around her trying to find a husband who will be compatible with her rather than just one of the right social class. The other marriage and love plots in the play serve mainly as foils to the central plot.
question_14: Who is the most admirable character in She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_14: CONSTANCE NEVILLE She is in love with George Hastings who plans to elope with her to France but cannot because she cannot leave her jewels behind. Neville is equally admirable and honest; she is also loving and charming and helps in her own way to resolve some of the numerous mistakes in the play.
question_15: Why is Tony Lumpkin an important character in She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_15: Tony Lumpkin is therefore an important character in the way that he is used to introduce important themes, but also in the way that he is the agent that is able to clear the way for one of the couples, Hastings and Constance to marry, simultaneously destroying his mother's plans for him.
question_16: Who is the chief of the servants She Stoops to Conquer?

question_17: How does Kate win the heart of Marlow?
answert_17: Humorous mishaps occur when Tony dupes Marlow and Hastings into believing that Mr. Hardcastle's home is an inn. By posing as a servant, Kate wins the heart of Marlow, who is uncomfortable in the company of wellborn women but is flirtatious with barmaids.
question_18: How does Kate manage to cure Marlow's duplicity in She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_18: Kate thus cures Marlow through disguising herself and tricking him, which also gives her the opportunity to get to know her future husband.
question_19: How does Kate as the barmaid rebuff Marlow?
answert_19: When she changes back into her regular clothing, Marlow mistakes her for the barmaid. He flirts with her and calls her pretty. In an effort to seduce Marlow, Kate pretends to be the barmaid so he does not talk to her in a stiff, reserved manner as he did when she was in her more conservative dress.
question_20: How does Constance Neville stoop conquer?
answert_20: Now that Constance has them, however, her path to marrying Hastings is clear. Constance Neville stoops to conquer, in that she attempts to hoodwink her aunt, Mrs. Hardcastle, to marry the man that she wantsHastingswithout forfeiting her inheritance.
question_21: What is the main conflict and climax in Oliver Goldsmith's She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_21: Tony Lumpkin will get 1,500 pounds a year when he comes of age. Thus, without financial worries, he devotes himself to ale and a do-nothing life. The climax occurs when Kate reveals her true identity to young Marlow while Hardcastle and Sir Charles listen behind a screen.

question_23: What is the setting of the play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_23: The setting for She Stoops to Conquer is England and the interactions between the characters take place at the Three Pigeons Ale House, an old country manor, and the surrounding grounds and countryside.

question_25: What is the moral lesson of the play She Stoops to Conquer?
answert_25: A main moral message of this play is that truth does not necessarily appear on the surface, but has to be searched out. Although it can often seem immoral to use stratagems to discover the truth about people, this play shows that sometimes truth only appears in a roundabout wayand that's OK.

question_1: Is Juliet turning 14?
answert_1: In Act I, scene iii, we learn that Juliet will turn fourteen in a little more than two weeks, meaning that she's thirteen during the events of the play. Legally, girls in Elizabethan England could marry as young as 12 with parental consent.
question_2: When Capulet speaks of his daughter to Paris he notes that she is not yet fourteen years old?
answert_2: When Capulet speaks of his daughter to Paris, he notes that she is not yet fourteen years old. Capulet eagerly promises Paris that he may wed Juliet as soon as possible. Romeo and Benvolio overhear Capulet inviting Paris to a party at the Capulet home.
question_3: What does Capulet mean when he says the earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she?

question_4: What does Lady Capulet mean when she says so shall you share all that he doth possess by having him making yourself no less?
answert_4: Here, Lady Capulet means that Juliet will not be less of a person once she's married to Paris. The Nurse turns the idea bawdy by implying that Juliet will literally grow get bigger with pregnancy.
question_5: Is Juliet a 14 year old?
answert_5: A 13-year-old girl, Juliet is the only daughter of the patriarch of the House of Capulet. She falls in love with the male protagonist Romeo, a member of the House of Montague, with which the Capulets have a blood feud. The story has a long history that precedes Shakespeare himself.

question_9: What does Lord Capulet mean when he says this about Juliet My child is yet a stranger in the world?
answert_9: Her father means that she is inexperienced, which she is, but Juliet is also a stranger in the world because she prefers the transcendent experience she shares with Romeo to the compromises and practicalities of everyday life, even to the extent of choosing to die rather than live in a world without Romeo.
question_10: What is Paris reaction to Capulet's statement about his daughters age?
answert_10: Paris argues: Younger than she are happy mothers made. And Capulet voices one of his major objections. And too soon marr'd are those so early made.
question_11: How does Capulet respond when Juliet tells him she will not marry Paris?

question_12: What does Lady Capulet think about Juliet getting married to Paris at fourteen?
answert_12: Even though Juliet is not yet fourteen, Lady Capulet thinks it's the right thing to do and argues that many other girls of Verona marry and have children at even younger ages than Juliet. She tells her to keep her eye on Paris at the party to determine if she could marry him.
question_13: What does the quote She is the hopeful lady of my earth mean?
answert_13: Capulet describes Juliet as 'the hopeful lady of my earth'which suggests he sees her as security in a business arrangement which will maintain his social status and acknowledge he has done his duty in providing his only child with a rich husband.

question_21: Is Juliet almost 14 years old?
answert_21: Juliet is almost 14 years old. Juliet refuses to marry Paris because she loves someone else. Tybalt is glad Romeo was able to attend the Capulet party. Benvolio and Romeo overhear Capulet talking about his party, and decide to sneak in.
question_22: How old is Juliet in Romeo and Juliet?
answert_22: Juliet Capulet, on the cusp of 14 years old, falls in love with Romeo, the son of her family's enemy.

question_24: Is Juliet twelve years old?
answert_24: The age is probably significant: the audience know that Juliet is one year older than twelve an age when, as far as the nurse is concerned she may be ready to lose her virginity. The bawdiness in the play is a constant undercurrent to the purity of Romeo and Juliet's love.
